Question: What do you expect? They're savages. One lot steals a goat from another lot and before you know it, they're ripping each other to pieces.
Answer: I've never seen wildlings do a thing like this. I've never seen a thing like this, not ever in my life.

Question: How close did you get?
Answer: Close as any man would.

Question: Do the dead frighten you?
Answer: Our orders were to track the wildlings. We tracked them. They won't trouble us no more.

Question: You don't think he'll ask us how they died? Get back on your horse.
Answer: Whatever did it to them could do it to us. They even killed the children.

Question: What is it?
Answer: It's …

Question: And which one of you was a marksman at ten? Keep practicing, Bran. Go on.
Answer: Don't think too much, Bran.

Question: Do you have to?
Answer: He swore an oath, Cat.

Question: You understand why I did it?
Answer: Jon said he was a deserter.

Question: But do you understand why I had to kill him?
Answer: Our way is the old way?

Question: Our way is the old way?
Answer: The man who passes the sentence should swing the sword.

Question: Is it true he saw the White Walkers?
Answer: The White Walkers have been gone for thousands of years.

Question: So he was lying?
Answer: A madman sees what he sees.

Question: What is it?
Answer: Mountain lion?

Question: Mountain lion?
Answer: There are no mountain lions in these woods.

Question: You want to hold it?
Answer: Where will they go? Their mother's dead.

Question: Where will they go? Their mother's dead.
Answer: They don't belong down here.

Question: Lord Stark? There are five pups. One for each of the Stark children. The direwolf is the sigil of your House. They were meant to have them.
Answer: You will train them yourselves. You will feed them yourselves. And if they die, you will bury them yourselves.

Question: What about you?
Answer: I'm not a Stark. Get on.

Question: What is it?
Answer: The runt of the litter. That one's yours, Snow.

Question: What if Jon Arryn told someone?
Answer: But who would he tell?

Question: But who would he tell?
Answer: My husband.

Question: If he told the king, both our heads would be skewered on the city gates by now. Whatever Jon Arryn knew or didn't know, it died with him. And Robert will choose a new Hand of the king, someone to do his job while he's off fucking boars and hunting whores. Or is it the other way around? And life will go on.
Answer: You should be the Hand of the king.

Question: How much could he possibly drink? A man of his … stature.
Answer: We've brought up eight barrels of ale from the cellar. Perhaps we'll find out.

Question: Why's your mother so dead-set on us getting pretty for the king?
Answer: It's for the queen, I bet. I hear she's [sleek as a mink?]

Question: It's for the queen, I bet. I hear she's [sleek as a mink?]
Answer: I hear the prince is a right royal prick.

Question: D'you know what?
Answer: What?

Question: What?
Answer: You always look at your feet before you lie. Run and find your father. Tell him the king is close.

Question: Where's Arya? Sansa, where's your sister?
Answer: Hey,, hey, hey, hey. What are you doing with that on? [Pulls off ARYA's helm]

Question: Hey,, hey, hey, hey. What are you doing with that on? [Pulls off ARYA's helm]
Answer: Move!

Question: Nine years. Why haven't I seen you? Where the hell have you been?
Answer: Guarding the North for you, Your Grace. Winterfell is yours.

Question: Where's the Imp?
Answer: Will you shut up?

Question: Will you shut up?
Answer: Who have we here? You must be Robb. My, you're a pretty one. Your name is?

Question: Who have we here? You must be Robb. My, you're a pretty one. Your name is?
Answer: Arya.

Question: Where is our brother? Go find the little beast.
Answer: Tell me about Jon Arryn.

Question: He never had to teach you much, but me … You remember me at 16? All I wanted to do was crack skulls and fuck girls. He showed me what was what.
Answer: Aye.

Question: Did you hear the king's in Winterfell?
Answer: I did hear something about that.

Question: And the other brother?
Answer: The queen has two brothers?

Question: The queen has two brothers?
Answer: There's the pretty one. And there's the clever one.

Question: Oh? I hear he's more than earned it. I hear he's a drunken little lecher into all manner of perversions.
Answer: Clever girl.

Question: Have you?
Answer: The gods gave me one blessing.

Question: Should I explain to you the meaning of a closed door in a whorehouse, brother?
Answer: You've much to teach me, no doubt. But our sister craves your attention.

Question: Did you have to bury her in a place like this? She should be on a hill somewhere with the sun and the clouds above her.
Answer: She was my sister. This is where she belongs.

Question: Daenerys! There's our bride to be! Look – a gift from Illyrio. Touch it. Come on. Feel the fabric. Mmmm. Isn't he a gracious host?
Answer: We've been his guests for over a year and he's never asked us for anything.

Question: Illyrio is no fool. He knows I won't forget my friends when I come into my throne. You still slouch. Let me see. You have a woman's body now. I need you to be perfect today. Can you do that for me? You don't want to wake the dragon, do you?
Answer: No.

Question: Where is he?
Answer: The Dothraki are not known for their punctuality.

Question: May I present my honored guests? Viserys of House Targaryen, the third of his name. The rightful King of the Andals and the First Men. And his sister, Daenerys, of the House Targaryen.
Answer: Do you see how long his hair is? When Dothraki are defeated in combat, they cut off their braid so the whole world can see their shame. Khal Drogo has never been defeated. He's a savage, of course, but he's one of the finest killers alive. And you will be his queen.

Question: Do you see how long his hair is? When Dothraki are defeated in combat, they cut off their braid so the whole world can see their shame. Khal Drogo has never been defeated. He's a savage, of course, but he's one of the finest killers alive. And you will be his queen.
Answer: Come forward, my dear.

Question: Where's he going?
Answer: The ceremony is over.

Question: But he didn't say anything. Did he like her?
Answer: Trust me, Your Grace. If he didn't like her, we'd know.

Question: When will they be married?
Answer: Soon. The Dothraki never stay still for long.

Question: Is it true they lie with their horses?
Answer: I wouldn't ask Khal Drogo.

Question: Do you take me for a fool?
Answer: I take you for a king. Kings lack the caution of common men. My apologies if I've given offense.

Question: So do I. I want us both to go home. But they took it from us. So tell me, sweet sister, how do we go home?
Answer: I don't know.

Question: Do you think Joffrey will like me? What if he thinks I'm ugly?
Answer: Then he is the stupidest prince that ever lived.

Question: When would we be married? Soon or do we have to wait?
Answer: Hush now. Your father hasn't even said yes.

Question: Why would he say no? He'd be the second most powerful man in the kingdoms.
Answer: He'd have to leave home. He'd have to leave me. And so would you.

Question: Is he dead yet?
Answer: Uncle Benjen!

Question: You got bigger. I rode all day. Didn't want to leave you alone with the Lannisters. Why aren't you at the feast?
Answer: Lady Stark thought it might insult the royal family to seat a bastard in their midst.

Question: What're you doing back there?
Answer: Preparing for a night with your family. I've always wanted to see the Wall.

Question: You're Tyrion Lannister. The queen's brother?
Answer: My greatest accomplishment. You – you're Ned Stark's bastard, aren't you?

Question: My greatest accomplishment. You – you're Ned Stark's bastard, aren't you?
Answer: Did I offend you? Sorry. You are the bastard, though.

Question: Did I offend you? Sorry. You are the bastard, though.
Answer: Lord Eddard Stark is my father.

Question: What the hell do you know about being a bastard?
Answer: All dwarves are bastards in their fathers' eyes.

Question: The boy I beheaded. Did you know him?
Answer: Of course I did. Just a lad. But he was tough, Ned. A true Ranger.

Question: Robb boy. How are ye?
Answer: I'm good.

Question: Is this your first time in the North, Your Grace?
Answer: Yes. Lovely country.

Question: Hello, little dove. But you are a beauty. How old are you?
Answer: Thirteen, Your Grace.

Question: You're tall. Still growing?
Answer: I think so, Your Grace.

Question: And have you bled yet?
Answer: No, Your Grace.

Question: And your dress. Did you make it?
Answer: Such talent. You must make something for me.

Question: No? Getting a little old for it?
Answer: I don't fight in tournaments because when I fight a man for real, I don't want him to know what I can do.

Question: How did he get so fat?
Answer: He only stops eating when it's time for a drink.

Question: This was sent from the Eyrie. What's she doing at the Eyrie? She hasn't been back there since her wedding.
Answer: What news?

Question: What news?
Answer: She's fled the capital. She says Jon Arryn was murdered. By the Lannisters. She says the king is in danger.

Question: Lysa's head would be on a spike right now if the wrong people had found that letter. Do you think she would risk her life, her son's life, if she wasn't certain her husband was murdered?
Answer: If this news is true, and the Lannisters conspire against the throne, who but you can protect the king?

Question: If this news is true, and the Lannisters conspire against the throne, who but you can protect the king?
Answer: They murdered the last Hand. Now you want Ned to take the job.

Question: When do I meet with the Khal? We need to begin planning the invasion.
Answer: If Khal Drogo has promised you a crown, you shall have it.

Question: When?
Answer: When their omens favor war.

Question: Thank you, ser. Are you from my country?
Answer: Ser Jorah Mormont of Bear Island. I served your father for many years. Gods be good, I hope to always serve the rightful king.

Question: Do you know the Common Tongue?
Answer: Is ‘no' the only word that you know?

Question: Is ‘no' the only word that you know?
Answer: Rough night, Imp?

Question: Rough night, Imp?
Answer: If I get through this without squirting from one end or the other, it will be a miracle.

Question: Are you as good with a spear as you used to be?
Answer: No, but I'm still better than you.

Question: I know what I'm putting you through. Thank you for saying yes. I only ask you because I need you. You're a loyal friend. You hear me? A loyal friend. The last one I've got.
Answer: I hope I'll serve you well.

Question: Are you completely mad?
Answer: He saw us.

Question: I heard you the first time. Quite the little climber, aren't you? How old are you, boy?
Answer: Ten

Question: Isn't there anything else?
Answer: The Dothraki have two things in abundance

Question: Well, Mormont, as brutish as this life is, I suppose it is preferable to beheading. What did Ned Stark want you for? Buying from a slaver?
Answer: Selling to one... Some poachers I caught on my land.

Question: What good will my sympathies do them?
Answer: None. But it is expected of you. Your absence has already been noted.

Question: Go! Tell her. But first you will get to Lord and Lady Stark and you will fall on your knees in front of them and tell them how very sorry you are, that you are at their service, and that all your prayers are with them. Do you understand?
Answer: You can't...

Question: Do you understand?
Answer: The Prince will remember that, little lord.

Question: Is Bran going to die?
Answer: Apparently not.

Question: What do you mean?
Answer: The Maester says the boy may live.

Question: Where's your sense of wonder? The greatest structure ever built, the intrepid men of the Night's Watch, the wintry abode of the White Walkers.
Answer: Tell me you're not thinking of taking the black.

Question: And go celibate? The whores would go begging from Dorne to Casterly Rock. I just want to stand on top of the Wall and piss off the edge of the world.
Answer: The children don't need to hear your filth. Come.

Question: This is your home. I'm your guest. Handsome one, isn't he? I lost my first boy, a little black-haired beauty. He was a fighter too... Tried to beat the fever that took him. Forgive me. It's the last thing you need to hear right now.
Answer: I never knew.

Question: A sword for the wall?
Answer: I already have one.

Question: Good man. Have you swung it yet?
Answer: Of course I have.

Question: Is it "we" already? Have you taken your vows then?
Answer: Soon enough.

Question: Thank you, Nymeria. Septa Mordane says I have to do it again. "My things weren't properly folded", she says. Who cares how they're folded?! They're going to get all messed up anyway.
Answer: It's good you've got help.

Question: A present?
Answer: Close the door. This is no toy. Be careful you don't cut yourself.

Question: You'll have to work at it every day. How does it feel? Do you like the balance?
Answer: I think so.

Question: You've said goodbye to Bran? He's not going to die. I know it.
Answer: You Starks are hard to kill.

Question: My mother?
Answer: She was very kind.

Question: Is my mother alive? Does she know about me? Where I am, where I'm going? Does she care?
Answer: The next time we see each other, we'll talk about your mother. I promise.

Question: There was that one... Oh, what was her name? That common girl of yours? Becca? With the great big tits you could bury your face in.
Answer: Bessie. She was one of yours.

Question: Bessie! Thank the gods for Bessie and her tits. Yours was... Aleena? No. You told me once. Meryl? Your bastardo s mother?
Answer: Wylla.

Question: Daenerys Targaryen has wed some Dothraki horselord. What of it? Should we send her a wedding gift?
Answer: A knife perhaps, a good sharp one, and a bold man to wield it.

Question: Oh, it's unspeakable to you? What her father did to your family... That was unspeakable. What Rhaegar Targaryen did to your sister... the woman I loved. I'll kill every Targaryen I get my hands on.
Answer: But you can't get your hands on this one, can you?

Question: But you can't get your hands on this one, can you?
Answer: This Khal Drogo, it's said he has 100,000 men in his horde.

Question: Rapers. They were given a choice no doubt... Castration or the Wall. Most choose the knife. Not impressed by your new brothers? Lovely thing about the Watch... You discard your old family and get a whole new one.
Answer: Why do you read so much?

Question: Why do you read so much?
Answer: Look at me and tell me what you see.

Question: Is this a trick?
Answer: What you see is a dwarf. If I'd been born a peasant they might've left me out in the woods to die. Alas, I was born a Lannister of Casterly Rock. Things are expected of me. My father was the Hand of the King for 20 years.

Question: Yes, until my brother killed him. Life is full of these little ironies. My sister married the new King and my repulsive nephew will be King after him. I must do my part for the honor of my house, wouldn't you agree? But how? Well, my brother has his sword and I have my mind. And a mind needs books like a sword needs a whetstone. That's why I read so much. And you? What's your story, bastard?
Answer: Ask me nicely and maybe I'll tell you, dwarf.

Question: When was the last time you left this room?
Answer: I have to take care of him.

Question: What if he's wrong? Bran needs me.
Answer: Rickon needs you. He's six. He doesn't know what's happening. He follows me around all day, clutching my leg, crying...

Question: Have you ever seen a dragon?
Answer: Dragon gone, Khaleesi.

Question: Everywhere? Even in the east?
Answer: No dragon. Brave men kill them. It is known.

Question: The moon?
Answer: He told me the moon was an egg, Khaleesi, that once there were two moons in the sky. But one wandered too close to the sun and it cracked from the heat. Out of it poured a thousand thousand dragons and they drank the sun's fire.

Question: Leave me with her. Why did the trader from Garth tell you these stories?
Answer: Men like to talk when they're happy. Before your brother bought me for you, it was my job to make men happy.

Question: How old were you?
Answer: I was nine when my mother sold me to the pleasure house.

Question: Nine?!
Answer: I did not touch a man for three years, Khaleesi. First you must learn.

Question: Can you teach me how to make the Khal happy?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Will it take three years?
Answer: No.

Question: Someone tried to kill him twice. Why? Why murder an innocent child? Unless he saw something he wasn't meant to see.
Answer: Saw what, my lady?

Question: Saw what, my lady?
Answer: I don't know. But I would stake my life the Lannisters are involved. We already have reason to suspect their loyalty to the crown.

Question: Did you notice the dagger the killer used? It's too fine a weapon for such a man. The blade is Valyrian steel, the handle dragonbone. Someone gave it to him.
Answer: They come into our home and try to murder my brother? If it's war they want...

Question: They come into our home and try to murder my brother? If it's war they want...
Answer: If it comes to that, you know I'll stand behind you.

Question: What, is there going to be a battle in the Godswood? Too easily words of war become acts of war. We don't know the truth yet. Lord Stark must be told of this.
Answer: I don't trust a raven to carry these words.

Question: What about Bran?
Answer: I have prayed to the Seven for more than a month. Bran's life is in their hands now.

Question: Finish a man?
Answer: Kings traveled across the world for a night with Irogenia. Magisters sold their palaces. Khals burned her enemies just to have her for a few hours. They say a thousand men proposed to her and she refused them all.

Question: You will make him like it, Khaleesi. Men want what they've never had. And the Dothraki take slaves like a hound takes a bitch. Are you a slave, Khaleesi? Then don't make love like a slave. Very good, Khaleesi. Out there he is the mighty Khal, but in this tent, he belongs to you.
Answer: I don't think that this is the Dothraki way.

Question: If he wanted the Dothraki way, why did he marry you?
Answer: No. No. Tonight I would look upon your face.

Question: Do I frighten you so much, girl? Or is it him there making you shake? He frightens me too. Look at that face.
Answer: I'm sorry if I offended you, Ser. Why won't he speak to me?

Question: I'm sorry if I offended you, Ser. Why won't he speak to me?
Answer: He hasn't been very talkative these last 20 years. Since the mad King had his tongue ripped out with hot pincers.

Question: He speaks damn well with his sword though. Ser Ilyn Payne, the King's justice. The royal executioner. What is it, sweet lady? Does the hound frighten you? Away with you, dog. You're scaring my lady. I don't like to see you upset. The sun is finally shining. Come walk with me.
Answer: Stay, Lady. I probably shouldn't have any more. Father only lets us have one cup at feasts.

Question: What are you doing here? Go away.
Answer: Your sister? And who are you, boy?

Question: Your sister? And who are you, boy?
Answer: Mycah, my Lord.

Question: A butcher's boy who wants to be a Knight, eh? Pick up your sword, butcher's boy. Let's see how good you are.
Answer: She asked me to, my Lord. She asked me to.

Question: And you're not a Knight. Only a butcher's boy. That was my lady's sister you were hitting, do you know that?
Answer: Stop it!

Question: Where is she?
Answer: She's been taken directly before the King.

Question: Who took her?
Answer: The Lannisters found her.

Question: Are you hurt?
Answer: No.

Question: It's all right. What is the meaning of this? Why was my daughter not brought to me at once?
Answer: How dare you speak to your King in that manner?

Question: How dare you speak to your King in that manner?
Answer: Quiet, woman. Sorry, Ned. I never meant to frighten the girl. But we need to get this business done quickly.

Question: Enough! He tells me one thing, she tells me another. Seven hells! What am I to make of this? Where's your other daughter, Ned?
Answer: In bed asleep.

Question: What would you have me do, whip her through the streets? Damn it, children fight. It's over.
Answer: Joffrey will bear these scars for the rest of his life.

Question: You let that little girl disarm you? See to it that your daughter is disciplined. I'll do the same with my son.
Answer: Gladly, your Grace.

Question: And what of the direwolf? What of the beast that savaged your son?
Answer: I'd forgot the damned wolf.

Question: He doesn't mean Lady, does he? No no, not Lady! Lady didn't bite anyone! She's good!
Answer: Lady wasn't there! You leave her alone!

Question: s this your command... your Grace?
Answer: Where is the beast?

Question: Where is the beast?
Answer: Chained up outside, your Grace.

Question: Is this some trick?
Answer: The wolf is of the north. She deserves better than a butcher.

Question: The butcher's boy... You rode him down?
Answer: He ran... Not very fast.

Question: Sturdy old thing. How many kings' asses have polished it, I wonder? What's the line? The King shits and the Hand wipes.
Answer: Very handsome armor. Not a scratch on it.

Question: 500 men just stood there and watched. All the great knights of the Seven Kingdoms. You think anyone said a word, lifted a finger? No, Lord Stark. 500 men and this room was silent as a crypt. Except for the screams, of course, and the Mad King laughing. And later... When I watched the Mad King die, I remembered him laughing as your father burned... It felt like justice.
Answer: Is that what you tell yourself at night? You're a servant of justice? That you were avenging my father when you shoved your sword in Aerys Targaryen's back?

Question: Is that what you tell yourself at night? You're a servant of justice? That you were avenging my father when you shoved your sword in Aerys Targaryen's back?
Answer: Tell me... If I'd stabbed the Mad King in the belly instead of the back, would you admire me more?

Question: Tell me... If I'd stabbed the Mad King in the belly instead of the back, would you admire me more?
Answer: You served him well, when serving was safe.

Question: How many years has it been? You were a young man.
Answer: And you served another King.

Question: How forgetful of me. This belongs to you, now. Should we begin?
Answer: Without the King?

Question: Without the King?
Answer: Winter may be coming, but I'm afraid the same cannot be said for my brother.

Question: Mmm, how much?
Answer: 40,000 gold dragons to the champion, 20,000 to the runner-up, 20,000 to the winning archer.

Question: Can the treasury bear such expense?
Answer: I'll have to borrow it. The Lannisters will accommodate, I expect. We already owe Lord Tywin 3 million gold. What's another 80,000?

Question: I'll have to borrow it. The Lannisters will accommodate, I expect. We already owe Lord Tywin 3 million gold. What's another 80,000?
Answer: Are you telling me the Crown is three million in debt?

Question: Are you telling me the Crown is three million in debt?
Answer: I'm telling you the Crown is six million in debt.

Question: How could you let this happen?
Answer: The Master of Coin finds the money. The King and the Hand spend it.

Question: Do I have to marry her?
Answer: Yes. She's very beautiful and young. If you don't like her, you only need to see her on formal occasions and when the time comes, to make little princes and princesses. And if you'd rather fuck painted whores, you'll fuck painted whores. And if you'd rather lie with noble virgins, so be it. You are my darling boy and the world will be exactly as you want it to be. Do something nice for the Stark girl.

Question: How would you handle them?
Answer: I'd double their taxes and command them to supply 10,000 men to the royal army.

Question: A royal army?
Answer: Why should every lord command his own men? It's primitive, no better than the hill tribes. We should have a standing army of men loyal to the Crown, trained by experienced soldiers... Instead of a mob of peasants who've never held pikes in their lives.

Question: Why should every lord command his own men? It's primitive, no better than the hill tribes. We should have a standing army of men loyal to the Crown, trained by experienced soldiers... Instead of a mob of peasants who've never held pikes in their lives.
Answer: And if the northerners rebel?

Question: And if the northerners rebel?
Answer: I'd crush them. Seize Winterfell and install someone loyal to the realm as Warden of the North. Uncle Kevan, maybe.

Question: And these 10,000 northern troops, would they fight for you or their lord?
Answer: For me. I'm their King.

Question: So you agree... The Starks are enemies?
Answer: Everyone who isn't us is an enemy.

Question: Practicing for what?
Answer: The Prince.

Question: What's happening here?
Answer: Arya would rather act like a beast than a lady.

Question: The same dollmaker makes all of Princess Myrcella's toys. Don't you like it?
Answer: I haven't played with dolls since I was eight. May I be excused?

Question: I haven't played with dolls since I was eight. May I be excused?
Answer: You've barely eaten a thing.

Question: Arya, open the door. May I come in? Whose sword is that?
Answer: Mine.

Question: Give it to me. I know this maker's mark. This is Mikken's work. Where did you get this? This is no toy. Little ladies shouldn't play with swords.
Answer: I wasn't playing. And I don't want to be a lady.

Question: Come here. Now what do you want with this?
Answer: It's called Needle.

Question: A blade with a name. And who were you hoping to skewer with Needle? Your sister? Do you know the first thing about sword fighting?
Answer: Stick 'em with the pointy end.

Question: But how you can let her marry someone like that?
Answer: Well… Look at me. You're a Stark of Winterfell. You know our words.

Question: I don't want to frighten you, but I won't lie to you either. We've come to a dangerous place. We cannot fight a war amongst ourselves. All right? Go on. It's yours.
Answer: I can keep it?

Question: I can keep it?
Answer: Try not to stab your sister with it. If you're going to own a sword, you'd better know how to use it.

Question: Oh, my sweet summer child. What do you know about fear? Fear is for the winter, when the snows fall a hundred feet deep. Fear is for the long night, when the sun hides for years and children are born and live and die all in darkness. That is the time for fear, my little Lord, when the White Walkers move through the woods. Thousands of years ago there came a night that lasted a generation. Kings froze to death in their castles, same as the shepherds in their huts. And women smothered their babies rather than see them starve, and wept and felt the tears freeze on their cheeks. So is this the sort of story that you like? In that darkness, the White Walkers came for the first time. They swept through cities and kingdoms, riding their dead horses, hunting with their packs of pale spiders big as hounds…
Answer: What are you telling him now?

Question: What are you telling him now?
Answer: Only what the little Lord wants to hear.

Question: How do you feel? You still don't remember anything? I've seen you climb a thousand times. In the wind, in the rain... A thousand times. You never fall.
Answer: I did though. It's true, isn't it... what Maester Luwin says about my legs? I'd rather be dead.

Question: I did though. It's true, isn't it... what Maester Luwin says about my legs? I'd rather be dead.
Answer: Don't ever say that.

Question: Welcome to King's Landing, Lady Stark. Would you mind following us?
Answer: I would. We've done nothing wrong.

Question: Instructed? I don't know who's providing your instructions, but...
Answer: Follow me, Lady Stark.

Question: How dare you bring me here! Have you lost your mind?
Answer: No one will come looking for you here. Isn't that what like you wanted? I'm truly sorry... about the locale.

Question: No one will come looking for you here. Isn't that what like you wanted? I'm truly sorry... about the locale.
Answer: How did you know I was coming to King's Landing?

Question: How did you know I was coming to King's Landing?
Answer: A dear friend told me.

Question: How did you know I was coming?
Answer: Knowledge is my trade, my Lady. Did you bring the dagger with you, by any chance? My little birds are everywhere. Even in the north. They whisper to me the strangest stories. Valyrian steel.

Question: Knowledge is my trade, my Lady. Did you bring the dagger with you, by any chance? My little birds are everywhere. Even in the north. They whisper to me the strangest stories. Valyrian steel.
Answer: Do you know whose dagger this is?

Question: Do you know whose dagger this is?
Answer: I must admit I do not.

Question: Yours?
Answer: At least it was, until the tournament on Prince Joffrey's last nameday. I bet on Ser Jaime in the jousting, as any sane man would. When the Knight of the Flowers unseated him, I lost this dagger.

Question: To whom?
Answer: Tyrion Lannister. The Imp.

Question: If that were a real sword, you'd be dead. Lord Snow here grew up in a castle spitting down on the likes of you. Pyp. Do you think Ned Stark's bastard bleeds like the rest of us?
Answer: Next!

Question: And how's that going, Commander Mormont?
Answer: Slowly. A raven came for Ned Stark's son.

Question: Good news or bad?
Answer: Both.

Question: Good news? Perhaps you'd like to share it with your wife?
Answer: My wife is in Winterfell.

Question: Is she?
Answer: I thought that she'd be safest in here. One of several such establishments I own.

Question: What're you looking at, halfman?
Answer: I'm looking at you. You've got an interesting face. Very distinctive faces. All of you.

Question: What do you care about our faces?
Answer: It's just I think they would look marvelous decorating spikes in King's Landing. Perhaps I'll write my sister, the Queen, about it.

Question: How could you be so stupid?
Answer: Calm down.

Question: He's a child... 10 years old. What were you thinking?
Answer: I was thinking of us. You're a bit late to start complaining about it now. What has the boy told them?

Question: I was thinking of us. You're a bit late to start complaining about it now. What has the boy told them?
Answer: Nothing. He's said nothing. He remembers nothing.

Question: Then what are you raving about?
Answer: What if it comes back to him? If he tells his father what he saw...

Question: What if it comes back to him? If he tells his father what he saw...
Answer: We'll say he was lying. We'll say he was dreaming. We'll say whatever we like. I think we can outfox a 10-year-old.

Question: And my husband?
Answer: I'll go to war with him if I have to. They can write a ballad about us

Question: And if you find the proof?
Answer: Then I bring it to Robert... And hope he's still the man I once knew. You watch yourself on the road, huh? That temper of yours is a dangerous thing.

Question: Then I bring it to Robert... And hope he's still the man I once knew. You watch yourself on the road, huh? That temper of yours is a dangerous thing.
Answer: My temper? Gods be good, you nearly killed poor Littlefinger yesterday.

Question: My temper? Gods be good, you nearly killed poor Littlefinger yesterday.
Answer: He still loves you.

Question: Does he?
Answer: Off with you.

Question: It's been a long time. But I still remember every face. You remember your first?
Answer: Of course, your Grace.

Question: Who was it?
Answer: A Tyroshi. Never learned the name.

Question: How'd you do it?
Answer: Lance through the heart.

Question: Quick one. Lucky for you. Mine was some Tarly boy at the Battle of Summerhall. My horse took an arrow so I was on foot, slogging through the mud. He came running at me, this dumb high-born lad, thinking he could end the rebellion with the single swing of his sword. I knocked him down with the hammer. Gods, I was strong then. Caved in his breastplate. Probably shattered every rib he had. Stood over him, hammer in the air. Right before I brought it down he shouted, "Wait! Wait!"... They never tell you how they all shit themselves. They don't put that part in the songs. Stupid boy. Now the Tarlys bend the knee like everyone else. He could have lingered on the edge of the battle with the smart boys and today his wife would be making him miserable, his sons would be ingrates, and he'd be waking three times in the night to piss into a bowl. Wine! Lancel. Gods, what a stupid name. Lancel Lannister. Who named you? Some halfwit with a stutter? What are you doing?
Answer: It's empty, your Grace.

Question: What do you mean it's empty?
Answer: There's no more wine.

Question: Is that what empty means?! So get more. Tell your cousin to get in here. Kingslayer! Get in here. Surrounded by Lannisters. Every time I close my eyes I see their blond hair and their smug, satisfied faces. It must wound your pride, huh? Standing out there like a glorified sentry. Jaime Lannister, son of the mighty Tywin... Forced to mind the door while your King eats and drinks and shits and fucks. So come on. We're telling war stories. Who was your first kill, not counting old men?
Answer: One of the outlaws in the Brotherhood.

Question: Your outlaw... Any last words?
Answer: I cut his head off, so no.

Question: What about Aerys Targaryen? What did the Mad King say when you stabbed him in the back? I never asked. Did he call you a traitor? Did he plead for a reprieve?
Answer: He said the same thing he'd been saying for hours... "Burn them all." If that's all, your Grace...

Question: From whom?
Answer: If you rule a city and you see the horde approaching, you have two choices

Question: You want the entire horde to stop? For how long?
Answer: Until I command them otherwise.

Question: You dare! You give commands to me? To me? You do not command the dragon. I am Lord of the Seven Kingdoms. I don't take orders from savages or their sluts. Do you hear me?
Answer: Rakharo ask if you want him dead, Khaleesi.

Question: Shall we return to the Khalasar, Khaleesi?
Answer: You walk. [to Viserys]

Question: You're leaving?
Answer: I'm the First Ranger. My job is out there. There have been disturbing reports.

Question: What kind of reports?
Answer: The kind I don't want to believe.

Question: You're joking?
Answer: And his brains and his guts, his lungs and his heart all fried in his own fat. When you're a hundred miles north of the Wall and you ate your last meal a week ago, you leave nothing for the wolves.

Question: And how do a bear's balls taste?
Answer: A bit chewy. And what about you, my Lord? What's the strangest thing you've eaten?

Question: A bit chewy. And what about you, my Lord? What's the strangest thing you've eaten?
Answer: Do Dornish girls count? So you roam the Seven Kingdoms, collaring pickpockets and horse thieves and bringing them here as eager recruits?

Question: Do Dornish girls count? So you roam the Seven Kingdoms, collaring pickpockets and horse thieves and bringing them here as eager recruits?
Answer: But it's not all of 'em's done bad things. Some of 'em's just poor lads looking for steady feed. Some of 'em's high-born lads looking for glory.

Question: The Night's Watch is a joke to you, is it? Is that what we are, Lannister? An army of jesters in black?
Answer: You don't have enough men to be an army and aside from Yoren here, none of you are particularly funny.

Question: Do you think I'm plump? Listen, Benjen... May I call you Benjen?
Answer: Call me what you like.

Question: Are you going below? Keep well, keep warm.
Answer: Enjoy the capital, brother.

Question: I think he's starting to like me. "Going below"?
Answer: Into the tunnel and out the other side. He'll be north of the Wall for a month or two.

Question: What are you doing?
Answer: When was last time you bleed, Khaleesi? You change, Khaleesi. It's a blessing from the Great Stallion.

Question: When was last time you bleed, Khaleesi? You change, Khaleesi. It's a blessing from the Great Stallion.
Answer: For a man on horseback, the curved blade is a good thing, easier to handle. It's a good weapon for a Dothrakan. But a man in full plate... the arakh won't get through the steel. That's where the broadsword has the advantage. Designed for piercing plate.

Question: Armor. Armor make a man... Vroz?
Answer: Slow.

Question: He was bloodrider to Khal Bharbo. And your father, Jorah the Andal? He was a warrior also?
Answer: He still is. A man of great honor. And I betrayed him.

Question: Have you seen any ducks, woman? No rabbits, no ducks. Do you have eyes in your head? Do you?
Answer: Dog then. I have seen many dogs.

Question: How many winters have you seen, Lord Tyrion?
Answer: Eight... no, nine.

Question: All of them brief?
Answer: They say the winter of my birth was three years long, Maester Aemon.

Question: How do you know?
Answer: I know.

Question: Will you stop at Winterfell on your way South?
Answer: I expect I will. Gods know there aren't many feather beds between here and King's Landing.

Question: Who are you?
Answer: Your dancing master, Syrio Forel.

Question: What if I drop it?
Answer: The steel must be part of your arm. Can you drop part of your arm? No. Nine years Syrio Forel was first sword to the Sealord of Braavos. He knows these things. You must listen to me, boy.

Question: The steel must be part of your arm. Can you drop part of your arm? No. Nine years Syrio Forel was first sword to the Sealord of Braavos. He knows these things. You must listen to me, boy.
Answer: I'm a girl.

Question: Ahhh… Just so. Now we will begin the dance. Remember, child, this is not the dance of the Westeros we are learning... The knight's dance, hacking and hammering. This is the Bravo's dance... The water dance. It is swift and sudden. All men are made of water, do you know this? If you pierce them, the water leaks out and they die. Now you will try to strike me.
Answer: Up! Dead. Dead. Very dead. Come. Again, faster.

Question: Really? If I was cooped up all day with no one but this old bat for company, I'd go mad. Anyway, you don't have a choice. Robb's waiting.
Answer: I don't want to go.

Question: Any man of the Night's Watch, but not I, eh, boy?
Answer: I'm not your boy, Lannister. I'm Lord of Winterfell while my father is away.

Question: So it's true. Hello Bran. Do you remember anything about what happened?
Answer: He has no memory of that day.

Question: Why are you here?
Answer: Would your charming companion be so kind as to kneel? My neck is beginning to hurt.

Question: Would your charming companion be so kind as to kneel? My neck is beginning to hurt.
Answer: Kneel, Hodor.

Question: Do you like to ride, Bran?
Answer: Yes. Well, I mean I did like to.

Question: What of it? With the right horse and saddle, even a cripple can ride.
Answer: I'm not a cripple.

Question: Will I really be able to ride?
Answer: You will. On horseback you will be as tall as any of them.

Question: Is this some kind of trick? Why do you want to help him?
Answer: I have a tender spot in my heart for cripples, bastards and broken things.

Question: Couldn't resist some northern ass? If you like redheads, ask for Ros.
Answer: Come to see me off, Greyjoy? Kind of you. Your master doesn't seem to like Lannisters.

Question: Come to see me off, Greyjoy? Kind of you. Your master doesn't seem to like Lannisters.
Answer: He's not my master.

Question: No, of course not. What happened here? Where is lady Stark? Why didn't she receive me?
Answer: She wasn't feeling well.

Question: She's not in Winterfell, is she? Where did she go?
Answer: My lady's whereabouts...

Question: My lady? Your loyalty to your captors is touching. Tell me, how do you think Balon Greyjoy would feel if he could see his only surviving son has turned lackey? I still remember seeing my father's fleet burn in Lannisport. I believe your uncles were responsible?
Answer: Must have been a pretty sight.

Question: What in seven hells is that?
Answer: They'll need an eighth hell to fit him in.

Question: Are you sure you want to do this?
Answer: No. Yield yield yield! I yield.

Question: Did he hurt you?
Answer: I've had worse.

Question: It's not going to get any easier, you know? You'll have to defend yourself.
Answer: Why didn't you get up and fight?

Question: Why didn't you get up and fight?
Answer: I wanted to. I just couldn't.

Question: Why not?
Answer: I'm a coward. My father always says so.

Question: If my brother was given an army of Dothraki, could you conquer the Seven Kingdoms?
Answer: The Dothraki have never crossed the Narrow Sea. They fear any water their horses can't drink.

Question: But if they did?
Answer: King Robert is fool enough to meet them in open battle, but the men advising him are different.

Question: And you know these men?
Answer: I fought beside them once, long ago. Now Ned Stark wants my head. He drove me from my land.

Question: Why?
Answer: I had no money and an expensive wife.

Question: And where is she now?
Answer: In another place, with another man.

Question: Your Grace?
Answer: Yes, my dear?

Question: Yes, my dear?
Answer: They call you the last dragon...

Question: You have dragon's blood in your veins?
Answer: It's entirely possible.

Question: What happened to the dragons? I was told that brave men killed them all.
Answer: The brave men didn't kill dragons. The brave men rode them. Rode them from Valyria to build the greatest civilization this world has ever seen. The breath of the greatest dragon forged the Iron Throne, which the Usurper is keeping warm for me. The swords of the vanquished, a thousand of them... melted together like so many candles.

Question: Really? Why dragons?
Answer: They can fly. And wherever they are, just a few flaps of their wings and they're somewhere else... Far away. And they can kill. Anyone or anything that tries to hurt them gets burned away to nothing... melted... like so many candles. Seeing a dragon would make me very happy.

Question: What have you seen?
Answer: I've seen... A man from Asshai with a dagger of real dragonglass. I've seen a man who could change his face the way that other men change their clothes. And I've seen a pirate who wore his weight in gold and whose ship had sails of colored silk. So... Have you seen one?

Question: I've seen... A man from Asshai with a dagger of real dragonglass. I've seen a man who could change his face the way that other men change their clothes. And I've seen a pirate who wore his weight in gold and whose ship had sails of colored silk. So... Have you seen one?
Answer: A pirate ship?

Question: A pirate ship?
Answer: A dragon.

Question: What happened to the skulls?
Answer: I don't know. The Usurper had them smashed to powder, I expect. Scattered to the wind.

Question: Yes, it is. What did I buy you for? To make me sad?
Answer: No, your Grace. To teach your sister.

Question: To teach my sister how to be a better lover? You think I bought you to make Khal Drogo happy? You pretty little idiot. Go on then. Get on with it.
Answer: Someday your husband will sit there and you will sit by his side. And one day, before too long, you will present your son to the court. All the lords of Westeros will gather here to see the little prince...

Question: What if I have a girl?
Answer: Gods be good, you'll have boys and girls and plenty of them.

Question: What if I only have girls?
Answer: I wouldn't worry about that.

Question: But what if?
Answer: If you only had girls, I suppose the throne would pass to Prince Joffrey's little brother.

Question: Nonsense. Why would you say such a thing? That business with the wolves? I've told you a hundred times... A direwolf is not...
Answer: Please shut up about it.

Question: Do you remember your lessons? Who built the Iron Throne?
Answer: Aegon the Conqueror.

Question: And who built the Red Keep?
Answer: Maegor the Cruel.

Question: My grandfather and uncle were murdered here, weren't they?
Answer: They were killed on the orders of King Aerys, yes.

Question: Why were they killed?
Answer: You should speak to your father about these matters.

Question: I will?
Answer: You found money for a champion's purse, you can find money to keep the peace. I'll also give you 20 of my household guards till the crowds have left.

Question: I'm sure the tourney puts coins in many a pocket. Now... If there's nothing else, my Lords?
Answer: This heat. On days like this, I envy you northerners your summer snows. Until tomorrow my Lord.

Question: Lord Arryn? His death was a great sadness to all of us. I took personal charge of his care, but I could not save him. His sickness struck him very hard and very fast. I saw him in my chambers just the night before he passed. Lord Jon often came to me for counsel.
Answer: Why?

Question: Why?
Answer: I have been Grand Maester for many years. Kings and Hands have come to me for advice since...

Question: What did Jon want the night before he died?
Answer: He came inquiring after a book.

Question: A book? What book?
Answer: I fear it would be of little interest to you, my Lord. A ponderous tome.

Question: Did Jon Arryn tell you what he wanted with it?
Answer: He did not, my Lord. And I did not presume to ask.

Question: Did he say anything to you during his final hours?
Answer: Nothing of import, my Lord. There was one phrase he kept repeating

Question: The seed is strong"? What does that mean?
Answer: The dying mind is a demented mind, Lord Stark. For all the weight they're given, last words are usually as significant as first words.

Question: And you're quite certain he died of a natural illness?
Answer: What else could it be?

Question: What else could it be?
Answer: Poison.

Question: Yes. Women, cravens... and eunuchs. Did you know that lord Varys is a eunuch?
Answer: Everybody knows that.

Question: Cats? Syrio says…
Answer: He says every swordsman should study cats. They're quiet as shadows and as light as feathers. You have to be quick to catch them.

Question: Now that Bran's awake will he come live with us?
Answer: He needs to get his strength back first.

Question: He wants to be a knight of the King's Guard. He can't be one now, can he?
Answer: No. But someday he could be Lord of a holdfast or sit on the King's Council. Or he might raise castles like Brandon the Builder.

Question: Can I be Lord of a holdfast?
Answer: You will marry a high Lord and rule his castle. And your sons shall be knights and princes and lords.

Question: You can't fight. You can't see. You're afraid of heights and almost everything else probably. What are you doing here, Sam?
Answer: On the morning of my 18th nameday, my father came to me. "You're almost a man now," he said, "but you're not worthy of my land and title. Tomorrow, you're going to take the black, forsake all claim to your inheritance and start north. If you do not," he said, "then we'll have a hunt and somewhere in these woods your horse will stumble and you'll be thrown from your saddle to die. Or so I'll tell your mother. Nothing would please me more." Ser Alliser's going to make me fight again tomorrow, isn't he?

Question: On the morning of my 18th nameday, my father came to me. "You're almost a man now," he said, "but you're not worthy of my land and title. Tomorrow, you're going to take the black, forsake all claim to your inheritance and start north. If you do not," he said, "then we'll have a hunt and somewhere in these woods your horse will stumble and you'll be thrown from your saddle to die. Or so I'll tell your mother. Nothing would please me more." Ser Alliser's going to make me fight again tomorrow, isn't he?
Answer: Yes, he is.

Question: I'm not going to get any better, you know?
Answer: Well… You can't get any worse.

Question: He never stops. Do you know Ser Hugh of the Vale? Not surprising. Until recently, he was only a squire... Jon Arryn's squire. He was knighted almost immediately after his master's untimely death.
Answer: Knighted for what? Why are you telling me this?

Question: Knighted for what? Why are you telling me this?
Answer: I promised Cat that I'd help you.

Question: Where is Ser Hugh? I'll speak to him.
Answer: A singularly bad idea. Do you see that boy there? One of Varys's little birds. The Spider has taken a great interest in your comings and goings. Now look there. That one belongs to the Queen. And do you see that Septa pretending to read her book?

Question: A singularly bad idea. Do you see that boy there? One of Varys's little birds. The Spider has taken a great interest in your comings and goings. Now look there. That one belongs to the Queen. And do you see that Septa pretending to read her book?
Answer: Varys or the Queen?

Question: Varys or the Queen?
Answer: No. She's one of mine. Is there someone in your service whom you trust completely?

Question: No. She's one of mine. Is there someone in your service whom you trust completely?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Ser Hugh? Ser Hugh!
Answer: As you can see, I'm busy.

Question: What did Lord Arryn want?
Answer: He always came to see the boy.

Question: There's nothing to forgive. When Lord Arryn came to visit you, what would you talk about?
Answer: He just asked me questions is all, my Lord.

Question: What kind of questions?
Answer: About my work at first, if I was being treated well, if I liked it here. But then he started asking me about my mother.

Question: Your mother?
Answer: Who she was, what she looked like.

Question: What did you tell him?
Answer: She died when I was little. She had yellow hair. She'd sing to me sometimes.

Question: Find anything?
Answer: King Robert's bastard son.

Question: Listen. Do you hear them? How many do you think are in there with him? Guess.
Answer: Three? Four?

Question: Three? Four?
Answer: He likes to do this when I'm on duty... He makes me listen as he insults my sister.

Question: Why do I have to forgive you? Have you wronged me?
Answer: We've met before, you know.

Question: Have we? Strange, I've forgotten.
Answer: The siege of Pyke. We fought side by side one afternoon.

Question: That's where you got your scar?
Answer: Aye. One of the Greyjoys nearly took my eye.

Question: They stopped liking it at the end. That was a proper battle. D'you remember Thoros of Myr charging through the breach?
Answer: With his burning sword? I'll remember that till the day I die.

Question: With his burning sword? I'll remember that till the day I die.
Answer: I saw the youngest of the Greyjoy lads at Winterfell. It was like seeing a shark on a mountaintop.

Question: Theon? He's a good lad.
Answer: I doubt it.

Question: Can I leave this with you? The message from Lord Stark.
Answer: I don't serve Lord Stark.

Question: Where have you been?
Answer: Watch duty. With Sam.

Question: Prince Porkchop. Where is he?
Answer: He wasn't hungry.

Question: What are you waiting for? Attack him! You, get in there.
Answer: Hit me. Go on, hit me! I yield! Yield yield. I yield.

Question: You think this is funny, do you? When you're out there beyond the Wall with the sun going down, do you want a man at your back? Or a sniveling boy?
Answer: You send this whore to give me commands? I should have sent you back her head!

Question: You send this whore to give me commands? I should have sent you back her head!
Answer: Forgive me, Khaleesi. I did as you asked.

Question: Why did you hit her?!
Answer: How many times do I have to tell you? You do not command me.

Question: How many times do I have to tell you? You do not command me.
Answer: I wasn't commanding you. I just wanted to invite you to supper.

Question: What's this?
Answer: It's a gift. I had it made for you.

Question: Dothraki rags? Are you going to dress me now?
Answer: Please.

Question: You would turn me into one of them, wouldn't you? Next you'll want to braid my hair.
Answer: You've no right to a braid. You've won no victories yet.

Question: Don't you think it's a little bit unfair? Making us take our vows while they sneak off for a little sally on the side?
Answer: Sally on the side?

Question: Sally on the side?
Answer: It's silly, isn't it? What, we can't defend the Wall unless we're celibate? It's absurd.

Question: It's silly, isn't it? What, we can't defend the Wall unless we're celibate? It's absurd.
Answer: I didn't think you'd be so upset about it.

Question: Why not? Because I'm fat? But I like girls just as much as you do. They might not like me as much. I've never... been with one. You've probably had hundreds.
Answer: As a matter of fact, I'm the same as you.

Question: You didn't know where to put it?
Answer: I know where to put it.

Question: Was she... Old and ugly?
Answer: Young and gorgeous. A whore named Ros.

Question: What color hair?
Answer: Red.

Question: That good?
Answer: Better.

Question: What's my name?
Answer: Jon Snow?

Question: Jon Snow?
Answer: And why is my surname Snow?

Question: And why is my surname Snow?
Answer: Because... You're a bastard from the north.

Question: I never met my mother. My father wouldn't even tell me her name. I don't know if she's living or dead. I don't know if she's a noblewoman or a fisherman's wife... Or a whore. So I sat there in the brothel as Ros took off her clothes. But I couldn't do it. Because all I could think was what if I got her pregnant and she had a child, another bastard named Snow? It's not a good life for a child.
Answer: So... You didn't know where to put it?

Question: So... You didn't know where to put it?
Answer: Enjoying yourselves? You look cold, boys.

Question: Enjoying yourselves? You look cold, boys.
Answer: It is a bit nippy.

Question: A bit nippy, yeah, by the fire, indoors. It's still summer. Do you boys even remember the last winter? How long has it been now? What, 10 years? I remember. Was it uncomfortable at Winterfell? Were there days when you just couldn't get warm, never mind how many fires your servants built?
Answer: I build my own fires.

Question: That's admirable. I spent six months out there, beyond the Wall during the last winter. It was supposed to be a two-week mission. We heard a rumor Mance Rayder was planning to attack Eastwatch. So we went out to look for some of his men... Capture them, gather some knowledge. The Wildlings who fight for Mance Rayder are hard men. Harder than you'll ever be. They know their country better than we do. They knew there was a storm coming in. So they hid in their caves and waited for it to pass. And we got caught in the open. Wind so strong it yanked 100-foot trees straight from the ground, roots and all. If you took your gloves off to find your cock to have a piss, you lost a finger to the frost. And all in darkness. You don't know cold. Neither of you do. The horses died first. We didn't have enough to feed them, to keep them warm. Eating the horses was easy. But later when we started to fall... That wasn't easy. We should have had a couple of boys like you along, shouldn't we? Soft, fat boys like you. We'd have lasted a fortnight on you and still had bones leftover for soup. Soon we'll have new recruits and you lot will be passed along to the Lord Commander for assignment and they will call you men of the Night's Watch, but you'd be fools to believe it. You're boys still. And come the winter you will die... Like flies.
Answer: I hit him. I hit the dragon.

Question: What do you pray for, Ser Jorah?
Answer: Home.

Question: Lover's quarrel?
Answer: I'm sorry. Do I...?

Question: I'm sorry. Do I...?
Answer: Sansa dear, this is Lord Baelish. He's known...

Question: Why do they call you Littlefinger?
Answer: Arya!

Question: Gods, who is that?
Answer: Ser Gregor Clegane. They call him the Mountain. The Houndo s older brother.

Question: And his opponent?
Answer: Ser Hugh of the Vale. He was Jon Arryn's squire. Look how far he's come.

Question: Not what you were expecting? Has anyone ever told you the story of the Mountain and the Hound? Lovely little tale of brotherly love. The Hound was just a pup, six years old maybe. Gregor a few years older, already a big lad, already getting a bit of a reputation. Some lucky boys just born with a talent for violence. One evening... Gregor found his little brother playing with a toy by the fire... Gregor's toy, a wooden knight. Gregor never said a word, he just grabbed his brother by the scruff of his neck and shoved his face into the burning coals. Held him there while the boy screamed, while his face melted. There aren't very many people who know that story.
Answer: I won't tell anyone. I promise.

Question: I thought we might put what happened on the Kingsroad behind us – the ugliness with the wolves. And forcing you to kill the beast was extreme. Though sometimes we go to extremes where our children are concerned. How is Sansa?
Answer: She likes it here.

Question: What are you doing here?
Answer: I might ask the same of you. What is it you hope to accomplish?

Question: I might ask the same of you. What is it you hope to accomplish?
Answer: The King called on me to serve him and the realm, and that's what I'll do until he tells me otherwise.

Question: You're just a soldier, aren't you? You take your orders and you carry on. I suppose it makes sense. Your older brother was trained to lead and you were trained to follow.
Answer: I was also trained to kill my enemies, Your Grace.

Question: Good idea, grandfather. I'm starving. A song while we wait or?
Answer: I'd rather throw myself down a well.

Question: Is there nothing I can do... to remedy this?
Answer: You can have my room.

Question: There's a clever man. You can manage food, I trust? Yoren, dine with me.
Answer: Aye, my Lord.

Question: My Lord of Lannister! Might I entertain you while you eat? I can sing of your father's victory at King's Landing!
Answer: Nothing would more likely ruin my supper. Lady Stark! What an unexpected pleasure. I was sorry to have missed you at Winterfell.

Question: I was still Catelyn Tully the last time I stayed here. You, Ser... Is that the black bat of Harrenhal I see embroidered on your coat?
Answer: It is, my Lady.

Question: And is Lady Whent a true and honest friend to my father... Lord Hoster Tully of Riverrun?
Answer: She is.

Question: Does Ser Hugh have any family in the capital?
Answer: No. I stood vigil for him myself last night. He had no one else.

Question: Who determines the draw?
Answer: All the knights draw straws, Lord Stark.

Question: Aye... But who holds the straws? You've done good work, Sisters.
Answer: Life is strange. Not so many years ago we fought as enemies at the Trident.

Question: And that lad... He was a squire until a few months ago. How could he afford a new suit of armor?
Answer: Perhaps Lord Arryn left him some money? I hear the King wants to joust today.

Question: Perhaps Lord Arryn left him some money? I hear the King wants to joust today.
Answer: Yes. That will never happen.

Question: Your mother was a dumb whore with a fat arse. Did you know that? Look at this idiot! One ball and no brains. He can't even put a man's armor on him properly.
Answer: You're too fat for your armor.

Question: Fat? Fat, is it? Is that how you speak to your King? That was funny, is it?
Answer: Oh, it's funny, is it?

Question: Oh, it's funny, is it?
Answer: No, Your Grace.

Question: No? You don't like the Hando s joke?
Answer: You're torturing the poor boy.

Question: The breastplate stretcher?
Answer: How long before he figures it out?

Question: How long before he figures it out?
Answer: Maybe you should have one invented.

Question: Why? Because I'm king? Piss on that. I want to hit somebody!
Answer: And who's going to hit you back?

Question: And who's going to hit you back?
Answer: Anybody who can. And the last man in his saddle... will be you!

Question: Are you telling me those cowards would let me win?
Answer: Aye.

Question: Your squire... A Lannister boy?
Answer: Hmm... A bloody idiot... But Cersei insisted. I have Jon Arryn to thank for her. "Cersei Lannister will make a good match", he told me. "You'll need her father on your side." I thought being King meant I could do whatever I wanted. Enough of this! Let's go watch 'em ride. At least I can smell someone else's blood.

Question: Robert?
Answer: What? Oh! An inspiring sight for the people, eh? Come! Bow before your King! Bow, you shits!

Question: What? Oh! An inspiring sight for the people, eh? Come! Bow before your King! Bow, you shits!
Answer: Where's Arya

Question: Now what will I buy with 100 gold dragons? A dozen barrels of Dornish wine? Or a girl from the pleasure houses of Lys?
Answer: Or you could even buy a friend.

Question: And tell me, Lord Renly, when will you be having your friend?
Answer: Loras knew his mare was in heat. Quite crafty, really.

Question: Very wise. They'll be out in droves, looking for me in the wrong place. Wordo s probably gotten to my father by now. He'll be offering a handsome reward. Everyone knows a Lannister always pays his debts. Would you be so good as to untie me?
Answer: And why would I do that?

Question: And why would I do that?
Answer: Why not? Am I going to run? The hill tribes would kill me for my boots. Unless a Shadowcat ate me first.

Question: Why not? Am I going to run? The hill tribes would kill me for my boots. Unless a Shadowcat ate me first.
Answer: Shadowcats and hill tribes are the least of your concerns.

Question: Ah... the Eastern Road. We're going to The Vale. You're taking me to your sister's to answer for my imagined crimes. Tell me, Lady Stark. When was the last time you saw your sister?
Answer: Five years ago.

Question: What sort of imbecile arms an assassin with his own blade?
Answer: Should I gag him?

Question: Should I gag him?
Answer: Why? Am I starting to make sense?

Question: Why? Am I starting to make sense?
Answer: My Lady, this way.

Question: Untie me. If I die, what's the point?
Answer: Rodrik?

Question: Rodrik?
Answer: I'll be fine, my Lady. There's no need to bloody yourself.

Question: Your first? You need a woman. Nothing like a woman after a fight.
Answer: Well, I'm willing if she is.

Question: Lords?
Answer: The Greyjoys.

Question: Those are Tully words... Your mother's. Are we playing a game?
Answer: Family, duty, honor"... Is that the right order?

Question: Family, duty, honor"... Is that the right order?
Answer: You know it is.

Question: Family comes first?
Answer: Your mother had to leave Winterfell to protect the family.

Question: How can she protect the family, if she's not with her family?
Answer: Your mother sat by your bed for three weeks while you slept.

Question: Why did she leave?
Answer: I still can't tell you, but she will be home soon.

Question: Do you know where she is now? Today?
Answer: No, I don't.

Question: Then how can you promise me she'll be home soon?
Answer: Sometimes I worry you're too smart for your own good.

Question: And where is that written?
Answer: You need legs to work a bow.

Question: Really?
Answer: Dothraki boys learn when they're four years old. Why shouldn't you?

Question: Dothraki boys learn when they're four years old. Why shouldn't you?
Answer: Shh... Keep it down. You're not supposed to be inside the castle walls.

Question: Who? the Imp? I'd call him half a nobleman.
Answer: Jealous?

Question: Jealous?
Answer: Why should I be jealous?

Question: Why should I be jealous?
Answer: Anyone with a few coppers in his pocket can own you for the night. What's a dwarf like down below? I've always wondered.

Question: Anyone with a few coppers in his pocket can own you for the night. What's a dwarf like down below? I've always wondered.
Answer: Might surprise you.

Question: Hmm?
Answer: He's good with his fingers too. And his tongue.

Question: And what about the Starks?
Answer: I've been Lord Stark's ward since I was eight years old.

Question: My father fought for the freedom of his people! What did your father do? Fucked a cook and whelped a whore.
Answer: You're a very serious boy.

Question: How is your son, my Lord?
Answer: He'll never walk again.

Question: But his mind is sound?
Answer: So they say.

Question: A blessing then. I suffered an early mutilation myself. Some doors close forever... others open in the most unexpected places. May I?
Answer: If the wrong ears heard what I'm about to tell you, off comes my head. And who would mourn poor Varys then? North or South, they sing no songs for spiders. But there are things you must know. You are the King's Hand and the King is a fool... your friend, I know, but a fool... and doomed unless you save him.

Question: If the wrong ears heard what I'm about to tell you, off comes my head. And who would mourn poor Varys then? North or South, they sing no songs for spiders. But there are things you must know. You are the King's Hand and the King is a fool... your friend, I know, but a fool... and doomed unless you save him.
Answer: I've been in the capital a month. Why have you waited so long to tell me this?

Question: I've been in the capital a month. Why have you waited so long to tell me this?
Answer: I didn't trust you.

Question: So why do you trust me now?
Answer: The Queen is not the only one who has been watching you closely. There are few men of honor in the capital. You are one of them. I would like to believe I am another, strange as that may seem.

Question: What sort of doom does the King face?
Answer: The same sort as Jon Arryn. The tears of Lys, they call it. A rare and costly thing, as clear and tasteless as water. It leaves no trace.

Question: Who gave it to him?
Answer: Some dear friend, no doubt. But which one? There were many. Lord Arryn was a kind and trusting man. There was one boy... all he was he owed to Jon Arryn.

Question: Some dear friend, no doubt. But which one? There were many. Lord Arryn was a kind and trusting man. There was one boy... all he was he owed to Jon Arryn.
Answer: The squire, Ser Hugh?

Question: The squire, Ser Hugh?
Answer: Pity what happened to him, just when his life seemed to be going so nicely.

Question: If Ser Hugh poisoned him, who paid Ser Hugh?
Answer: Someone who could afford it.

Question: Jon was a man of peace. He was Hand for 17 years -- 17 good years. Why kill him?
Answer: He started asking questions.

Question: And when he knows the truth, what will he do?
Answer: The gods alone know. The fools tried to kill his son. What's worse, they botched it. The wolf and the lion will be at each other's throats. We will be at war soon, my friend.

Question: What good is war now? We're not ready. If one Hand can die, why not a second?
Answer: This Hand is not the other.

Question: Am I? All those birds that whisper in your ear, such pretty little things. Trust me, we accommodate all inclinations.
Answer: Oh, I'm sure. Lord Redwyne likes his boys very young, I hear.

Question: Though I suppose beauty is a subjective quality, no? Is it true that Ser Marlon of Tumblestone prefers amputees?
Answer: All desires are valid to a man with a full purse.

Question: Tell me. Does someone, somewhere, keep your balls in a little box? I've often wondered.
Answer: Do you know, I have no idea where they are? And we had been so close. But enough about me. How have you been since we last saw each other?

Question: Do you know, I have no idea where they are? And we had been so close. But enough about me. How have you been since we last saw each other?
Answer: Since you last saw me or since I last saw you?

Question: Since you last saw me or since I last saw you?
Answer: Now the last time I saw you, you were talking to the Hand of the King.

Question: Saw me with your own eyes?
Answer: Eyes I own.

Question: But you know something? I do believe that I have seen you even more recently than you have seen me.
Answer: Have you?

Question: Have you?
Answer: Yes. Earlier today, I distinctly recall seeing you talking to Lord Stark in his chambers.

Question: Was that you under the bed?
Answer: And not long after that when I saw you escorting a certain foreign dignitary... Council business? Of course you would have friends from across The Narrow Sea. You're from there yourself, after all. We're friends, aren't we, Lord Varys? I'd like to think we are. So you can imagine my burden, wondering if the King might question my friendo s sympathies… To stand at a crossroads where turning left means loyalty to a friend, turning right, loyalty to the realm.

Question: And not long after that when I saw you escorting a certain foreign dignitary... Council business? Of course you would have friends from across The Narrow Sea. You're from there yourself, after all. We're friends, aren't we, Lord Varys? I'd like to think we are. So you can imagine my burden, wondering if the King might question my friendo s sympathies… To stand at a crossroads where turning left means loyalty to a friend, turning right, loyalty to the realm.
Answer: Oh, please.

Question: What are you two conspiring about? Well, whatever it is, you'd best hurry up. My brother is coming.
Answer: To a small council meeting?

Question: To a small council meeting?
Answer: Disturbing news from far away. Haven't you heard?

Question: Disturbing news from far away. Haven't you heard?
Answer: Off with you. No begging.

Question: D'you want a smack on your ear to help you with your hearing?
Answer: I want to see my father.

Question: You want your father, boy? He's lying on the floor of some tavern, getting pissed on by his friends.
Answer: My father is Hand of the King! I'm not a boy. I'm Arya Stark of Winterfell and if you lay a hand on me, my father will have both your heads on spikes! Now are you going to let me by or do I need to smack you on the ear to help with your hearing?

Question: My father is Hand of the King! I'm not a boy. I'm Arya Stark of Winterfell and if you lay a hand on me, my father will have both your heads on spikes! Now are you going to let me by or do I need to smack you on the ear to help with your hearing?
Answer: You know I had half my guard out searching for you? You promised me this would stop.

Question: You know I had half my guard out searching for you? You promised me this would stop.
Answer: They said they were going to kill you.

Question: Who did?
Answer: I didn't see them, but I think one was fat.

Question: Where did you hear this?
Answer: In the dungeons, near the dragon skulls.

Question: What were you doing in the dungeons?
Answer: Chasing a cat.

Question: Your name, friend?
Answer: Yoren, if it please. This must be your son. He has the look.

Question: Did Benjen send you?
Answer: No one sent me, my Lord. I'm here to find men for The Wall, see if there's any scum in the dungeons that might be fit for service.

Question: Know what?
Answer: Best said in private, my Lord.

Question: How many guards does my father have?
Answer: Here in King's Landing? Fifty.

Question: Here in King's Landing? Fifty.
Answer: You wouldn't let anyone kill him, would you?

Question: You wouldn't let anyone kill him, would you?
Answer: No fear on that count, little Lady.

Question: Well?
Answer: It's about your wife, my Lord. She's taken the Imp.

Question: To whom do I speak?
Answer: Ser Vardis Egen, Knight of The Vale. Is Lady Arryn expecting your visit?

Question: Ser Vardis Egen, Knight of The Vale. Is Lady Arryn expecting your visit?
Answer: There was no time to send word.

Question: May I ask, my Lady, why he is with you?
Answer: That's why there was no time. He is my prisoner.

Question: Is it about my wife?
Answer: No, my Lord. I believe it concerns Daenerys Targaryen.

Question: I warned you this would happen. Back in the North, I warned you, but you didn't care to hear. Well, hear it now. I want 'em dead, mother and child both. And that fool, Viserys as well. Is that plain enough for you? I want them both dead.
Answer: You will dishonor yourself forever if you do this.

Question: Honor?! I've got Seven Kingdoms to rule! One King, Seven Kingdoms. Do you think honor keeps them in line? Do you think it's honor that's keeping the peace? It's fear! Fear and blood!
Answer: Then we're no better than the Mad King.

Question: You want to assassinate a girl... Because the Spider heard a rumor?
Answer: No rumor, my Lord. The princess is with child.

Question: Based on whose information?
Answer: Ser Jorah Mormont. He is serving as adviser to the Targaryens.

Question: Mormont? You bring us the whispers of a traitor half a world away and call it fact?
Answer: Jorah Mormont's a slaver, not a traitor. Small difference, I know, to an honorable man.

Question: He broke the law, betrayed his family, fled our land. We commit murder on the word of this man?
Answer: And if he's right? If she has a son? A Targaryen at the head of a Dothraki army… What then?

Question: And if he's right? If she has a son? A Targaryen at the head of a Dothraki army… What then?
Answer: The Narrow Sea still lies between us. I'll fear the Dothraki the day they teach their horses to run on water.

Question: Do nothing? That's your wise advice? Do nothing til our enemies are on our shores? You're my council? Counsel! Speak sense to this honorable fool.
Answer: I understand your misgivings, my Lord. Truly, I do. It is a terrible thing we must consider, a vile thing. Yet, we who presume to rule must sometimes do vile things for the good of the realm. Should the gods grant Daenerys a son, the realm will bleed.

Question: I bear this girl no ill will, but should the Dothraki invade, how many innocents will die? How many towns will burn? Is it not wiser, kinder even, that she should die now so that tens of thousands might live?
Answer: We should have had them both killed years ago.

Question: Out! Out, damn you! I'm done with you. Go! Run back to Winterfell! I'll have your head on a spike! I'll put it there myself, you fool! You think you're too good for this? Too proud and honorable? This is a war!
Answer: I'll go ahead with my daughters. Get them ready. Do it yourself. Don't ask anyone for help.

Question: What can I do for you?
Answer: When do you return to Winterfell?

Question: When do you return to Winterfell?
Answer: Why? What do you care?

Question: Why? What do you care?
Answer: If you're still here come nightfall, I'll take you to see the last person Jon Arryn spoke with before falling ill. If that sort of thing still interests you.

Question: Round up all the men we have and station them outside the girls' chambers. Who are your best two swords?
Answer: Heward and Wyl.

Question: You bring him here without permission? You pollute my home with his presence? Your aunt has done a bad thing, Robin, a very bad thing. You remember her, don't you? Isn't he beautiful? And strong too. Jon knew it. His last words were, "the seed is strong." He wanted everyone to know what a good, strong boy his son would grow up to be. Look at him, the Lord of all the Vale.
Answer: Lysa, you wrote me about the Lannisters, warning me t-

Question: Mommy? Is that the bad man?
Answer: It is.

Question: Oh? Did I kill him too? I've been a very busy man.
Answer: You will watch your tongue! These men are Knights of the Vale. Every one of the loved Jon Arryn. Every one of them would die for me.

Question: Are you sure this won't hurt?
Answer: Only if I slip.

Question: And you prefer me like this?
Answer: Mhmm.

Question: My brother thinks that anyone who hasn't been to war isn't a man. He treats me as if I'm a spoiled child. Oh, and you're not? Loras Tyrell, the Knight of the Flowers? How many wars have you fought in? Oh, and how much did your father spend on that armor of yours?
Answer: Hold still.

Question: Everywhere?
Answer: Everywhere. So how did it end up? The Targaryen girl will die?

Question: Everywhere. So how did it end up? The Targaryen girl will die?
Answer: It needs to be done, unpleasant as it is. Robert's rather tasteless about it. Every time he talks about killing her, I swear the table rises six inches.

Question: Hmm... How did that ever happen?
Answer: Because he loves his killing and he used to be good at it.

Question: Do you know who should be King?
Answer: Be serious.

Question: And where was Robert in the line of royal succession? Joffrey is a monster. Tommen is eight.
Answer: Stannis?

Question: Stannis?
Answer: Stannis has the personality of a lobster.

Question: What are you doing?!
Answer: Look at it.

Question: You're willing to do what needs to be done, but you don't gloat over it. You don't love killing. Where is it written that power is the sole province of the worst? That thrones are only made for the hated and the feared. You would be a wonderful King.
Answer: I'm sorry your marriage to Ned Stark didn't work out. You seemed so good together.

Question: No. He's not serious enough. I'll say this for Ned Stark - he's serious enough. Was it really worth it? Losing him this way?
Answer: I don't know. But I do know this, if the Targaryen girl convinces her horse-lord husband to invade and the Dothraki horde crosses The Narrow Sea... We won't be able to stop them.

Question: Is my father wrong?
Answer: Let's say Viserys Targaryen lands with forty thousand Dothraki screamers at his back. We hole up in our castles, a wise move. Only a fool would meet the Dothraki in an open field. They leave us in our castles. They go from town to town, looting and burning, killing every man who can't hide behind a stone wall, stealing all our crops and livestock, enslaving all our women and children. How long do the people of the Seven Kingdoms stand behind their absentee King, their cowardly King hiding behind high walls? When do the people decide that Viserys Targaryen is the rightful monarch after all.

Question: Let's say Viserys Targaryen lands with forty thousand Dothraki screamers at his back. We hole up in our castles, a wise move. Only a fool would meet the Dothraki in an open field. They leave us in our castles. They go from town to town, looting and burning, killing every man who can't hide behind a stone wall, stealing all our crops and livestock, enslaving all our women and children. How long do the people of the Seven Kingdoms stand behind their absentee King, their cowardly King hiding behind high walls? When do the people decide that Viserys Targaryen is the rightful monarch after all.
Answer: We still outnumber them.

Question: Which is the bigger number -- five or one?
Answer: Five.

Question: What do you want?
Answer: We haven't had a real fight in nine years. Back-stabbing doesn't prepare you for a fight. And that's all the realm is now, back-stabbing and scheming and arse-licking and money-grubbing. Sometimes I don't know what holds it together.

Question: Ah, so here we sit, seventeen years later, holding it all together. Don't you get tired?
Answer: Every day.

Question: How long can hate hold a thing together?
Answer: Well, seventeen years is quite a long time.

Question: Yes, it tis. What was she like?
Answer: You've never asked about her, not once. Why not?

Question: You've never asked about her, not once. Why not?
Answer: At first, just saying her name, even in private felt like I was breathing life back into her. I thought if I didn't talk about her, she'd just fade away for you. When I realized that wasn't going to happen, I refused to ask out of spite. I didn't want to give you the satisfaction of thinking I cared enough to ask. And eventually it became clear that my spite didn't mean anything to you, as far as I could tell, you actually enjoyed it.

Question: So why now?
Answer: What harm could Lyanna Stark's ghost do to either of us that we haven't done to each other a hundred times over?
