Question: What harm could Lyanna Stark's ghost do to either of us that we haven't done to each other a hundred times over?
Answer: You want to know the horrible truth? I can't even remember what she looked like. I only know she was the one thing I ever wanted... Someone took her away from me, and Seven Kingdoms couldn't fill the hole she left behind.

Question: You want to know the horrible truth? I can't even remember what she looked like. I only know she was the one thing I ever wanted... Someone took her away from me, and Seven Kingdoms couldn't fill the hole she left behind.
Answer: I felt something for you once, you know?

Question: I felt something for you once, you know?
Answer: I know.

Question: Even after we lost our first boy -- for quite a while, actually. Was it ever possible for us? Was there ever a time, ever a... moment?
Answer: No. Does that make you feel better or worse?

Question: No. Does that make you feel better or worse?
Answer: It doesn't make me feel anything.

Question: She looks like him, don't she, my Lord? She has his nose, his black hair.
Answer: Tell him when you see him, my Lord. If it please you... Tell him how beautiful she is.

Question: When Jon Arryn came to visit you, what did he want?
Answer: He wasn't that sort of man, my Lord. He just wanted to know if the child was happy, healthy.

Question: What do you know of King Robert's bastards?
Answer: Well, he has more than you, for a start.

Question: How many?
Answer: Does it matter? If you fuck enough women, some of them will give you presents.

Question: Does it matter? If you fuck enough women, some of them will give you presents.
Answer: And Jon Arryn tracked them all down. Why?

Question: And Jon Arryn tracked them all down. Why?
Answer: He was the King's Hand. Perhaps Robert wanted them looked after. He was overcome with fatherly love.

Question: What's the meaning of this, Lannister?
Answer: Get back inside where it's safe. I'm looking for my brother. You remember my brother, don't you, Lord Stark? Blond hair, sharp tongue, short man.

Question: Get back inside where it's safe. I'm looking for my brother. You remember my brother, don't you, Lord Stark? Blond hair, sharp tongue, short man.
Answer: I remember him well.

Question: It seems he had some trouble on the road. You wouldn't know what happened to him, would you?
Answer: He was taken at my command to answer for his crimes.

Question: Threaten? As in, "I'm going to open your Lord from balls to brains and see what Starks are made of”?
Answer: You kill me, your brother's a dead man.

Question: Do you know what your wife has done?
Answer: She did nothing I did not command.

Question: Who'd have thought she had it in her?
Answer: By what right dare you lay hands on my blood?

Question: By what right dare you lay hands on my blood?
Answer: I am the King's Hand -

Question: Oh, will both of you shut your mouths? Catelyn will release Tyrion and you'll make your peace with Jaime.
Answer: He butchered my men.

Question: See what she does to me? My loving wife. I should not have hit her. That was not… That was not kingly.
Answer: If we don't act… there will be a war.

Question: So tell your wife to return that little shit of an Imp to King's Landing. She's had her fun, now put an end to it. You hear me? Send a raven and put an end to it.
Answer: And what about Jaime Lannister? What about Jaime?

Question: And what about Jaime Lannister? What about Jaime?
Answer: I'm half a kingdom in debt to his bloody father. I don't know what happened between you and those yellow-haired shits. I don't want to know. This is what matters - I can't rule the kingdoms if the Starks and the Lannisters are at each other's throats, so enough!

Question: The hunt?
Answer: Killing things clears my head. You'll have to sit on the throne while I'm away. You'll hate it more than I do.

Question: Khaleesi?
Answer: Oh, Khaleesi!

Question: When are you gonna tell him?
Answer: Not now.

Question: You want me to march on Casterly Rock?!
Answer: You're not a boy anymore. They attacked your father. They've already started the war. It's your duty to represent your House when your father can't.

Question: Where's Bran?
Answer: I don't know. It's not my House.

Question: Robb?
Answer: All alone in the deep dark woods.

Question: I don't see him. Got him hidden under your cloak?
Answer: Oh, that's a pretty pin. Silver.

Question: What's wrong with you? You some kind of cripple?
Answer: I'm Brandon Stark of Winterfell and if you don't let me be, I'll have you all killed!

Question: Are you all right?
Answer: Yes, it doesn't hurt.

Question: Have you lost your mind? What if you'd missed?
Answer: He would have killed you and cut Bran's throat.

Question: To what, to save your brother's life? It was the only thing to do, so I did it.
Answer: What about her?

Question: What about her?
Answer: Give me my life, my lord, and I'm yours.

Question: How would you like to be rich?
Answer: Dwarf man still making noise.

Question: No?
Answer: They killed Jory. My father is hurt. I don't care about stupid wooden swords.

Question: More trouble for you. Just so… How can you be quick as a snake, or as quiet as a shadow, when you are somewhere else? You are fearing for your father, hmm? That is right. Do you pray to the gods?
Answer: The old and the new.

Question: She has to eat a whole heart? I hope that wasn't my horse.
Answer: She's doing well.

Question: I need a large army… I'm the last hope of a dynasty, Mormont. The greatest dynasty this world has ever seen, on my shoulders since I was five years old and no one has ever given me what they gave to her in that tent. Never. Not a piece of it… How can I carry what I need to carry without it? Hmm? Who can rule without wealth, or fear, or love? Oh, you stand there, all nobility and honor. You don't think I see you looking at my little sister, hmm? Don't think I know what you want? I don't care. You can have her. She can be queen of the savages and dine on the finest bloody horseparts, and you can dine on whichever parts of her you like. But let me go.
Answer: You can go, but you can't have the eggs.

Question: You swore an oath to me. Does loyalty mean nothing to you?
Answer: It means everything to me.

Question: And yet here you stand?
Answer: And here I stand.

Question: Where?
Answer: Where? I don't know where, but when they free me -

Question: Where? I don't know where, but when they free me -
Answer: You want free? Go be free.

Question: You want free? Go be free.
Answer: Have you ever heard the phrase “Rich as a Lannister”? Of course you have. You're a smart man. You know who the Lannisters are. I am a Lannister. Tyrion, son of Tywin! And of course, you have also heard the phrase, “a Lannister always pays his debts.” If you deliver a message from me to Lady Arryn, I will be in your debt. I will owe you gold. If you deliver the message and I live, which I very much intend to do.

Question: Have you ever heard the phrase “Rich as a Lannister”? Of course you have. You're a smart man. You know who the Lannisters are. I am a Lannister. Tyrion, son of Tywin! And of course, you have also heard the phrase, “a Lannister always pays his debts.” If you deliver a message from me to Lady Arryn, I will be in your debt. I will owe you gold. If you deliver the message and I live, which I very much intend to do.
Answer: What message?

Question: What message?
Answer: Tell her I wish to confess my crimes.

Question: You wish to confess your crimes?
Answer: Yes, my lady. I do, my lady.

Question: Where do I begin, my lords and ladies? I'm a vile man, I confess it. My crimes and sins are beyond counting. I have lied and cheated, gambled and whored. I'm not particularly good at violence, but I'm good at convincing others to do violence for me. You want specifics, I suppose. When I was seven, I saw a servant girl bathing in the river. I stole her robe. She was forced to return to the castle, naked and in tears. I close my eyes, I can still see her tits bouncing. When I was ten, I stuffed my uncle's boots with goatshit. When confronted with my crime, I blamed a squire. Poor boy was flogged and… I escaped justice. When I was twelve, I milked my eel into a pot of turtle stew. I flogged the one-eyed snake. Robert started a war to win her back. He killed Rhaegar, but she died anyway. That's where l saw Father.

Answer: l'll have peace on those terms. They can keep their Red Castle and their iron chair too. The King in the North!

Question: Kings? Oh, l can tell you all there is to know about kings. The thing you need to understand about kings is – For the past 67 years, l've known truly known more kings than any man alive. They're complicated men, but l know how to serve them. Yes, and keep on serving them. Aerys Targaryen. Of all the thousand thousand maladies the Gods visit on us, madness is the worst. He was a good man. Such a charmer. To watch him melt away before my eyes, consumed by dreams of fire and blood. Robert Baratheon was an entirely different animal – powerful man, great warrior, but alas - winning a kingdom and ruling a kingdom are rather different things. They say that if a man goes through life with his battle visor down, he can often be blind to the enemies at his side. Now l serve his son King Joffrey, may the Gods bless his reign.
Answer: He is a capable young man. Strong military mind. Stern. But sternness in defense of the realm is no vice. lt's far too soon to know what manner of king he will be, but l sense true greatness on the horizon for our new King. Mmm. True greatness.

Question: l'll not sit meekly by and wait for the snows. l mean to find out what's happening. Answer: Cities, living or dead. Caravans and people. Rivers or lakes or the great salt sea. Find how far the Red Waste extends before us, and what lies on the other side.

Question: No. Ghost, no. No. Ghost, away. Shoo. Shoo! . You all right? Did he frighten you?
Answer: You shouldn't touch me.

Question: What're you doing?
Answer: This is Gilly, she's one of Craster's daughters.

Question: Hello, Gilly. What're you doing?
Answer: Sam said you could help.

Question: What? .
Answer: I know it sounds a bit mad.

Question: If it's a boy what? . You want us to risk our lives for you, and you won't even tell us why.
Answer: Why did you do that?

Question: Why did you do that?
Answer: Do what, ask her a question?

Question: Do what, ask her a question?
Answer: You were cruel.

Question: Cruel! Sam are you in such a hurry to lose a hand?
Answer: I didn't touch her!

Question: No you just want to steal her. What do you think Craster cuts off for that?
Answer: I can't steal her, she's a person not a goat.

Question: We're heading deeper and deeper into wildling territory. We can't take a girl with us. Mormont wouldn't have it. And even if he would, what would we do with her? Who's gonna deliver her baby? You?
Answer: I could try. . What? I've read about it. A bit.

Question: I could try. . What? I've read about it. A bit.
Answer: I'm sorry Sam, we can't help her.

Question: Who did this?
Answer: Khal Pono perhaps, Khal Jhaqo They don't like the idea of a woman leading a Khalasaar.

Question: Is it as you remember my lord?
Answer: Looks smaller.

Question: Who will?
Answer: Anyone who matters, , this is a big day for them. They haven't had much to get excited about since I left. It's a hard place the Iron Islands always has been. It's cold and it's wet.

Question: Shhh. Did he hurt you?
Answer: No, my lord… It's Mhaegen.

Question: Who?
Answer: She works for you. She's the one, the girl whose, they killed her baby.

Question: You know, you remind me of another girl. A lovely thing I once acquired from an Elysium pleasure house. Beautiful, like yourself, and intelligent as yourself. But she wasn't happy. She cried, often. I asked her why but, we didn't have the kind of rapport that you and I have. Yes, it was quite sad. Girls from Elysium pleasure houses are expensive. Extremely expensive. And this one wasn't making me any money. I hate bad investments. Really, I do. They haunt me. I had no idea how to make her happy, no idea how to mitigate my losses. A very wealthy patron, he offered me a tremendous amount of money to let him transform this lovely, sad girl. To use her in ways that never occur to most men. And you know what occurs to most men. I would not say he succeeded in making her happy but my losses were definitely mitigated. . Take tonight off to mourn Mhaegen's child. I'll see you tomorrow. But you'll be happy? . That makes me happy.
Answer: More wine?

Question: More wine?
Answer: Damn it, boy!

Question: Is that your new squire? Could have found you a proper lad.
Answer: Myself, I prefer the improper ones.

Question: Hmm, that's a good red. Dornish?
Answer: You know your wines, my lord.

Question: No, but who else would want to murder King Robert's bastards? She's always been a jealous woman.
Answer: You know your sister better than I do.

Question: Are you drunk? I'll not have my honor questioned by an Imp.
Answer: I'm not questioning your honor, Lord Janos. I'm denying its existence.

Question: Dwarf? You should have stopped at imp. And yes, you will stand here and take it from me, unless you'd like to take it from my friend here.
Answer: I intend to serve as Hand of the King until my father returns from the war, and seeing as you betrayed the last Hand of the King, well, I just wouldn't feel safe with you lurking about.

Question: Boys?
Answer: I have friends at court! Powerful friends! The king himself made me a lord!

Question: If I told you to murder, an infant girl say, still at her mother's breast, would you do it without question?
Answer: Without question? No. I'd ask how much.

Question: Without question? No. I'd ask how much.
Answer: If they come back, I say we yield. Gendry's the one they want. I don't want to get caught in the middle of a battle.

Question: So?
Answer: So, if they got armor on, it's a battle.

Question: What's a dyer's apprentice know about battles anyway?
Answer: Gendry's an armorer's apprentice. Hot Pie, tell Gendry what makes it a battle.

Question: A knight?
Answer: How'd you know he was a knight?

Question: How'd you know he was a knight?
Answer: Well, cause he got armor on.

Question: How'd you know?
Answer: Cause I sold armor.

Question: What do the gold cloaks want with you?
Answer: No idea.

Question: No goodo s ever come? Who asked questions before?
Answer: How can someone so small be such a huge pain in my ass?

Question: How can someone so small be such a huge pain in my ass?
Answer: Who asked questions?

Question: Who asked questions?
Answer: The Hand of the King. Er, hands of the King. Lord Arryn came first, a few weeks before he died. And then Lord Stark came, a few weeks before he died.

Question: See? Asking me questions is bad luck. . You'll probably be dead soon.
Answer: What did they ask about?

Question: What did they ask about?
Answer: My mom.

Question: Who's your mom?
Answer: Just my mom. Worked in a tavern. Died when I was little.

Question: And who was your father?
Answer: He could be one of those gold-hatted bastards, for all I know. What about you, anyway? You thought they were after you, why? Did you kill someone, or is it just because you're a girl?

Question: He could be one of those gold-hatted bastards, for all I know. What about you, anyway? You thought they were after you, why? Did you kill someone, or is it just because you're a girl?
Answer: I'm not a girl!

Question: Yes you are. You think I'm as stupid as the rest of them?
Answer: Stupider. Night's Watch doesn't take girls, everyone knows that.

Question: What you carrying?
Answer: Pears and oranges. Wine from the Arbor. And the heir to Pyke of the Iron Islands. . The only living son of Balon Greyjoy. . Me.

Question: You been at sea long? Or were there just no women where you came from?
Answer: None like you.

Question: You don't know what you're like. You need someone to teach you. Know who I am?
Answer: You think I offer free rides to every man in jewelry. Lord Greyjoy.

Question: Nine years. Do you still know your way around a ship? Have these hands ever touched a rope?
Answer: Don't you worry about my hands. . The sea's in my blood.

Question: Is that an offer from my future king?
Answer: An order, from your future king. You can tell your grandchildren about this night.

Question: Nine years, is it? They took a frightened boy. What have they given back?
Answer: A man. Your blood and your heir.

Question: And how do you feel about that?
Answer: What's done is done. I've brought you a proposal from Robb Stark.

Question: Who gave you those clothes? . Was it Ned Stark's pleasure to make you his daughter?
Answer: If my clothes offend you, I will change them.

Question: It will. . That bauble around your neck. Did you pay the iron price for it or the gold? . I asked a question. Did you pull it from the neck of a corpse you made or did you buy it to match your fine clothes? Iron or gold?
Answer: Gold.

Question: He heeds your counsel?
Answer: I've lived with him, hunted with him, fought at his side, he thinks of me as a brother.

Question: No, not here, , not in my hearing, you will not name him brother. This son of the man who put your true brothers to the sword. Or have you forgotten your own blood?
Answer: I forget nothing. I remember my brothers. And I remember when my father was a king.

Question: Oh, you will?
Answer: I'm your son. Your only living heir. Who else?

Question: I'm your son. Your only living heir. Who else?
Answer: I told you to wait outside. . How did you get past the guards?

Question: I told you to wait outside. . How did you get past the guards?
Answer: Anything with a cock is easy to fool.

Question: Yara?
Answer: So good to see you, brother. This is a homecoming I'll tell my grandchildren about.

Question: And why not?
Answer: You're a woman!

Question: Who said anything about the Lannisters?
Answer: You'll have your gold when we take the treasury at King's Landing.

Question: All these kings fighting for the throne, and this Stannis has the smallest army. Why would I bet on the man with the worst chance?
Answer: Because you're a smart gambler. Stannis has proved himself in war. Twice. His baby brother has never set foot on a battlefield. Neither has the false king, Joffrey.

Question: You think I'm insulted? I am a pirate. I'm an excellent pirate. I don't sail for promises.
Answer: Of course you do. Every time you leave harbor, you're leaving on a promise. A promise that somewhere on the seas, somebody's got some gold and you can take it from them.

Question: The queen?
Answer: Cersei, I want her. I'll sail with your fleet, all 30 of my ships, and if we don't drown at the bottom of Blackwater Bay, I will fuck this blonde queen and I will fuck her well.

Question: You believe your king can win?
Answer: He is the one true king.

Question: When will the King have a sail?
Answer: As soon as his God wills it.

Question: You want me to have a god, fine. King Stannis is my god. He raised me up and blessed me with his trust. He gave you a future I could never have imagined. You know how to read, you'll be a knight someday. You think your fire god commanded all that? It was Stannis. Only Stannis.
Answer: Stannis is my king, but he's only a man.

Question: Listen to me, Queen Regent, you're losing the people. Do you hear me?
Answer: Ha, the people. You think I care?

Question: Ha, the people. You think I care?
Answer: You might find it difficult to rule over millions who want you dead. Half the city will starve when winter comes. The other half will plot to overthrow you. And your gold-plated thugs just gave them the rallying cry, “The Queen slaughters babies.” . You don't even have the decency to deny it.

Question: It wasn't you who gave the order, was it? Joffrey didn't even tell you. Or did he tell you? I imagine that would be even worse.
Answer: He did what needed to be done. . You want to be the Hand of the King? You want to rule? This is what ruling is! Lying on a bed of weeds, ripping them out by the root one by one before they strangle you in your sleep.

Question: He did what needed to be done. . You want to be the Hand of the King? You want to rule? This is what ruling is! Lying on a bed of weeds, ripping them out by the root one by one before they strangle you in your sleep.
Answer: I'm no king, but I think there's more to ruling that that.

Question: You're funny. . You've always been funny. But none of your jokes will ever match the first one, will they? You remember... back when you ripped my mother open on your way out of her and she bled to death.
Answer: She was my mother too.

Question: How did it fare with your pirate?
Answer: Salladhor Saan will join our fleet. 30 ships. His men know how to fight.

Question: It won't be a choice this time. Do you trust him?
Answer: Salladhor Saan is an old friend, I've known him 30 years. I've never trusted him.

Question: What did you say to him?
Answer: I told him death by fire is the purest death.

Question: Why?
Answer: Because it is true. You're troubled my king.

Question: Faith? In a real war, the side with the greater number wins nine times out of ten.
Answer: Then we must be the ten.

Question: A son?
Answer: Out, all of you.

Question: What did you do?
Answer: I followed him. He took the baby into the woods, the newborn.

Question: What business is that of yours?
Answer: No, you don't understand. He's killing them, all the boys...

Question: Offerings? He's murdering his own children. He's a monster.
Answer: Aye, many a time that monster has been the difference between life and death for our rangers, your uncle among them. We have other wars to fight, out there. Like it or not, we need men like Craster.

Question: Hodor. Rouse Bran, will you? It's time for his lessons.
Answer: Every night it's the same.

Question: So she was lying? They don't exist?
Answer: Well, they may have done. But they're gone from the world, along with much else. These are dreams, Bran, nothing more.

Question: What about all the dreams you had that didn't come true? Hmm? Right.
Answer: This link is made of Valyrian steel. Only one maester in a hundred wears it on his chain. It signifies that I have studied the higher mysteries. And all who study these mysteries try their hand at spells. I was no different. I was young. And what boy doesn't secretly wish for hidden powers to lift him out of his dull life into a special one? But in the end, for all my efforts, I got no more out of it than a thousand boys before me. Come on.

Question: This link is made of Valyrian steel. Only one maester in a hundred wears it on his chain. It signifies that I have studied the higher mysteries. And all who study these mysteries try their hand at spells. I was no different. I was young. And what boy doesn't secretly wish for hidden powers to lift him out of his dull life into a special one? But in the end, for all my efforts, I got no more out of it than a thousand boys before me. Come on.
Answer: All right. Maybe magic once was a mighty force in the world. But not anymore. The dragons are gone. The giants are dead. And the Children of the Forest forgotten.

Question: What?
Answer: I will be one of your seven, pledge my life to yours, and keep you safe from all harm.

Question: Lady Catelyn. I'm pleased to see you. May I present my wife, Margaery of House Tyrell?
Answer: You are very welcome here, Lady Stark. I'm so sorry for your loss.

Question: Has your son marched against Tywin Lannister yet?
Answer: I do not sit on my son's war councils. And if I did, I would not share his strategies with you.

Question: Gerard. How's your foot?
Answer: Better, Your Grace.

Question: And all of them young and bold like your Knight of Flowers? It's a game to you, isn't it? I pity them.
Answer: Why?

Question: Why?
Answer: Because it won't last. Because they are the knights of summer and winter is coming.

Question: At once, Your Grace. Shall I return after?
Answer: That won't be necessary. I would pray awhile. Alone.

Question: What are you doing here?
Answer: I live here. Are you angry with me, brother?

Question: I live here. Are you angry with me, brother?
Answer: You lying bitch.

Question: Recognize you? How could I? The last time I saw you- you looked like a fat little boy.
Answer: You were a fat little boy, too, but I recognized you.

Question: Why didn't you tell me?
Answer: I wanted to see who you were first. And I did.

Question: The wolf pup has gone south with the entirety of the Northern army at his back. While he's tangling with the lion in the Westerlands, the North is ripe for the taking. The Ironborn will reave and pillage, as it was in the old days, all along the northern coast. We'll spread our dominion across the green lands, securing the Neck and everything above. Every stronghold will yield to us, one by one. Winterfell may defy us for a year, but what of it? The rest shall be ours, forest, field, and hall.
Answer: Yara, my daughter, you'll take thirty longships to attack Deepwood Motte.

Question: And what's my role in all this?
Answer: You'll take a ship to raid the fishing villages on the Stoney Shore.

Question: A ship? You give her thirty and I get one?
Answer: The Sea Bitch. We thought she'd be perfect for you.

Question: I'm to fight fishermen?
Answer: Be careful of their nets.

Question: What do you know of it, woman? I'm a proven warrior.
Answer: Your brothers were warriors, both of them dead at the hands of those you seem so eager to protect.

Question: I'm not protecting anyone. I just wonder if it's not wiser to wait. Why risk going against the North if they would be our allies? Rise up against them and they could destroy us. But if we pledge fealty to them, they'll give us Casterly Rock.
Answer: What are our words? Our words?

Question: What are our words? Our words?
Answer: We do not sow.

Question: You act as if I volunteered to go. You gave me away, if you remember. The day you bent the knee to Robert Baratheon. After he crushed you. Did you take what was yours then?
Answer: You gave me away!

Question: You'd have our father bow down to your other family?
Answer: I have no other family.

Question: Don't you? Make your choice, Theon, and do it quickly. Our ships sail with or without you.
Answer: You won't let me leave this room. You won't let me-

Question: Why? You think your father can hear me? He's three hundred miles away!
Answer: I don't intend for you to stay here. I might be able to bring you into the castle kitchens.

Question: Scullion? What is a scullion?
Answer: Kitchen wench.

Question: A kitchen wench?
Answer: Yes, but-

Question: Cleaning pots? Is that how my lion wants to see me?
Answer: Your lion wants to see you alive. We've come to a dangerous place. My sister wants to hurt me. She'll look for any weakness she can find. She can't know about you.

Question: I'm the weakness?
Answer: It's a compliment, my lady.

Question: How is being a weakness a compliment?
Answer: Language can be a bit tricky here.

Question: When will Joffrey and Sansa be married?
Answer: Soon, darling, when the war is over.

Question: Is Joffrey going to kill Sansa's brother?
Answer: He might.

Question: Would you like that?
Answer: No. I don't think so.

Question: Even if he does, Sansa will do her duty. Won't you, little dove?
Answer: Come in.

Question: Who are you?
Answer: I'm Shae, my lady. Your new handmaiden.

Question: What are you doing?
Answer: Waiting for you to tell me what to do.

Question: What things?
Answer: Change my linens, wash my clothing, scrub the floor, empty my chamber pot, brush my hair.

Question: Have you ever been a handmaiden before?
Answer: Yes.

Question: For whom?
Answer: Lady Zuriff.

Question: Do you want me to leave?
Answer: Just brush my hair.

Question: I can trust you, Pycelle, can I not?
Answer: Why, yes, of course, my lord.

Question: Matrimony, huh? Yes.
Answer: I'm trusting the council with these plans, but the Queen mustn't know. We can't have her meddling in affairs that could determine the future of the realm. There's too much at stake.

Question: Myrcella sent away to Dorne?
Answer: But remember, the Queen mustn't know.

Question: Theon Greyjoy? Forgive me, my lord, but how? He grew up a ward of Winterfell. He fights for Robb Stark.
Answer: Precisely.

Question: Tell no one what?
Answer: I plan to wed Princess Myrcella to Robin Arryn of the Vale. Lysa is not fond of me. But perhaps the promise of a royal match will convince her to let bygones be bygones.

Question: She imprisoned you. She tried to execute you. And you offer her son a princess?
Answer: For men in our position, holding grudges can be an encumbrance, don't you think?

Question: For men in our position, holding grudges can be an encumbrance, don't you think?
Answer: And I suppose you want me to broker this agreement?

Question: And I suppose you want me to broker this agreement?
Answer: Who better?

Question: Who better?
Answer: Yes, I could sing this song to Lysa, if I cared to. What's in it for me?

Question: Yes, I could sing this song to Lysa, if I cared to. What's in it for me?
Answer: The gratitude of the people of Westeros for helping to end this war, the adoration of the King for bringing the Vale back into the fold... and Harrenhal.

Question: I need you to deliver Lysa Arryn. I didn't need Janos Slynt. It's settled, then?
Answer: Good. Oh. And remember-

Question: What? What is it?
Answer: A member of the Kingsguard? As if I wasn't humiliated enough already.

Question: A member of the Kingsguard? As if I wasn't humiliated enough already.
Answer: Brienne is a very capable warrior.

Question: Jealous? Of Brienne the Beauty? Don't make me laugh.
Answer: I'll make it up to you.

Question: And Margaery's a virgin?
Answer: Officially. Shall I bring her to you?

Question: Officially. Shall I bring her to you?
Answer: I should warn you, I've had quite a bit of wine.

Question: You think so? I can't decide how I like it better. This way, or this way.
Answer: You certainly don't need it.

Question: Do you want my brother to come in and help?
Answer: What?

Question: What?
Answer: He could get you started. I know he wouldn't mind. Or I can turn over and you can pretend I'm him.

Question: You monster. Myrcella is my only daughter. Do you really think I'll let you sell her like a common whore?
Answer: Myrcella's a princess. Some would say she was born for this.

Question: Are you mad? The Martells loathe us.
Answer: That's why we need to seduce them. We're going to need their support in the war your son started.

Question: Just how safe do you think Myrcella is if this city falls? Do you want to see her raped, butchered like the Targaryen children? Make no mistake. They'll mount her pretty little head on a spike right beside yours.
Answer: Get out! Get out!

Question: Theon of the House Greyjoy, you would this day consecrate your faith to the Drowned God?
Answer: I would.

Question: I don't appreciate being made a fool of, dwarf. If Myrcella marries the Martell boy, she can't very well marry Robin Arryn, can she?
Answer: No, afraid not. Sorry about that.

Question: No, he won't. But his mother might. How would you like to see your beloved Cat again?
Answer: Find him?

Question: Find him?
Answer: Oh, aye. And he has company. Filthy old stoat. Almost hate to interrupt.

Question: What is the meaning of this?
Answer: No, please, please.

Question: How long have you been spying for my sister?
Answer: All I did, I did for House Lannister. Always. Your lord father, ask him. I've always been his servant since the days of the Mad King.

Question: What? What?
Answer: Oh, no. No.

Question: How many Hands have you betrayed, Pycelle? Eddard Stark? Jon Arryn?
Answer: Oh, Lord Arryn, h-he knew. He, he knew the t-truth about, about, about the Queen. An-And he planned to act, to t-tell King Robert.

Question: So you poisoned him?
Answer: No. Never.

Question: And it seems the Grand Maester has found his way into a black cell?
Answer: Well played, My Lord Hand. But should I be worried? Janos Slynt, Pycelle - The Small Council grows smaller every day.

Question: Well played, My Lord Hand. But should I be worried? Janos Slynt, Pycelle - The Small Council grows smaller every day.
Answer: The Council has a reputation for serving past Hands poorly. I don't mean to follow Ned Stark to the grave.

Question: Power is a curious thing, my lord. Are you fond of riddles?
Answer: Why, am I about to hear one?

Question: Why, am I about to hear one?
Answer: Three great men sit in a room. A king, a priest and a rich man. Between them stands a common sellsword. Each great man bids the sellsword kill the other two. Who lives, who dies?

Question: Three great men sit in a room. A king, a priest and a rich man. Between them stands a common sellsword. Each great man bids the sellsword kill the other two. Who lives, who dies?
Answer: Depends on the sellsword.

Question: Does it? He has neither crown nor gold nor favor with the gods.
Answer: He has a sword, the power of life and death.

Question: But if it's swordsmen who rule, why do we pretend kings hold all the power? When Ned Stark lost his head, who was truly responsible? Joffrey? The executioner? Or something else?
Answer: I've decided I don't like riddles.

Question: What?
Answer: How do you sleep?

Question: How do you sleep?
Answer: Same as most men, I think.

Question: How do you sleep when you... when you have those things in your head?
Answer: You didn't see that. I made damn sure.

Question: You know, we've got something in common, me and you. You know that? I must have been a couple of years older than you. I saw my brother stabbed through the heart right on our doorstep. He weren't much of a villain what skewered him. Willem, the lado s name was. He ran off before anyone could spit. And I just stood there, watching my brother die. Here's the funny part. I can't picture my brother's face anymore. But Willem, oh, he was a nice-looking boy. He had good white teeth, blue eyes, one of those dimpled chins all the girls like. I would think about him when I was working, when I was drinking, when I was having a shit. It got to the point where I would say his name every night before I went to bed. Willem. Willem. Willem. A prayer almost. Well, one day, Willem came riding back into town. I buried an ax so deep into Willem's skull, they had to bury him with it. Willem's horse got me to the Wall and I've been wearing black ever since. Well... That'll help you sleep, eh?
Answer: Ho! Get up, you lazy sons of whores! Arm yourselves.

Question: Keep out of sight. If things go wrong, you run. Do you hear me? You run along north and don't look back.
Answer: Hey, there's men out there who want to fuck your corpses. Outside, now!

Question: Loras Tyrell?
Answer: Loras Tyrell. He's prettier than the Queen.

Question: How good could he be? He's been stabbing Renly Baratheon for years, and Renly ain't dead.
Answer: The horses seem a little spooked to you? They're horses.

Question: The horses seem a little spooked to you? They're horses.
Answer: They get spooked by their own shadows.

Question: Shh. Do you hear that?
Answer: No.

Question: I swear you pissed yourself. "Oh, who goes there? Ahh!"
Answer: There is something out there.

Question: Do you think I'm an idiot?
Answer: Rennick!

Question: What's your name?
Answer: Talisa.

Question: Your last name?
Answer: You want to know what side my family fights on?

Question: You want to know what side my family fights on?
Answer: You know my family name. You have me at a disadvantage.

Question: That boy did?
Answer: The family he fights for.

Question: Do you think he's friends with King Joffrey? He's a fisherman's son that grew up near Lannisport. He probably never held a spear before they shoved one in his hands a few months ago.
Answer: I have no hatred for the lad.

Question: You're going to kill Joffrey?
Answer: If the gods give me strength.

Question: And then what?
Answer: I don't know. We'll go back to Winterfell. I have no desire to sit on the Iron Throne.

Question: So who will?
Answer: I don't know.

Question: You're fighting to overthrow a king, and yet you have no plan for what comes after?
Answer: First we have to win the war.

Question: Volantis? You're far from home. The boy was lucky you were here.
Answer: He was unlucky that you were.

Question: What is the meaning of this?
Answer: What kind of knight beats a helpless girl?

Question: What kind of knight beats a helpless girl?
Answer: The kind who serves his king, Imp.

Question: Someone get the girl something to cover herself with. She is to be your queen. Have you no regard for her honor?
Answer: I'm punishing her.

Question: For what crimes? She did not fight her brother's battle, you half-wit.
Answer: You can't talk to me like that. The king can do as he likes!

Question: The Mad King did as he liked. Has your Uncle Jaime ever told you what happened to him?
Answer: No one threatens His Grace in the presence of the Kingsguard.

Question: I'm not threatening the king, ser. I am educating my nephew. Bronn, the next time Ser Meryn speaks, kill him. That was a threat. See the difference?
Answer: I apologize for my nephew's behavior. Tell me the truth. Do you want an end to this engagement?

Question: I apologize for my nephew's behavior. Tell me the truth. Do you want an end to this engagement?
Answer: I am loyal to King Joffrey, my one true love.

Question: You think dipping his wick will cure what ails him?
Answer: There's no cure for being a cunt. But the boy's at that age. And he's got nothing to do all day but pick wings off flies. Couldn't hurt to get some of the poison out.

Question: What are you doing here, dog?
Answer: Your uncle left your nameday present and asked me to see that you got it.

Question: And? What is it?
Answer: Look inside, Your Grace.

Question: Could you hit her?
Answer: My uncle sent you?

Question: My uncle sent you?
Answer: Yes, Your Grace. He chose us himself.

Question: Now you do the Lannisters' bidding, is that it? Tell me, was my brother's body even cold before you secured your newest patron?
Answer: I'm a practical man.

Question: And who would you have me be loyal to? Your brother's corpse?
Answer: I don't like you, Lord Baelish. I don't like your face. I don't like the words that come oozing out of your mouth. I don't want you in my tent one minute more than necessary. So tell me, why are you here?

Question: I don't like you, Lord Baelish. I don't like your face. I don't like the words that come oozing out of your mouth. I don't want you in my tent one minute more than necessary. So tell me, why are you here?
Answer: You can trust Brienne. Her loyalty comes without charge.

Question: Your tent"? Not "Our tent"? The king snores, perhaps? Or simply prefers solitude? Pressures of command, no doubt. Four kings vying for the throne.
Answer: I am not tutored in warfare, but basic arithmetic favors the side with the greater numbers.

Question: And on the night of your wedding, who was by the king's side then?
Answer: You seem quite interested in our marriage.

Question: You've never married, have you?
Answer: I've been unlucky in my affections, sadly.

Question: Qarth?
Answer: Three days to the east, on the sea.

Question: Will they let us in?
Answer: They said they would be honored to receive the Mother of Dragons.

Question: What do you know of this place?
Answer: Only that the desert around their walls is called the Garden of Bones. Every time the Qartheen shut their gates on a traveler, the garden grows.

Question: What kind of fire melts stone?
Answer: Dragonfire.

Question: There's dragons here?
Answer: No, all the dragons are dead.

Question: What's that smell?
Answer: Dead people.

Question: They take someone every day?
Answer: Does anyone live?

Question: Does anyone live?
Answer: Joffrey. Cersei. llyn Payne. The Hound. Joffrey. Cersei. llyn Payne. The Hound. Joffrey. Cersei. llyn Payne. The Hound.

Question: How dare you?
Answer: You may have heard false reports.

Question: Betrayed? I wanted him to serve as Protector of the Realm. I begged him to seize the moment.
Answer: I trusted you. My husband trusted you. And you repaid our faith with treachery.

Question: Have you lost your mind? Get out!
Answer: Do you want to see your girls again? Sansa, more beautiful than ever? And Arya, just as wild as ever?

Question: Do you want to see your girls again? Sansa, more beautiful than ever? And Arya, just as wild as ever?
Answer: You have Arya, too?

Question: You have Arya, too?
Answer: Both girls are healthy and safe. For now. But you know the Queen and you know Joffrey. I fear for their longevity if they remain in the capital.

Question: What do you want?
Answer: The Lannisters will trade your daughters for the Kingslayer.

Question: Of course they will. Jaime Lannister for two girls? Robb will never agree to those terms.
Answer: I'm not bringing these terms to him. I'm bringing them to you.

Question: You think I keep secrets from my son?
Answer: Robb has surprised them all with his skills in battle, but he's not a mother. Consider it, Cat. You may not get another chance. I've brought you a gift.

Question: Good faith?
Answer: What's this?

Question: What's this?
Answer: Your husband was an honorable man. He should rest beside his family in the crypts beneath Winterfell. You may not believe

Question: The Mountain. What are you doing?
Answer: He told me he stares at him every day. That's why he doesn't get picked.

Question: Is there gold and silver in the village?
Answer: I don't know.

Question: Gems?
Answer: I didn't see any.

Question: Where is the Brotherhood?
Answer: I don't know. Please.

Question: Which of the villagers aided them?
Answer: Who?

Question: Who?
Answer: I-

Question: Who helped him?
Answer: Ganes, the butcher, and his son.

Question: No, stop, please! What are you doing? Please, stop! Please, stop!
Answer: No! No! I told you everything! No! No!

Question: Can that truly be you?
Answer: Who else might it be?

Question: Who else might it be?
Answer: When I saw your standard, I couldn't be sure. Whose banner is that?

Question: When I saw your standard, I couldn't be sure. Whose banner is that?
Answer: My own.

Question: I suppose if we used the same one, the battle would be terribly confusing. Why is your stag on fire?
Answer: The king has taken for his sigil the fiery heart of the Lord of Light.

Question: Born amidst salt and smoke? Is he a ham?
Answer: That's twice I've warned you.

Question: Look across those fields, brother. Can you see all those banners?
Answer: You think a few bolts of cloth will make you king?

Question: You think a few bolts of cloth will make you king?
Answer: No. The men holding those bolts of cloth will make me king.

Question: Would you believe I loved him once?
Answer: I thought we were welcome.

Question: Horde?
Answer: My name is Daenerys-

Question: You know me, my lord?
Answer: Only by reputation, Khaleesi. And I'm no lord, merely a humble merchant. They call you the Mother of Dragons.

Question: And what should I call you?
Answer: Oh, my name is quite long and quite impossible for foreigners to pronounce. I am simply a trader of spices. But we are the Thirteen, charged with the governance and protection of Qarth, the greatest city that ever was or will be.

Question: Might we see the dragons?
Answer: My friend, we have traveled very far. We have no food, no water. Once I see my people fed, I would be honored

Question: What are you doing? You promised to receive me.
Answer: We have received you. Here we are, and here you are.

Question: The girl threatens to burn our city to the ground and you would invite her in for a cup of wine? She is the Mother of Dragons.
Answer: Do you expect her to watch her people starve without breathing fire? I believe we can allow a few Dothraki through our gates without dooming our city. After all, here I am, a savage from the Summer Isles, and Qarth still stands.

Question: Do you expect her to watch her people starve without breathing fire? I believe we can allow a few Dothraki through our gates without dooming our city. After all, here I am, a savage from the Summer Isles, and Qarth still stands.
Answer: Our decision is final.

Question: Is there gold or silver in the village?
Answer: I'm not from the village.

Question: What's this?
Answer: We weren't expecting you till tomorrow, Lord Tywin.

Question: Evidently not. Why are these prisoners not in their cells?
Answer: Cells are overflowing, my lord.

Question: Are we so well-manned that we can afford to discard able young bodies and skilled laborers?
Answer: You, do you have a trade?

Question: You, do you have a trade?
Answer: Smith, my lord.

Question: What are you looking at? Kneel! Kneel or I'll carve your lungs out, boy.
Answer: He'll do no such thing. This one's a girl, you idiot, dressed as a boy. Why?

Question: He'll do no such thing. This one's a girl, you idiot, dressed as a boy. Why?
Answer: Safer to travel, my lord.

Question: So it is. Will you take a cup with me? I find that mulled wine helps me sleep.
Answer: I am here at Her Grace's behest, not to drink with you, Imp.

Question: If my sister was so concerned for Pycelle, I would have thought she'd come herself. Instead she sends you. What am I to make of that?
Answer: I don't care what you make of it, so long as you release your prisoner immediately.

Question: And you've received these instructions directly from Cersei?
Answer: As I said several times.

Question: And you've waited this long to deliver the information?
Answer: When the Queen Regent gives me a command, I carry it out without delay.

Question: An anointed knight, yes. Tell me, did Cersei have you knighted before or after she took you into her bed? What? Nothing to say? No more warnings for me, ser?
Answer: You will withdraw these filthy accusations.

Question: Have you ever given any thought to what King Joffrey will have to say when he finds out you've been bedding his mother?
Answer: It's not my fault!

Question: Did she take you against your will? Can you not defend yourself, knight?
Answer: Your own father, Lord Tywin, when I was named the King's squire, he told me to obey her in everything.

Question: Did he tell you to fuck her, too?
Answer: I only meant I did as I was bid.

Question: Hated every moment of it, is that what you'll have me believe? A high place in court, a knighthood, my sister's legs spreading open for you at night. Oh, yes, it must have been terrible. Wait here. His Grace will want to hear this.
Answer: Mercy! Mercy, my lord! I beg you.

Question: My lord?
Answer: You heard me. My father told you to obey my sister. Obey her. Stay close to her side. Keep her trust. Pleasure her whenever she requires. No one ever need know, as long as you keep faith with me. I want to know what Cersei is doing, where she goes, who she sees, what they talk of, everything. And you will tell me.

Question: But her demands?
Answer: Oh, I'll give her Pycelle.

Question: You will?
Answer: Yes, I'll release him in the morning. Cersei can keep him as a pet, if she wants, but I will not have him on the Council. I could swear that I had not harmed a single hair on his head, but that would not, strictly speaking, be true. Stay within one table length.

Question: Do your knuckle bones bring you luck?
Answer: Well, life's been good since you hacked them off, Your Grace. And it's four less fingernails to clean.

Question: Pardon?
Answer: Four fewer fingernails to clean. Never understood why you had to wear them.

Question: Does he listen?
Answer: To me? Gods, no. But if your Red Woman told him to leap from the crow's nest

Question: To me? Gods, no. But if your Red Woman told him to leap from the crow's nest
Answer: She has a name. I trust you've not forgotten your smuggler's tricks.

Question: Any shore, any night. What am I bringing ashore?
Answer: The Red Woman. No one must know what you do and we'll not speak of this again.

Question: Are you afraid, Onion Knight?
Answer: Someone once told me the night is dark and full of terrors.

Question: You've carried more unpleasant cargo in your time. Are you a good man, Ser Davos Seaworth?
Answer: I'd say my parts are mixed, my lady, good and bad.

Question: And which are you?
Answer: Oh, good. I'm a knight myself, of sorts, a champion of light and life.

Question: Do you love your wife?
Answer: I do.

Question: You swear it?
Answer: By the mother. My son has no interest in the Iron Throne.

Question: And the wording of this oath?
Answer: The same Ned Stark swore to Robert eighteen years ago. Cat, their friendship held the kingdoms together.

Question: And in return for my son's loyalty?
Answer: In the morning, I'll destroy my brother's army.

Question: Negotiate with Stannis? You heard him out there. I'd have better luck debating the wind.
Answer: Please bring my terms to your son. I believe we are natural allies. I hope he feels the same. Together we could end this war in a fortnight.

Question: I don't believe that. You don't believe that. Who gained the most from our king's death?
Answer: Stannis.

Question: Tell me, Ser Loras, what do you desire most in this world?
Answer: Revenge.

Question: Do you want to be a queen?
Answer: No. I want to be the queen.

Question: Killed? By whom?
Answer: Accounts differ. Most seem to implicate Catelyn Stark in some way.

Question: Really? Who'd have thought?
Answer: Some say it was one of his own Kingsguard, while still others say it was Stannis himself who did it after negotiations went sour.

Question: Aren't there other things you should be doing, like sealing my daughter in a crate so you can ship her away?
Answer: She'll be safer in Dorne.

Question: So clever. Aren't you always so clever with your schemes and your plots?
Answer: Schemes and plots are the same thing. They are going to attack us. We need to be ready.

Question: May I ask specifically what the king has in mind?
Answer: You may, specifically, or you may ask vaguely. The answer will be the same.

Question: Wildfire? You wouldn't lie to me, would you, cousin?
Answer: No.

Question: It is not a lie. Why would I lie?
Answer: Tell me, if the vile allegations against my brother and sister are true, do you think it will make Jaime more likely to kill you or less likely? When I tell him you're fucking her, I mean.

Question: Tell me, if the vile allegations against my brother and sister are true, do you think it will make Jaime more likely to kill you or less likely? When I tell him you're fucking her, I mean.
Answer: I'm telling you the truth.

Question: When did she tell you this?
Answer: I heard her talking with the pyromancer. And the other night, after I left her, she went to meet him. I swear to you.

Question: Swear to me on what?
Answer: On my life.

Question: What is it?
Answer: I'm sorry about your brother, Your Grace, I wanted to let you know that people grieve for him.

Question: You've come to lecture me on truth?
Answer: I've come to tell you that what I saw.

Question: When do we sail for King's Landing?
Answer: As soon as I've consolidated my troops. We'll make short work of the Lannisters' fleet. Once Blackwater Bay is cleared, we'll deliver our troops to their doorstep and take the city.

Question: And will you bring Lady Melisandre with you?
Answer: That's not your concern.

Question: I never thought I'd have reason to doubt your loyalty. Was I wrong?
Answer: Loyal service means telling hard truths.

Question: Oh, truth again. All right, what's the truth? The hard truth?
Answer: She's a foreigner preaching her foreign religion. Some believe she whispers orders in your ear and you obey.

Question: What do you believe?
Answer: You won those bannermen from Renly. Don't lose them to her.

Question: Stannis has more infantry, more ships, more horses. What do we have?
Answer: There's that mind of yours you keep going on about.

Question: Good thing. I'd be out of a job. What about your father?
Answer: He hasn't sent a raven in weeks. He's very busy. Being repeatedly humiliated by Robb Stark is time-consuming. We won't be able to hold the city against Stannis, not the way Joffrey's planning on holding it.

Question: We are swollen, bloated, foul. Brother fornicates with sister in the bed of kings and we're surprised when the fruit of their incest is rotten? Yes, a rotten king.
Answer: It's hard to argue with his assessment.

Question: What? Demon monkey?
Answer: People think you're pulling the king's strings. They blame you for the city's ills.

Question: Blame me? I'm trying to save them.
Answer: You don't need to convince me.

Question: You're the crew of the Sea Bitch? I'm your commander. Welcome.
Answer: Stop. Stop! Your captain commands you to stop!

Question: Where are we headed, Captain?
Answer: The Stony Shore, to raid their villages. There'll be spoils in it for you, and women, if you do your jobs well.

Question: And who decides if we've done our jobs well?
Answer: I do. Your captain.

Question: I have been reaving and raping since before you left Balon's balls, Captain. Don't reckon I've got much use for your ideas on how to do it. Don't reckon I've got much use for a captain at all. I'm thinking I can do the job of captain real well myself. All I need is a ship. You wouldn't know where I could find myself a ship now, would you?
Answer: You could do that, take the ship, head out on your own. And I will hunt you down, drag you back here in chains and hang you for a traitor.

Question: Who are you?
Answer: Dagmer, your first mate.

Question: Why aren't you with the rest of them? Or did they send you to row me out and dump me halfway in the sea? That would be good for a laugh.
Answer: They're not gonna respect you until you prove yourself.

Question: And how am I supposed to prove myself by pillaging piss-poor fishing villages?
Answer: You're not.

Question: They're all Iron Islanders. Do they do as they're told or do they do as they like?
Answer: The Stony Shore's not far from Torrhen's Square.

Question: The seat of the House of Tallhart, a more impressive prize than a few fishermen's daughters. What, you don't think we could take it?
Answer: No, we could. We could never hold it for more than a few days. As soon as Winterfell got word that we'd taken Torrhen's Square, the Starks would send their men to take it back. And then-

Question: And I'm sure if those same spies snuck into our own encampments, they would report growing discontent amongst the Southern lords. This is war, no one's content. We've underestimated the Stark boy for too long. He has a good mind for warfare, his men worship him. And as long as he keeps winning battles, they'll keep believing he is King in the North. You've been waiting for him to fail. He is not going to fail, not without our help. So how do we stop him?
Answer: We've worked through the night, my lord. Perhaps we'd profit from some sleep.

Question: Not wine, water. We'll be here for some time. Girl, where are you from?
Answer: Maidenpool, my lord.

Question: And who are the Lords of Maidenpool? Remind me.
Answer: House Mooton, my lord.

Question: And what is their sigil?
Answer: A red salmon. I think a Maidenpool girl would remember that. You're a Northerner, aren't you?

Question: A red salmon. I think a Maidenpool girl would remember that. You're a Northerner, aren't you?
Answer: Good. One more time, where are you from?

Question: Good. One more time, where are you from?
Answer: Barrowton, my lord. House Dustin. Two crossed longaxes beneath a black crown.

Question: And what do they say of Robb Stark in the North?
Answer: They call him the Young Wolf.

Question: And?
Answer: They say he rides into battle on the back of a giant direwolf. They say he can turn into a wolf himself when he wants. They say he can't be killed.

Question: And do you believe them?
Answer: No, my lord. Anyone can be killed.

Question: A girl keeps her mouth closed. No one hears, and friends may talk in secret, yes? A boy becomes a girl.
Answer: I was always a girl.

Question: And you fetch water for one of them now. Why is this right for you and wrong for me?
Answer: I didn't have a choice.

Question: Three what?
Answer: The Red God takes what is his, lovely girl. And only death may pay for life. You saved me and the two I was with. You stole three deaths from the Red God. We have to give them back. Speak three names and the man will do the rest. Three lives I will give you, no more, no less, and we're done.

Question: I can name anyone and you'll kill him?
Answer: A man has said.

Question: When will he come?
Answer: The Halfhand does things in his own time.

Question: Beautiful, isn't it? Gilly would love it here.
Answer: There's nothing more sickening than a man in love.

Question: Thousands and thousands of years ago, the First Men stood here where we're standing all through the long night. What do you think they were like, the First Men?
Answer: Stupid. Smart people don't find themselves in places like this.

Question: Wildlings?
Answer: One blast is for rangers returning. Wildlings is two blasts.

Question: But if it's been a thousand years, how do you know?
Answer: Well I read it in a book.

Question: To do what?
Answer: The jars are put in catapults and flung at the enemy.

Question: How much do you have?
Answer: If you could get real soldiers to man the catapults, then maybe you'd hit your target one time in ten, but all the real soldiers are in the Riverlands with your father.

Question: Well, he's not living anymore. And all his pots of wildfire didn't help him, did they? Men win wars, not magic tricks.
Answer: We have been working tirelessly, day and night, ever since your royal sister commanded us to do so. Our present count stands at 7,811. Enough to burn Stannis Baratheon's fleet and armies both.

Question: Did you see the dress Xaro had made for you? They say he's the wealthiest man in Qarth.
Answer: It is known.

Question: What are they doing?
Answer: Malakko says the statue is too heavy to carry. Kovarro says that Malakko is an idiot. They can pry out the gems, the rest is pure gold. Very soft. He can chop off as much as we can carry.

Question: Why not?
Answer: Our host saved us from the Red Waste and you want to steal from him? I will hear no more.

Question: Our host saved us from the Red Waste and you want to steal from him? I will hear no more.
Answer: My brother used to say the only thing the Dothraki knew how to do was steal things better men have built.

Question: Mother of Dragons. On behalf of the warlocks of Qarth, I welcome you. A demonstration?
Answer: Take this gem. Look at it. Into its depths. So many facets. Look closely enough and you can see yourself in them. Often more than once.

Question: What is the House of the Undying?
Answer: It is where the warlocks go to squint at dusty books and drink shade of the evening. It turns their lips blue and their minds soft. So soft, they actually believe their parlor tricks are magic.

Question: Do I know you?
Answer: I know you. Jorah Mormont of Bear Island.

Question: Who are you?
Answer: I'm no one. But she is the Mother of Dragons. She needs true protectors, now more than ever. They shall come day and night to see the wonder born into the world again. And when they see, they shall lust, for dragons are fire made flesh. And fire is power.

Question: Will you stay there long, my lady?
Answer: Only long enough to tell Robb what I have seen. After that, I will leave for Winterfell. My two youngest need me. I've been away from them for far too long.

Question: Once you're safely back amongst your own people, will you give me leave to go, my lady?
Answer: You mean to kill Stannis.

Question: Torrhen's Square is barely forty leagues from here. How can the Lannisters strike so far north?
Answer: Might be a raiding party led by the Mountain. Might be sellswords paid by Tywin Lannister.

Question: Do you need so many?
Answer: If we can't protect our own bannermen, why should they protect us? Go, Ser Rodrik. Take the men you need.

Question: If we can't protect our own bannermen, why should they protect us? Go, Ser Rodrik. Take the men you need.
Answer: Won't take long, my lord. Southerners don't do well up here.

Question: So, what does it mean?
Answer: Ask your Maester Luwin. He's the one studying books all the time.

Question: So, you've been dreaming of a three-eyed raven again? In the godswood, you told me you didn't dream. Now who's a liar? What did you see in your dream?
Answer: Something bad? Tell me, boy.

Question: Something bad? Tell me, boy.
Answer: I dreamt that the sea came to Winterfell. I saw waves crashing against the gates and the water came flowing over the walls. It flooded the castle. Drowned men were floating here, in the yard. Ser Rodrik was one of them.

Question: Osha. The three-eyed raven, what do they say about it north of the Wall?
Answer: They say all sorts of crazy things north of the Wall.

Question: Where?
Answer: On that mountain.

Question: How many wildlings have joined him?
Answer: From what we can tell, all of them. Mance has gathered them all like deer against the wolves. They're almost ready to make their move.

Question: Where?
Answer: Somewhere safe. Somewhere south. Can't just march into their midst. And we can't wait for them here with nothing but a pile of stones to protect us.

Question: You saying we should fall back to the Wall?
Answer: Mance was one of us once. Now he's one of them. He's going to teach them our way of doing things. They'll hit us in force and they won't run away when we hit back. They're gonna be more organized than before, more disciplined, more like us. So we need to be more like them, do things their way. Sneak in, kill Mance, and scatter them to the winds before they can march on the Wall. And to do that

Question: I've fought and killed a wight. How many rangers can say that?
Answer: He's the one?

Question: He's the one?
Answer: Aye. You killed a wight. You also let an old man beat you bloody and take your sword.

Question: Craster? In the boy's defense, that's a tough old goat.
Answer: I could take up Jon's duties while he's gone, my lord. It would be no trouble.

Question: So, tell me, how long has your manservant been in love with you?
Answer: He's not my manservant and he's not in love with me. He's my advisor and he's my friend.

Question: And what about what a woman wants?
Answer: Much more complicated. You, for example, what do you want?

Question: Much more complicated. You, for example, what do you want?
Answer: To cross the Narrow Sea and take back the Iron Throne.

Question: Why?
Answer: Because I promised my khalasar I'd protect them and find them a safe home.

Question: You want to conquer the Seven Kingdoms for the Dothraki?
Answer: I want them because they're mine by right. The Iron Throne is mine and I will take it.

Question: And how did you get all of this? Did someone give it to you?
Answer: No. I come from nothing. I hit the docks like a piece of cargo, except someone normally cares what happens to cargo.

Question: What do you want, Xaro Xhoan Daxos? At the gates of the city, you bled for me. Why?
Answer: I will show you why.

Question: And behind the door?
Answer: And it can all be mine?

Question: And it can all be mine?
Answer: All? Let us say half. More than enough to buy horses, ships, armies. Enough to go home.

Question: All? Let us say half. More than enough to buy horses, ships, armies. Enough to go home.
Answer: All I have to do?

Question: All I have to do?
Answer: Is marry me.

Question: See? I have more ambition than you thought. The time is right, Daenerys Targaryen, First of Your Name. Robert Baratheon is dead.
Answer: If you cross the sea with an army you bought and a foreign husband who paid for it...

Question: According to your new friend who earned your trust by cutting his hand?
Answer: The time to strike is now. We need to find ships and an army or we'll spend the rest of our lives rotting away at the edge of the world.

Question: What do you want? Tell me.
Answer: To see you on the Iron Throne.

Question: Why?
Answer: You have a good claim. A title. A birthright. But you have something more than that. You may cover it up and deny it, but you have a gentle heart. You would not only be respected and feared, you would be loved. Someone who can rule and should rule. Centuries come and go without a person like that coming into the world. There are times when I look at you and I still can't believe you're real.

Question: So what would you have me do, as my advisor?
Answer: Make your own way. Find your own ship. You only need one. The allies we need are in Westeros, not Qarth.

Question: And how do I get the ship?
Answer: I'll find it for you. A sound ship with a good captain.

Question: Sideface?
Answer: Sideways.

Question: Why?
Answer: Smaller target.

Question: Am I fighting someone?
Answer: You're practicing for a fight. You should practice right.

Question: Guards! Did you see anything? Go up there. Go and see where he fell from.
Answer: Go up the battlement.

Question: Theon?
Answer: It's Prince Theon now. Get up. You have to get dressed. I've taken Winterfell. I took it. I'm occupying it. I sent men over the walls with grappling claws and ropes.

Question: Why?
Answer: To take the castle.

Question: And he sent me back to Pyke. I'm a Greyjoy. I can't fight for Robb and my father both. Where's Hodor?
Answer: I don't know.

Question: Theon. Did you hate us the whole time?
Answer: I've yielded Winterfell to Theon.

Question: If you serve me as loyally as you served Ned Stark, I will be as good to you as he ever was. Betray me, and you will wish you hadn't. Maester Luwin, send a raven to Pyke informing my father of my victory here. And one to Deepwood Motte to my sister. Inform her that she's to bring You are a maester of the Citadel, sworn to serve the Lord of Winterfell, are you not?
Answer: I am.

Question: I see you've finally learned how to address your betters. What do you want? I was brought here a captive.
Answer: You were here the day I was taken.

Question: I'm the one who took you. What of it?
Answer: Let me serve you.

Question: Serve me how? I need fighters, not kitchen sluts.
Answer: It was Robb Stark who put me in the kitchens. Put a spear in my hand again.

Question: So you can bury it in my neck? Do you take me for a fool? Get up.
Answer: Step aside.

Question: Any last words, old man?
Answer: Gods help you, Theon Greyjoy. Now you are truly lost.

Question: Look around, boy. This look like home to you? You start thinking you know this place, it will kill you. You understand me?
Answer: No, you don't. We're at war. We've always been at war. It's never going to end 'cause we're not fighting an enemy. We're fighting the North, and it's not going anywhere. The Watch has given you a great gift. You only have one thing to give in return, your life.

Question: I don't want you to be glad about it. I want you to curse and fight until your heart's done pumping. And know this, boy. Your death will be a gift for them south of the Wall. They'll never know what you've done. They'll never know how you died. They won't even know your damn name. But they'll be alive because some nameless bastard north of the Wall gave his life for theirs. Now, do you understand me?
Answer: I do.

Question: Can you read?
Answer: My lord?

Question: My lord?
Answer: This letter detailing our infantry movements was meant for Lord Damon of House Marbrand. It was sent to Lord Marlyn of House Dormand.

Question: To whom does House Dormand owe allegiance?
Answer: My lord, I-

Question: Wine?
Answer: Thank you.

Question: What news from the capital?
Answer: I traveled here directly from Renly Baratheon's camp.

Question: You say that as if you were the first man alive to think it. Yes, a crisis is an opportunity. What other brilliant insights have you brought me today?
Answer: After the Lannisters and the Starks, the Tyrells command the largest host. Their lands are the most fertile in the Seven Kingdoms, feeding horses and soldiers.

Question: You would ride there yourself?
Answer: Tonight, with your leave.

Question: And what else?
Answer: On your son Tyrion's directive, I met with Catelyn Stark.

Question: Why?
Answer: He had an interesting proposal for her concerning her daughters.

Question: What's your name?
Answer: Ygritte.

Question: We'd need a big fire for that. Tell me, Ygritte. Why do you want us to build a big fire? Are there some more friends in the area?
Answer: Burn them or maybe you'll need those swords again.

Question: Our boy here's already killed one dead man. He can do it again if he has to. What waits beyond the pass?
Answer: The Free Folk.

Question: How many?
Answer: Hundreds and thousands. More than you've ever seen, crow.

Question: Why come to the mountains? What's in the Frostfangs your king could want?
Answer: Do you mean to march on the Wall?

Question: Do you mean to march on the Wall?
Answer: Do you know who I am, girl?

Question: Do you know who I am, girl?
Answer: Qhorin Halfhand.

Question: Tell me true. If your people captured me, would they take me prisoner?
Answer: They'd take your head off your shoulders if they was feeling kind. If not, they'd kill you slow.

Question: We have no food for her. Can't spare a man to watch her. Can't let her go. She'll bring Mance Rayder's army down on us. It needs to be done. Want me to do it?
Answer: No. No, I'll do it.

Question: You never killed a woman before, did you? You don't need to do it. Mance would take you. I know he would. There's secret ways. The crows would never catch us.
Answer: I'm as much a crow as they are.

Question: Will you burn me? After?
Answer: Can't. Someone might see the smoke.

Question: Did you say something, my lady?
Answer: My little brother cried when I left Winterfell.

Question: So?
Answer: It seems a normal thing.

Question: Is your little brother a prince?
Answer: No.

Question: Not really relevant then, is it? Come, dog.
Answer: Hail Joffrey! Hail to the King. Seven blessings on you, Your Grace.

Question: Who threw that? I want the man who threw that. Find who did that and bring him to me!
Answer: Hold on!

Question: What are you doing? I want these people executed!
Answer: And they want the same for you.

Question: Where's Sansa?
Answer: Through the door.

Question: They threw a cow pie at you, so you decided to kill them all? They're starving, you fool! All because of a war you started.
Answer: You're talking to a king!

Question: And now I've struck a king. Did my hand fall from my wrist? Where is the Stark girl?
Answer: Let them have her!

Question: Where are you going?
Answer: You ever been fucked, little girl? Come here.

Question: You ever been fucked, little girl? Come here.
Answer: Take some men and go and find the Stark girl.

Question: Where? This way.
Answer: Please! No! No!

Question: Are you hurt, my lady?
Answer: The little birdo s bleeding. Someone take her back to her cage. See to that cut.

Question: Every lady alive was lovelier and higher born than my grandfather. Did my servants not offer you something to eat, to drink? I'll have them flogged in the square.
Answer: Thank you, my lord. You are a gracious host, but there is no servant alive that can bring me what I want.

Question: Oh, she has a talent for drama, this one. So, my little princess, what is it you want?
Answer: My birthright. The Seven Kingdoms of Westeros.

Question: Retake? Did you once sit on the Iron Throne?
Answer: My father sat there, before he was murdered.

Question: But if you did not sit on it yourself, would it not be correct to say "take the Iron Throne"?
Answer: I didn't come here to argue grammar.

Question: Of course not. You came to take my ships. So let me explain my position, little princess. Unlike you, I do not have exalted ancestors. I make my living by trade. And I judge every trade on its merits. You ask for ships. You say I shall be repaid triple. I do not doubt your honesty or your intentions. But before you repay your debts, you must seize the Seven Kingdoms. Do you have an army?
Answer: Not yet.

Question: You do not have an army. Do you have powerful allies in Westeros?
Answer: There are many there that support my claim.

Question: When were you there last?
Answer: I left when I was a baby.

Question: Do you know lllyrio Mopatis, Magister of Pentos? Yes, we've met.
Answer: A shrewd man.

Question: For my wedding, he gave me three petrified dragon eggs. He believed The world believed that the ages had turned them to stone. How many centuries has it been since dragons roamed the skies? But I dreamt that if I carried those eggs into a great fire, they would hatch. When I stepped into the fire, my own people thought I was mad. But when the fire burned out, I was unhurt, the Mother of Dragons.
Answer: Do you understand? I'm no ordinary woman. My dreams come true.

Question: Do you understand? I'm no ordinary woman. My dreams come true.
Answer: I admire your passion. But in business, I trust in logic, not passion. I'm sorry, little princess.

Question: Who taught you to read?
Answer: My father, my lord.

Question: Hmm. I taught my son Jaime to read. The maester came to me one day, told me he wasn't learning. He couldn't make sense of the letters. He reversed them in his head. The maester said he'd heard tell of this affliction and that we simply must accept it. Ha! After that, I sat Jaime down for four hours every day until he learned. He hated me for it, for a time. For a long time. But he learned. Hmm. Where is your father? Is he alive? Who was he?
Answer: A stonemason.

Question: A stonemason who could read? Hmm.
Answer: He taught himself.

Question: Quite a man. What killed him?
Answer: Loyalty.

Question: You're a sharp little thing, aren't you?
Answer: Did... Forgive me, my lord. I shouldn't ask questions.

Question: Did you know your father, my lord?
Answer: I did. I grew up with him. I watched him grow old.

Question: Where are you going, girl?
Answer: The armory, my lord.

Question: Why?
Answer: Lord Tywin sent me.

Question: What might this be?
Answer: Lord Tywin gave it to me.

Question: What for?
Answer: To take to the armory.

Question: Why would he do that? Let's go and ask him.
Answer: Move! Get out of the way!

Question: Why are you so sure I'm of noble birth?
Answer: Because it's obvious.

Question: What if I told you my father sold lace on the Long Bridge, and my mother, my brother, and I lived with him above our shop?
Answer: I'd call you a liar.

Question: Will we be here long?
Answer: I couldn't really discuss troop movements with you.

Question: Lady Talisa...?
Answer: Maegyr.

Question: Maegyr? Forgive me, I do not know this name.
Answer: An uncommon name here. An old name in Volantis. Excuse me, my lady. Your Grace.

Question: Your brothers desert you? I can tell you which way to go.
Answer: We'll stop here. Too dark to go any farther today.

Question: Here? There's no shelter here.
Answer: There's no shelter anywhere.

Question: Think they're out looking for you?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Think they'll find you?
Answer: You're brave. Stupid, but brave.

Question: Was I? I didn't notice that time.
Answer: This cannot be true.

Question: Why? Why would Theon-
Answer: Because the Greyjoys are treasonous whores.

Question: My brothers?
Answer: We've heard nothing of them. But Rodrik Cassel is dead.

Question: How can I call myself king if I can't hold my own castle? How can I ask men to follow me if I can't-
Answer: You are a king. And that means you don't have to do everything yourself.

Question: Why on earth would I trust the word of a lying little savage like you?
Answer: I'm no liar.

Question: How? And don't tell me to put a spear in your hand.
Answer: There are other ways to serve, my lord.

Question: Like what?
Answer: We know things, the free people.

Question: You know things? Like what? How to eat dirt?
Answer: Other things.

Question: What do you want then, other than your miserable life?
Answer: What all free people want. My freedom.

Question: Why? Why would a stranger-
Answer: You are everything he will never have. Your horse eats better than his children. It doesn't matter now. He's dead.

Question: And where are you going?
Answer: I have something for you from Prince Theon.

Question: What?
Answer: Me. He says I'm to make the rounds. And keep you warm.

Question: The Spice King refuses me because I'm a bad investment. The Silk King won't support me because of his business with the Lannisters. Why offend his best customer? And the Copper King offers me a single ship on the condition that I lie with him for a night. Does he think I will whore myself for a boat?
Answer: When I came to this city, I had nothing. Truly nothing. I slept by the docks. And when I could find work loading the ships, I would eat. If not, I dreamed of food. Today, I am the richest man in Qarth. Do you think the path from poverty to wealth is always pure and honorable? I have done many things, Khaleesi, that a righteous man would condemn. And here I am, with no regrets.

Question: When I came to this city, I had nothing. Truly nothing. I slept by the docks. And when I could find work loading the ships, I would eat. If not, I dreamed of food. Today, I am the richest man in Qarth. Do you think the path from poverty to wealth is always pure and honorable? I have done many things, Khaleesi, that a righteous man would condemn. And here I am, with no regrets.
Answer: Bar the gates. Ring the bells. Slowly, Khaleesi.

Question: Where are they? Where are my dragons?
Answer: A cripple? You let a cripple escape? The boy can't walk, but somehow he slipped past you?

Question: A cripple? You let a cripple escape? The boy can't walk, but somehow he slipped past you?
Answer: The giant must have took him.

Question: The giant? Hodor? Oh, that's all right, then. You let a halfwit escape with a cripple. And Rickon, too? The little one?
Answer: Gone, along with the wildling woman. The one you were fucking.

Question: Come on, find the scent. Where they going?
Answer: Halt!

Question: Enjoying your first hunt?
Answer: So far, hunting seems very similar to riding, my lord.

Question: Did you pull a knife on me in the night?
Answer: What's the matter? Can't be the first time you pressed your bone against a woman's arse.

Question: What's the matter? Can't be the first time you pressed your bone against a woman's arse.
Answer: Let's move.

Question: It is the first time. How old are you, boy?
Answer: I'm a man of the Night's Watch.

Question: What, stones? Or bone?
Answer: Neither. Both.

Question: I heard they get all swollen and bruised if you don't use them. Of course, maybe that's just what the lads say when they want me feeling sorry for them. As if I'd feel sorry for them. Are there no girl crows?
Answer: There are no women of the Night's Watch, no.

Question: So the lads just do it with each other?
Answer: No.

Question: Never?
Answer: Never. We swore an oath.

Question: You have sheep at the Wall? With your hands, then? No wonder you're all so miserable.
Answer: Would you please shut up?

Question: Would you please shut up?
Answer: Would you please shut up? You think you're better than me, crow. I'm a free woman.

Question: Would you please shut up? You think you're better than me, crow. I'm a free woman.
Answer: You're a free woman?

Question: You're a free woman?
Answer: I might be your prisoner, but I'm a free woman.

Question: And you think you're free? You swore some stupid oath and now you can never touch a girl.
Answer: It was my choice to say the words.

Question: So you don't like girls?
Answer: Of course I like girls.
