Answer: The Brotherhood without Banners. Now come along. I want to hear how two boys and a very dangerous girl escaped Harrenhal.

Question: I'm not going with them. The Brotherhood? That's who the Mountain and them lot were looking for. They'll bring us back and put rats in us.
Answer: You've got nothing to fear from us, son. The lords of Westeros want to burn the countryside. We're trying to save it. Now come on. We'll talk some more over brown bread and stew. And then you can go on your way.

Question: Did anyone see you? No.
Answer: No.

Question: You sure? My father does not make idle threats. Having you killed would be the high point of his week. You have to be absolutely certain.
Answer: All right. What is this problem?

Question: All right. What is this problem?
Answer: I'm worried about Sansa. When she spoke with Lord Baelish, his friend warned me about him.

Question: Oh, Ros? The redhead?
Answer: How do you know her?

Question: How do you know her?
Answer: I try to know as many people as I can. You never know which one you'll need.

Question: And was she good? Did you like her?
Answer: Not as much as I like you, obviously, or she'd be the one torturing me right now. What did she say about Littlefinger?

Question: Not as much as I like you, obviously, or she'd be the one torturing me right now. What did she say about Littlefinger?
Answer: That Sansa shouldn't trust him.

Question: Is there an idiot in any village who trusts Littlefinger?
Answer: We have to protect her.

Question: A great beauty? Oh, a great beauty?
Answer: Yes, she is, objectively, very. Her face is quite pleasing-to other men and to women, people in general. But not to me, of course. I only have eyes for you.

Question: You pervert. You want her? This child?
Answer: I don't even want to talk about her.

Question: Now do you think I'm cruel?
Answer: Only if you stop. But you mustn't come here again.

Question: Do you hear me? You've come to a dangerous place full of dangerous people. Dangerous people.
Answer: Lady Tyrell, my king.

Question: You wanted to see me, Your Grace?
Answer: I'm leaving on a hunting trip. I just wanted to make sure you had everything you need before I left.

Question: Good. Good. How are you finding life in the capital? It must be quite a change after Renly's camp.
Answer: A welcome one. A military encampment is no place for a lady.

Question: And the bedside of a traitor? Is that a place for a lady?
Answer: Your Grace, I tried to do my duty as a wife, that is all.

Question: What was your duty to this traitor as you saw it?
Answer: The duty of any wife to any husband-to provide him with children.

Question: Why? I-I would not speak ill of the dead, Your Grace.
Answer: You think one ought to speak kindly of a traitor merely because he's had a sword put through his heart?

Question: You think one ought to speak kindly of a traitor merely because he's had a sword put through his heart?
Answer: No. I do beg your pardon. The subtleties of politics are often lost on me. Renly I don't believe he was interested in the company of women.

Question: What makes you say this?
Answer: Whenever I wanted to make a child with him, he-he had so many excuses, so many late-night war councils. He never wanted to try. Except one evening, after he'd had far too much wine to drink, he suggested something-something that sounded very painful and couldn't possibly result in children. Maybe the fault was with me.

Question: Do you like it? I just had it made. Probably one of the finest weapons in the Seven Kingdoms.
Answer: It's beautiful. Will you show me how it works?

Question: It's beautiful. Will you show me how it works?
Answer: It's a new design. Much easier to load. There's no crank. You use this lever to draw the string.

Question: Would you take me hunting sometime? Forgive me, Your Grace. I know a hunt is no place for a woman.
Answer: It's not unheard of.

Question: You no longer belong to him. Do you want to hold it?
Answer: May I? Please.

Question: May I? Please.
Answer: I imagine it must be so exciting to squeeze your finger here and watch something die over there.

Question: Could you do it? Could you kill something?.
Answer: I don't know, Your Grace Do you think I could?

Question: I don't know, Your Grace Do you think I could?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Would you like to watch me?
Answer: Stop! Stop!

Question: About what?
Answer: I don't know what you want.

Question: What truth?
Answer: Why'd you take Winterfell?

Question: Why'd you take Winterfell?
Answer: I took it to-I took it-

Question: Who gave the orders?
Answer: No one. I took it on my own.

Question: Why?
Answer: To take the North while it was vulnerable.

Question: What were you going to do once you took it?
Answer: Hold it. Rule it.

Question: Why did you do that?
Answer: I told you. Why did you take Winterfell?

Question: I told you. Why did you take Winterfell?
Answer: I took it to bring glory to my house and my father.

Question: What are you doing?
Answer: Please.

Question: Yara?
Answer: I'll come for you tonight when the castle sleeps.

Question: A three-eyed raven?
Answer: You've seen it?

Question: You've seen it?
Answer: We saw him together. You haven't forgotten?

Question: We saw him together. You haven't forgotten?
Answer: Does it have anything to do with warging?

Question: Does it have anything to do with warging?
Answer: No, the raven is something different, something deeper. The raven brings the sight.

Question: Seeing things that haven't happened yet?
Answer: Or things that happened long before you were born or things that are happening right now thousands of miles away.

Question: What's he telling him?
Answer: Why don't you ask?

Question: Why don't you ask?
Answer: Isn't he ashamed, your brother, needing you to protect him?

Question: Isn't he ashamed, your brother, needing you to protect him?
Answer: Where's the shame in that?

Question: Where's the shame in that?
Answer: Any boy his age who needs his sister to protect him is gonna find himself needing lots of protecting.

Question: You have the sight, too?
Answer: When I told my father about your father for the first time in my life, I saw him cry.

Question: Your father is Howland Reed? Yeah.
Answer: Yeah.

Question: Your father told you about the rebellion? Mine never did. But I saw that, too.
Answer: What else have you seen?

Question: What else have you seen?
Answer: Only one thing that matters-you.

Question: You see? They've all suffered through my bouts of sobriety. It's very tedious for all concerned. Now, how did three children-
Answer: We're not children.

Question: How did three young persons such as yourselves, untrained in the art of war, escape from Harrenhal?
Answer: Gendry's a smith. He was apprenticed in the armory.

Question: A smith, eh? Where'd you train?
Answer: King's Landing. Tobho Mott's shop.

Question: You'll free us?
Answer: I gave you my word.

Question: Now that is an uncommonly large person. How does one manage to subdue such an uncommonly large person?
Answer: One waits for him to drink until he passes out.

Question: Thoros? The fuck you doing here?
Answer: Drinking and talking too much. Same as ever.

Question: What in seven hells are you doing with the Stark bitch?
Answer: It's a tough decision - take the bridge and risk being seen or cross the great water.

Question: It's wonderful to watch you wrestle with these dilemmas. Which will she choose?
Answer: Gambler at heart. Wouldn't have guessed.

Question: I have these, you know, on your feet when you walk too far. What do you call them?
Answer: Get up now.

Question: See? If you were willing to hurt me, you might have had me there.
Answer: Looks like your woman's getting the better of you, if you can call that a woman.

Question: You sure he's the one?
Answer: That's him, all right. I saw him fight at the tourney for Ser Willem Frey's wedding.

Question: Enough to buy me a new head? If the King in the North hears I had the Kingslayer and let him go, he'll be taking it right off. I'd rather he takes yours.
Answer: If I may, nephew, I encountered a situation with one of my lieutenants at the Stone Mill which may have some bearing-

Question: Why don't you shut your mouth about that damned mill? And don't call him "nephew." He is your king.
Answer: Robb knows I meant him no disr-

Question: What value was the mill?
Answer: The Mountain was garrisoned across the river from it.

Question: Is he there now? Of course not.
Answer: We took the fight to him. He could not withstand us.

Question: Tywin Lannister has my sisters. Have I sued for peace?
Answer: No.

Question: Do you think he'll sue for peace because we have his father's brother's great-grandsons?
Answer: How many men did you lose?

Question: How many men did you lose?
Answer: But for every man we lost, the Lannisters-

Question: You know who isn't? Tywin Lannister.
Answer: Intimate. Lovely table. Better chairs than the old small council chamber. Conveniently close to your own quarters. I like it.

Question: What news of Jaime?
Answer: Twenty thousand unwashed Northerns have known about his escape for weeks. Collectively, you control more spies and informants than the rest of the world combined. Do you mean to tell me that none of you has any notion of where he is?

Question: Twenty thousand unwashed Northerns have known about his escape for weeks. Collectively, you control more spies and informants than the rest of the world combined. Do you mean to tell me that none of you has any notion of where he is?
Answer: We are trying, my lord.

Question: Try harder. What do we have, then?
Answer: Robb Stark and most of his bannermen are in Riverrun for the funeral of his grandfather Lord Hoster Tully. In Stark's absence, Roose Bolton holds Harrenhal, which would seem to make him Lord of Harrenhal, in practice if not in name.

Question: Master of Coin?
Answer: It would appear to be a position that best suits your talents.

Question: Would I?
Answer: They'll knock your teeth out.

Question: You think I care about my teeth?
Answer: No, I don't think you care about your teeth. If you fight them, they will kill you. Do you understand? I'm the prisoner of value, not you. Let them have what they want. What does it matter?

Question: No, I don't think you care about your teeth. If you fight them, they will kill you. Do you understand? I'm the prisoner of value, not you. Let them have what they want. What does it matter?
Answer: What does it matter?

Question: What does it matter?
Answer: Close your eyes. Pretend they're Renly.

Question: If you were a woman, you wouldn't resist? You'd let them do what they wanted?
Answer: If I was a woman, I'd make them kill me. But I'm not, thank the gods.

Question: Why are you helping him? He takes us prisoner and now he's our friend?
Answer: You're not our prisoner, little lady.

Question: What am I?
Answer: Our guest. No one's put any chains on you.

Question: So I can walk away, then?
Answer: These woods aren't safe for Ned Stark's daughter. You're lucky we found you.

Question: You think you're good with that bow, you little twat?
Answer: Better than anyone you've ever met.

Question: Why? So you can kiss him?
Answer: You remember the last time you were here?

Question: You remember the last time you were here?
Answer: Looks like every other shit inn on the road.

Question: What are you doing? We're about to leave.
Answer: I'm staying.

Question: You're what?
Answer: I baked some brown bread for the innkeep and she said she never had better. Told Thoros she's keeping me as a payment for all the free meals she's given him. Anyway, it's not me the Brotherhood wants. My brother ain't no king. I'm not a Stark of "Winterhell".

Question: You sure?
Answer: I'm sure.

Question: What is it?
Answer: It's a wolf.

Question: That's the tail?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: Maybe? Your father was a stubborn old ox. I was surprised when he died. Didn't think death had the patience.
Answer: I'm glad you were with him. I wish to the gods I had been. Did you make peace in the end?

Question: I'm glad you were with him. I wish to the gods I had been. Did you make peace in the end?
Answer: After thirty years of fighting, I don't think he remembered what started it. He asked me to stop calling myself Blackfish. He said it was an old joke and it was never funny to begin with. I told him people had been calling me Blackfish for so long, they don't remember my real name.

Question: Is it true what they say about him?
Answer: I don't know. What do they say about him?

Question: I don't know. What do they say about him?
Answer: That he can turn into a wolf at night.

Question: True. You're a Lannister, aren't you?
Answer: Martyn Lannister.

Question: Martyn Lannister. You've nothing to fear. My husband doesn't eat children. Unless it's a full moon. It's not a full moon tonight, is it? See? Nothing to fear.
Answer: Always the artists.

Question: How many men were here?
Answer: About three hundred.

Question: And you know what those men are now?
Answer: We're all the same to them - meat for their army.

Question: Do you think anyone got away?
Answer: It's not impossible. You don't go far betting against Mormont. But dead or alive, he took a big gamble coming north. And he lost. His best fighting men are dead. And whether he's Lord Commander of the Night's Watch or a blue-eyed corpse, he's a long way from home. Tormund. Climb the Wall. Take Orell and twenty good men. And take this one. He knows Castle Black's defenses better than any of us. And if he's useful, good. If not throw him off the Wall. See if crows can fly.

Question: We're finally going to war, old friend?
Answer: Hide near Castle Black. When I give the signal, hit them in the night. They've got a big old wall to hide behind, but it only guards one side.

Question: How will we see your signal?
Answer: Send your eagle above the Wall every night. When it's time, I'm going to light the biggest fire the North has ever seen.

Question: Ghost?
Answer: What have we here? Frozen crows?

Question: What have we here? Frozen crows?
Answer: We've come a long way.

Question: Oh, can we?
Answer: They need some water.

Question: You are a godly man?
Answer: I am. I got no fear of what's out there. When the white cold comes, your swords and cloaks and bloody fires won't help you. The only ones left will be those who are right with the gods. The real gods.

Question: Go tell her she can bite down on a rag or she can bite down on my fist. Women. That sow right there gave birth to a litter of eight. Barely a grunt. And she's almost as fat as this one here. Now why don't you dine on him? Carve off what you need as you go. Well, look at him. He's a walking feast.
Answer: Here we are.

Question: Sharpen these for me, would ya?
Answer: I see the head. Push.

Question: What is it? What is it?
Answer: Keep quiet.

Question: You're sure?
Answer: Ride east. Follow the rising sun. Your sister's waiting for you.

Question: You refuse to tell me where you're going?
Answer: I don't know yet. The fires will show me.

Question: How long will you be gone?
Answer: I don't know.

Question: Why?
Answer: You don't have the strength. It would kill you.

Question: To whom?
Answer: To any slave who contemplates doing whatever these slaves did.

Question: And what is she to do for soldiers?
Answer: We can find sellswords in Pentos and Myr.

Question: Is it 'we' already, Ser Barristan? If you want to sit on the throne your ancestors built, you must win it. That will mean blood on your hands before the thing is done.
Answer: The blood of my enemies, not the blood of innocents.

Question: How many wars have you fought in, Ser Barristan?
Answer: Three.

Question: Have you ever seen a war where innocents didn't die by the thousands?
Answer: I was in King's Landing after the sack, khaleesi. You know what I saw? Butchery. Babies, children, old men. More women raped than you can count. There's a beast in every man and it stirs when you put a sword in his hand. But the Unsullied are not men. They do not rape. They do not put cities to the sword unless they're ordered to do so. If you buy them, the only men they'll kill are those you want dead.

Question: I was in King's Landing after the sack, khaleesi. You know what I saw? Butchery. Babies, children, old men. More women raped than you can count. There's a beast in every man and it stirs when you put a sword in his hand. But the Unsullied are not men. They do not rape. They do not put cities to the sword unless they're ordered to do so. If you buy them, the only men they'll kill are those you want dead.
Answer: Do you disagree, Ser Barristan?

Question: Do you disagree, Ser Barristan?
Answer: When your brother Rhaegar led his army into battle at the Trident, men died for him because they believed in him, because they loved him, not because they'd been bought at a slaver's auction. I fought beside the last dragon on that day, Your Grace. I bled beside him.

Question: Did you know him well, Ser Barristan?
Answer: I did, Your Grace. Finest man I ever met.

Question: All? Did this one's ears mishear, Your Grace?
Answer: They did not. I want to buy them all.

Question: There are eight thousand Unsullied in Astapor. Is this what you mean by all?
Answer: Yes. eight thousand. And the ones still in training as well.

Question: So, ask this beggar queen how will she pay for the remaining 7,877?
Answer: Master Kraznys asks how you propose to pay for the remaining 7,877 unsullied.

Question: You're both here to advise me. I value your advice, but if you ever question me in front of strangers again, you'll be advising someone else. Is that understood?
Answer: Do you have a name?

Question: Do you have a name?
Answer: This one's name is Missandei, Your Grace.

Question: Do you have a family? A mother and a father you'd return to if you had the choice?
Answer: No, Your Grace. No family living.

Question: I offered water to one of the slaves dying on the Walk of Punishment. Do you know what he said to me? 'Let me die.'
Answer: There are no masters in the grave, Your Grace.

Question: Is it true what Master Kraznys told me about the Unsullied? About their obedience?
Answer: All questions have been taken from them. They obey, that is all. Once they are yours, they are yours. They will fall on their swords if you command it.

Question: And what about you? You know that I'm taking you to war. You may go hungry. You may fall sick. You may be killed.
Answer: Valar morghulis.

Question: I know. But how would the queen get that idea?
Answer: Why don't you ask her? Any advice for me on my new position?

Question: Why don't you ask her? Any advice for me on my new position?
Answer: Keep a low profile.

Question: They're only numbers. Numbers on paper. Once you understand that, it's easy to make them behave. Trivial even. You want a real challenge? Try whores.
Answer: I've tried quite a few. Well, lots of work to do. Enjoy the Eyrie.

Question: Yes, my lord?
Answer: After a long consultation with my colleague Ser Bronn, I finally found a suitable reward for the services you've provided over and above what might be considered reasonable. Tell me, Pod, have you ever been with a woman?

Question: After a long consultation with my colleague Ser Bronn, I finally found a suitable reward for the services you've provided over and above what might be considered reasonable. Tell me, Pod, have you ever been with a woman?
Answer: No, my lord.

Question: A fair enough repayment for putting your spear through my would-be killer's face, wouldn't you say?
Answer: Now, as it happens, Marei is quite the spear handler herself. She's here to thank you for staying by my side as the battle raged all around me.

Question: He's stealing it?
Answer: Worse, he's borrowing it.

Question: What's wrong with that?
Answer: We can't afford to pay it back, that's what's wrong with it. The crown owes millions to my father.

Question: Forgive a debt, my father? For a man of the world, you're strangely naive.
Answer: I've never borrowed money before. I'm not clear on the rules.

Question: And what if I don't?
Answer: Well, you have to.

Question: But what if I don't?
Answer: This is why I don't lend you money. Anyway, it's not my father I'm worried about. It's the Iron Bank of Braavos. We owe them tens of millions. If we fail to repay these loans, the bank will fund our enemies. One way or another, they always get their gold back.

Question: Ah, the return of the conquering hero. Does he have a little jaunt in his step?
Answer: The lado s practically skipping.

Question: You were gone a long time. I trust you got your money's worth. Or should I say my money's worth?
Answer: Oh, it was a gift, Podrick. This is more than I give you in a year.

Question: Have you ever known a whore to turn down gold? They were happy enough to take it when I gave it to them.
Answer: What did you tell them?

Question: What did you tell them?
Answer: I didn't tell them anything.

Question: What did you do to them?
Answer: Lots of things.

Question: And they seemed to like these things?
Answer: Of course they seemed to like it. They're paid to seem to like it.

Question: What are you saying? These ladies enjoyed him so much, they gave him the time for free?
Answer: Is that what you're telling us?

Question: Is that what you're telling us?
Answer: doesn't deny it.>/i>

Question: You know how we deal with runaways here, do you?
Answer: Take off his pants.

Question: You know who she is, don't you?
Answer: A big dumb bitch from who cares where. Never been with a woman that big.

Question: She's Brienne of Tarth. Her father is Lord Selwyn Tarth. Heard of Tarth?
Answer: I'm gonna cut your throat!

Question: They call it the Sapphire Isle. Do you know why? Every sapphire in Westeros was mined on Tarth. Sapphires are gemstones. The blue ones.
Answer: I know what they are.

Question: Your father, he'd pay your weight in gold to get you back?
Answer: You'll be a rich man till the end of your days. And your sons will be rich men and their sons after them. Lands, titles- you'll have them all. The North can't win this war. You're a smart man. You understand that. We have the numbers. We have the gold.

Question: Bring the bird over here and the carving knife. Will this work as a table, my lord?
Answer: Oh, yes. Yes, this will do nic- ah!

Question: Have you got something to say?
Answer: Careful. You don't want to say the wrong thing. You're nothing without your daddy, and your daddy ain't here. Never forget that.

Question: How many of those fingers do you think we could shove up his ass?
Answer: Depends if he's had any practice. Is that the sort of thing you and your sister go in for, Kingslayer? She loosened you up for us?

Question: Depends if he's had any practice. Is that the sort of thing you and your sister go in for, Kingslayer? She loosened you up for us?
Answer: He's going to fall. He's going to fall off his horse. Someone help him.

Question: About the events of the Blackwater. Perhaps this is the wrong time?
Answer: Oh, no. It's a wonderful time.

Question: End your life?
Answer: I didn't inherit Littlefinger's spies along with his position, I'm afraid. Which is why I'm coming to you. I need proof.

Question: Proof? Will there be a trial?
Answer: I need to know.

Question: I have no proof, only whispers. Before all this nastiness, I was going to tell you the story of how I was cut. Do you want to hear it still?
Answer: I don't know. Do I?

Question: I don't know. Do I?
Answer: As a boy, I traveled with a troupe of actors through the Free Cities. One day in Myr, a certain man made my master an offer too tempting to refuse. I feared the man meant to use me as I'd heard some men used small boys. But what he wanted was far worse. He gave me a potion that made me powerless to move or speak, yet did nothing to dull my senses. With a hooked blade he sliced me, root and stem, chanting all the while. He burned my parts in a brazier. The flames turned blue and I heard a voice answer his call. I still dream of that night. Not of the sorcerer, not of his blade. I dream of the voice from the flames. Was it a god? A demon? A conjurer's trick? I don't know. But the sorcerer called and a voice answered. And ever since that day, I have hated magic and all those who practice it. But you can see why I was eager to aid in your fight against Stannis and his Red Priestess. A symbolic revenge of sorts.

Question: As a boy, I traveled with a troupe of actors through the Free Cities. One day in Myr, a certain man made my master an offer too tempting to refuse. I feared the man meant to use me as I'd heard some men used small boys. But what he wanted was far worse. He gave me a potion that made me powerless to move or speak, yet did nothing to dull my senses. With a hooked blade he sliced me, root and stem, chanting all the while. He burned my parts in a brazier. The flames turned blue and I heard a voice answer his call. I still dream of that night. Not of the sorcerer, not of his blade. I dream of the voice from the flames. Was it a god? A demon? A conjurer's trick? I don't know. But the sorcerer called and a voice answered. And ever since that day, I have hated magic and all those who practice it. But you can see why I was eager to aid in your fight against Stannis and his Red Priestess. A symbolic revenge of sorts.
Answer: Yes, ahem. I feel the need for actual revenge against the actual person who tried to have me killed. Which will require a degree of influence, which-

Question: The Lord Commander told us to go to the Fist of the First Men. How'd that turn out for us?
Answer: He had no way of knowing.

Question: So he's your new protector now? Our good friend Craster?
Answer: We're like the sons he never had.

Question: He's beautiful. Does he have a name?
Answer: No.

Question: Are you going to give him one?
Answer: Why?

Question: Why?
Answer: Here.

Question: I don't want your stupid thimble. I want to save my baby's life. Can you do that? Can you?
Answer: I don't have time for you. I don't have time for anyone but him because he doesn't have much time.

Question: How?
Answer: You know how.

Question: How many times have I told you? No climbing.
Answer: Mother, I need to find it. It's here. It's calling me.

Question: Is he very large?
Answer: No larger than usual, apparently. And yet they said that he was-

Question: We're talking about the same Podrick? The quiet boy in Lord Tyrion's service? Seems a bit simple?
Answer: What did he do to them?

Question: What did he do to them?
Answer: I don't know, my lord. The girls are usually quite descriptive.

Question: So what did they say?
Answer: They said it was hard to describe.

Question: Huh. Prodigies appear in the oddest of places. And what did Littlefinger say about this loss of income?
Answer: He was too preoccupied to notice. He's leaving for the Eyrie soon. I'm helping him prepare for his journey.

Question: Ah, yes, to pursue his enduring love of the Lady Arryn and the title that comes with her. Sad, really. Is that all it takes to make our friend lose interest in poor Sansa Stark?
Answer: He hasn't spoken to her since the last time, as far as I know. But I don't think he's lost interest.

Question: What makes you say so?
Answer: His shipboard inventory.

Question: Of course. I'm missing something obvious you're about to point out?
Answer: Two featherbeds. He's bringing two featherbeds for the cabin.

Question: Who is important enough to Littlefinger to merit a featherbed besides Littlefinger? Could he be bringing one of his girls?
Answer: He's not interested in them, my lord.

Question: How do you know?
Answer: Because I'm one of his girls.

Question: What is this place?
Answer: Somewhere neither wolves nor lions come prowling.

Question: You're still swineherds and tanners and masons. You think carrying a crooked spear makes you a soldier?
Answer: No. Fighting in a war makes you a soldier.

Question: Beric Dondarrion? You've seen better days.
Answer: And I won't see them again.

Question: Last I heard, you were King Joffrey's guard dog. But here you are a thousand miles from home. Which of us is running?
Answer: Untie these ropes and we'll find out. What are you doing leading a mob of peasants?

Question: Untie these ropes and we'll find out. What are you doing leading a mob of peasants?
Answer: Ned Stark ordered me to execute your brother in King Robert's name.

Question: You found god? Is that it?
Answer: Aye. I've been reborn in the light of the one true god. As have we all. As would any man who's seen the things we've seen.

Question: Do you take me for my brother? Is being born Clegane a crime?
Answer: Murder is a crime.

Question: You don't deny killing this boy?
Answer: I was Joffrey's sworn shield. The boy attacked the prince.

Question: So, who will it be? Should we find out if your fire god really loves you, priest? Or you, archer? What are you worth with a sword in your hand? Or is the little girl the bravest one here?
Answer: Aye. She might be. But it's me you'll fight.

Question: And who knows? In ten years, some of the boys you send them may be Unsullied in their turn. Thus all shall prosper.
Answer: Is it done, then? They belong to me?

Question: Is it done, then? They belong to me?
Answer: It is done.

Question: You speak Valyrian?
Answer: I am Daenerys Stormborn of the House Targaryen, of the blood of Old Valyria. Valyrian is my mother tongue.

Question: Unsullied! You have been slaves all your life. Today you are free. Any man who wishes to leave may leave, and no one will harm him. I give you my word. Will you fight for me? As free men?
Answer: Lord, cast your light upon us.

Question: How often do these patrols go out?
Answer: It varies. If I knew where on the Wall we were heading, I could tell you.

Question: There are nineteen castles guarding the Wall. How many are manned?
Answer: Three.

Question: You sure of that?
Answer: Which three?

Question: Which three?
Answer: Castle Black.

Question: Aye, Castle Black. Everyone knows Castle Black. Which others?
Answer: Eastwatch-by-the-Sea and the Shadow Tower.

Question: How many men remain in Castle Black?
Answer: A thousand.

Question: What happens to your eagle after I kill you? Does he drift away like a kite with his strings cut or does he just flop dead to the ground?
Answer: He's no crow.

Question: Of course you do. Who stopped Rattleshirt when he was about to cut your throat? Who vouched for you with Mance? It seems you owe me a debt.
Answer: Give it back.

Question: Is Orell right? Are you still a crow? It's time you proved yourself.
Answer: Ygritte.

Question: Why are you still dressed? You know nothing, Jon Sno-
Answer: That thing you did with your mouth- is that what lords do to their ladies in the South?

Question: That thing you did with your mouth- is that what lords do to their ladies in the South?
Answer: I don't know. I just wanted to kiss you there is all.

Question: Aye, I liked it some. Who taught you that?
Answer: There's been no one else. Only you.

Question: I was a man of the Night's Watch. How about you? Were you a maid?
Answer: What do you think?

Question: What do you think?
Answer: Who was he?

Question: Who was he?
Answer: Just a boy. He came trading with his brothers. He had red hair like me. Kissed by fire. But he was weak. Not like you. That was the first one. Then there was this Thenn boy. Spoke no Common, but gods, he was built like a mammoth.

Question: How long's it been since you had a bath?
Answer: Let's not go back. Let's stay here a while longer. I don't ever want to leave this cave, Jon Snow. Not ever.

Question: Send it to his father?
Answer: You'll hold your tongue unless you want to lose it.

Question: Is there word from the capital?
Answer: You haven't heard? Stannis Baratheon laid siege to King's Landing. Sailed into Blackwater Bay. Stormed the gates with thousands of men. And your sister How can I put this? Your sister is alive and well. Your father's forces prevailed.

Question: You haven't heard? Stannis Baratheon laid siege to King's Landing. Sailed into Blackwater Bay. Stormed the gates with thousands of men. And your sister How can I put this? Your sister is alive and well. Your father's forces prevailed.
Answer: Ser Jaime isn't well. Take him to Qyburn.

Question: Will I die?
Answer: No. The corruption has spread. I fear it must be cut away. The safest course would be to take the whole arm off.

Question: Then you'll die. You're no maester. Where's your chain?
Answer: The Citadel stripped me of it. They found some of my experiments too bold. I can leave your upper arm, make the cut at your elbow.

Question: I see. And have you shared these suspicions with Lord Tywin?
Answer: My father's a practical man. He appreciates facts.

Question: Thank you. And your best will prove better than when I asked you to locate Arya Stark?
Answer: I assure you that it will.

Question: No need to speak. Are there any figs? Fetch some. I always take figs midafternoon. They help move the bowels. To what do I owe this summons?
Answer: Thank you for seeing me, my lady. I had hoped we might discuss a few financial matters.

Question: I climbed all those steps to discuss financial matters?
Answer: It's the royal wedding. I'm told you had a hand in planning it.

Question: What good is the word extravagant if it can't be used to describe a royal wedding?
Answer: I understand that.

Question: And?
Answer: And we're at war, Lady Olenna.

Question: I can't think how it slipped my mind. What is it, twelve thousand infantrymen the Tyrell family has supplied? Two thousand in support. Provisions so this city might survive the winter. A million bushels of wheat. Half a million bushels each of barley, oats, and rye. Twenty thousand head of cattle. Fifty thousand sheep. You don't have to lecture me about wartime expenses. I'm quite familiar with them.
Answer: And we are so grateful for your contributions which are necessary for the preservation of the realm.

Question: As is a royal wedding. The people are hungry for more than just food. They crave distractions. And if we don't provide them, they'll create their own. And their distractions are likely to end with us being torn to pieces. A royal wedding is much safer. Wouldn't you say?
Answer: I would.

Question: I was told you were drunk, impertinent, and thoroughly debauched. You can imagine my disappointment at finding nothing but a browbeaten bookkeeper. Where did you go for them, Volantis?
Answer: My lady-

Question: Oh, very well. I won't have it said that House Tyrell refuses to play its part. We'll pay for half the expenses and the celebrations will go on as planned. Is that sufficient?
Answer: Quite sufficient. Thank you.

Question: What are you doing?
Answer: Just mending Lord Beric's armor.

Question: Why?
Answer: I'm going to stay on and smith for the Brotherhood.

Question: Have you lost your mind? When the Lannisters find this place, you think they'll spare the smiths? They'll cave your head in with your own helmet.
Answer: The Lannisters wanted to kill me long before I joined the Brotherhood.

Question: What? Serve him? I've served men my entire life. I served Master Mott at King's Landing and he sold me to the Watch. I served Lord Tywin at Harrenhal, wondering every day if I'd get tortured or killed. I'm done serving.
Answer: You just said you were serving Lord Beric.

Question: Is this a rescue?
Answer: Lannister filth! Take him!

Question: Is that all of them? It took five of you to murder two unarmed squires?
Answer: Not murder, Your Grace. Vengeance.

Question: Vengeance? Those boys didn't kill your sons. I saw Harrion die on the battlefield and Torrhen-
Answer: Was strangled by the Kingslayer. They were his kin.

Question: It's treason to free your enemies. In war, you kill your enemies. Did your father not teach you that, boy?
Answer: Leave him.

Question: Aye. Leave me to the king. He wants to give me a scolding before he sets me free. That's how he deals with treason. Our King in the North. Or should I call him the King Who Lost the North?
Answer: Escort Lord Karstark to the dungeon. Hang the rest.

Question: Would you make me a liar as well as a murderer?
Answer: It wouldn't be lying. We will bury them and remain silent until the war is done.

Question: Rickard Karstark, Lord of Karhold, here in sight of gods and men, I sentence you to die. Would you speak a final word?
Answer: Kill me and be cursed. You are no king of mine.

Question: Joffrey. Cersei. Ilyn Payne. Ser Meryn. The Hound. What are you going to do with me?
Answer: At first light we'll ride for Riverrun. Your brother's there now. He'll make a contribution to our cause and you can go home.

Question: So why don't you?
Answer: We need the gold.

Question: Do I frighten you, child?
Answer: No.

Question: But how?
Answer: Thoros how many times have you brought me back?

Question: Thoros how many times have you brought me back?
Answer: It's the Lord of Light brings you back. I'm just the lucky drunk who says the words.

Question: How many times?
Answer: Five, I think. No, this makes six.

Question: Then the Lannisters caught me and executed me for treason. Was it a hanging or a dagger in the eye?
Answer: Both. Fuckers couldn't decide.

Question: Could you bring back a man without a head? Not six times. Just once.
Answer: I don't think it works that way, child.

Question: So you've come to see her as well? There is no need. You must keep away from such distractions.
Answer: She's my daughter. I want to see her.

Question: Mother said you fought in a battle. Did you win?
Answer: No.

Question: Did the Onion Knight come back with you?
Answer: He did. He fought bravely.

Question: Why not? He's my friend. Look.
Answer: He made this for me. But don't tell Mother I have it. It's a secret. Mother doesn't like the Onion Knight.

Question: What are you doing here?
Answer: I need a bath. Help me out of these rags.

Question: Why should I care how you die?
Answer: You swore a solemn vow, remember? You're supposed to get me to King's Landing in one piece. Not going so well, is it? No wonder Renly died with you guarding him.

Question: You swore a solemn vow, remember? You're supposed to get me to King's Landing in one piece. Not going so well, is it? No wonder Renly died with you guarding him.
Answer: That was unworthy. Forgive me. You protected me better than most-

Question: There it is. There's the look. I've seen it for seventeen years on face after face. You all despise me. Kingslayer. Oathbreaker. A man without honor. You've heard of wildfire?
Answer: Of course.

Question: The Mad King was obsessed with it. He loved to watch people burn, the way their skin blackened and blistered and melted off their bones. He burned lords he didn't like. He burned Hands who disobeyed him. He burned anyone who was against him. Before long, half the country was against him. Aerys saw traitors everywhere. So he had his pyromancer place caches of wildfire all over the city- beneath the Sept of Baelor and the slums of Flea Bottom. Under houses, stables, taverns. Even beneath the Red Keep itself. Finally, the day of reckoning came. Robert Baratheon marched on the capital after his victory at the Trident. But my father arrived first with the whole Lannister army at his back, promising to defend the city against the rebels. I knew my father better than that. He's never been one to pick the losing side. I told the Mad King as much. I urged him to surrender peacefully. But the king didn't listen to me. He didn't listen to Varys who tried to warn him. But he did listen to Grand Maester Pycelle, that grey, sunken cunt. 'You can trust the Lannisters,' he said. 'The Lannisters have always been true friends of the crown.' So we opened the gates and my father sacked the city. Once again, I came to the king, begging him to surrender. He told me to bring him my father's head. Then he turned to his pyromancer. 'Burn them all,' he said. 'Burn them in their homes. Burn them in their beds.' Tell me, if your precious Renly commanded you to kill your own father and stand by while thousands of men, women, and children burned alive, would you have done it? Would you have kept your oath then?
Answer: First, I killed the pyromancer. And then when the king turned to flee, I drove my sword into his back. 'Burn them all,' he kept saying. 'Burn them all.' I don't think he expected to die. He- he meant to burn with the rest of us and rise again, reborn as a dragon to turn his enemies to ash. I slit his throat to make sure that didn't happen. That's where Ned Stark found me.

Question: If this is true why didn't you tell anyone? Why didn't you tell Lord Stark?
Answer: Stark? You think the honorable Ned Stark wanted to hear my side? He judged me guilty the moment he set eyes on me. By what right does the wolf judge the lion? By what right?

Question: Stark? You think the honorable Ned Stark wanted to hear my side? He judged me guilty the moment he set eyes on me. By what right does the wolf judge the lion? By what right?
Answer: Help! Help! The Kingslayer!

Question: Princess? Gods, what are you doing here?
Answer: Shh, you'll wake Bert.

Question: Bert?
Answer: He's the fat one. He's on guard duty tonight. He likes to drink wine and sleep a lot.

Question: he said you Were a traitor. Are you?
Answer: I am, child. I disobeyed my king, your father, and now I'm paying the price.

Question: I don't care. You're my friend. You must get bored down here. I brought you something to read. It's about Aegon and his dragons. Aegon used to live here. Did you know that? And the Targaryens built this castle.
Answer: Aye. So they did.

Question: You can't?
Answer: I'll teach you. I'll come when Bert's on duty and teach you.

Question: Why not? What will they do, lock us in cells?
Answer: I wouldn't know where to start.

Question: Mm, you were first through the breach at Pyke?
Answer: The second. Thoros of Myr went in alone, waving that flaming sword of his.

Question: Thoros of Myr. Bloody madman. Robert knighted you after the battle?
Answer: Proudest moment of my life. One knee in the dust, the king's sword on my shoulder, listening to the words. 'In the name of the Warrior, I charge you to be brave.' All I could think of was how badly I had to piss.

Question: Yes. And a man of honor keeps his vows, even if he's serving a drunk or a lunatic. Just once in my life before it's over, I want to know what it's like to serve with pride, to fight for someone I believe in. Do you believe in her?
Answer: With all my heart.

Question: These are the ones?
Answer: Yes, khaleesi. The officers.

Question: You did not choose this life. But you are free men now. And free men make their own choices. Have you selected your own leader from amongst your ranks?
Answer: Remove your helmet

Question: What is your name?
Answer: Grey Worm.

Question: No? Doesn't the Lord of the Kingsguard traditionally-
Answer: Traditionally, yes, but I killed a dozen of Robert's friends during his rebellion.

Question: Which men do you have in mind?
Answer: Forgive me, Ser Jorah, for what I'm about to say, but your reputation in Westeros has suffered over the years.

Question: Our cause? Forgive me, Ser Barristan, but I was busy defending the khaleesi against King Robert's assassins while you were still bowing to the man.
Answer: We both want her to rule. Am I wrong?

Question: We both want her to rule. Am I wrong?
Answer: You only joined us a few days ago. I can't speak to your intentions.

Question: What can I do? Attack King's Landing? There's nothing he'd like better. He'd crush us in a day.
Answer: We could ride north. Take your land back from the Greyjoys. Wait out the winter.

Question: What?
Answer: Oh, I don't know. I don't even know where Winterfell is.

Question: What is it?
Answer: I can't force them to meet us in the field and I can't attack them where they're strongest, but I can attack them where they're not.

Question: Can you do it?
Answer: I need men to replace the Karstarks who marched home. There is only one person in this kingdom with that kind of army who hasn't already sided with the Lannisters. The man whose daughter I was supposed to marry- Walder Frey.

Question: How did you know?
Answer: Know what?

Question: Know what?
Answer: That I wanted to.

Question: You have a good deal of experience, do you?
Answer: With the husbands.

Question: Is he? And who's the lucky girl?
Answer: She may not be the grandest ship in the world or the fastest, but she's mine. I've always wanted a ship. Now I want a dozen. Strange, isn't it?

Question: She may not be the grandest ship in the world or the fastest, but she's mine. I've always wanted a ship. Now I want a dozen. Strange, isn't it?
Answer: What is?

Question: What is?
Answer: It doesn't matter what we want, once we get it, then we want something else. Your hair is different.

Question: Is it?
Answer: Lady Margaery wears it that way.

Question: You still want me to come with you?
Answer: It's not a question of what I want. It's what you want. You want to go home, don't you?

Question: It's not a question of what I want. It's what you want. You want to go home, don't you?
Answer: Of course. More than anything. But maybe it would be better to wait. I've been thinking how dangerous it would be. Not just for me, but for you. You've been so kind. I'd feel terrible if anything happened to you. I can't tell you how touched I am by your concern for my welfare.

Question: What's she doing here?
Answer: Our business concerns her, too. Sit.

Question: Sansa is the key to the North? I seem to remember she has an older brother.
Answer: The Karstarks have marched home. The young wolf has lost half his army. His days are numbered. Theon Greyjoy murdered both his brothers. That makes Sansa Stark the heir to Winterfell. And I am not about to hand her over to the Tyrells.

Question: The Tyrell army is helping us to win this war. Do you really think it's wise to refuse them?
Answer: There's nothing to refuse. This is a plot. Plots are not public knowledge. And the Tyrells won't carry this one out until after Joffrey's wedding. We need to act first and kill this union in its crib.

Question: And how do we do that?
Answer: We find Sansa Stark a different husband.

Question: Joffrey has made this poor girl's life miserable since the day he took her father's head. Now she's finally free of him and you give her to me? That's cruel even for you.
Answer: Do you intend on mistreating her? The girl's happiness is not my concern, nor should it be yours.

Question: Do you intend on mistreating her? The girl's happiness is not my concern, nor should it be yours.
Answer: She's a child!

Question: There, you see? You will wed her, bed her, and put a child in her. Surely you're capable of that.
Answer: And if I refuse?

Question: And if I refuse?
Answer: You wanted to be rewarded for your valor in battle. Sansa Stark is a finer reward than you could ever dare hope for. And it is past time you were wed.

Question: I was wed. Or don't you remember?
Answer: Only too well.

Question: What do you mean?
Answer: You'll marry Ser Loras.

Question: Someone built your fires for you growing up?
Answer: It doesn't get so cold down in the Reach. And there were servants, of course.

Question: What does it do?
Answer: I'm not sure that it does anything. It's beautiful, though, isn't it?

Question: I'm not sure that it does anything. It's beautiful, though, isn't it?
Answer: How much longer?

Question: How much longer?
Answer: Not so far. A few more days.

Question: Is the Wall as big as they say?
Answer: Bigger. So big you can't even see the top sometimes. It's hidden in clouds.

Question: Do you sing?
Answer: No. No, no, no. Not very well.

Question: Oh, you're gonna punch the rabbits to death?
Answer: I had someone else in mind.

Question: Well, some of us would say thank you when someone else hunts down their breakfast for them. Or don't they teach you to say thank you north of the Wall?
Answer: You've got a big mouth, girl, and too many teeth.

Question: Me? It's my fault? First time I met her, she put a knife to my throat.
Answer: First time I met you, you held a knife at me. We can't fight each other. We'll never make it to the Wall. I want you both to make peace.

Question: I said so, didn't I?
Answer: Osha!

Question: Thank you. See? Not so hard, is it? Thank you.
Answer: Don't push me.

Question: What's happening?
Answer: I'm right here with you.

Question: What's wrong with him?
Answer: The visions take their toll.

Question: He's having one now?
Answer: I saw Jon Snow.

Question: You saw him? At Castle Black?
Answer: He was on the wrong side of the Wall surrounded by enemies.

Question: You ever climbed it before?
Answer: No. But Tormundo s done it half a hundred times. You're afraid.

Question: Aren't you?
Answer: Aye. It's a long way up and a long way down. But I've waited my whole life to see the world from up there. Here, sit down.

Question: You kill someone for them?
Answer: Nah. I didn't kill him, but I bet his balls are still bruised.

Question: Can we not talk about that here?
Answer: Can we not talk about that here? I'm Jon Snow. I've killed dead men and Qhorin Halfhand, but I'm scared of naked girls.

Question: Can we not talk about that here? I'm Jon Snow. I've killed dead men and Qhorin Halfhand, but I'm scared of naked girls.
Answer: Did I seem scared the other day?

Question: Did I seem scared the other day?
Answer: You were trembling like a leaf.

Question: What secret?
Answer: Do you think I'm as dumb as all those girls in silk dresses you knew growing up? You're loyal and you're brave. You didn't stop being a crow the day you walked into Mance Rayder's tent.

Question: Do you think I'm as dumb as all those girls in silk dresses you knew growing up? You're loyal and you're brave. You didn't stop being a crow the day you walked into Mance Rayder's tent.
Answer: But I'm your woman now, Jon Snow. You're going to be loyal to your woman. The Night's Watch don't care if you live or die. Mance Rayder don't care if I live or die. We're just soldiers in their armies and there's plenty more to carry on if we go down.

Question: What?
Answer: Your muscles tense up when you hold. Pull the string back to the center of your chin and release. Never hold.

Question: Never aim?
Answer: Your eye knows where it wants the arrow to go. Trust your eye.

Question: The High Priest gave you a mission. Turn King Robert away from his idols and towards the Lord of Light. What happened?
Answer: I failed.

Question: You worship Him in your way, and I'll worship Him in mine. Do you speak the common tongue?
Answer: My friends here don't speak High Valyrian. Why are you here, my lady?

Question: My friends here don't speak High Valyrian. Why are you here, my lady?
Answer: Forgive my manners. I don't see many ladies these days.

Question: How many times has the Lord brought him back?
Answer: Six.

Question: The other side? There is no other side. I have been to the darkness, my lady. He sent you to us for a reason.
Answer: You have someone He needs.

Question: Bodkin point. Penetrates plate at two hundred yards. Can you make 'em?
Answer: Yeah, nothing tricky about it. Just need decent steel.

Question: What does that have to do with anything?
Answer: Forgive me, lad.

Question: What are you doing? Let go of him.
Answer: Tell them to stop. Come on. He wants to be one of you. He wants to join the Brotherhood. Stop them!

Question: Did the Lord of Light tell you that or did she?
Answer: You're not doing this for your god. You're doing it for gold.

Question: You staring at my ass, Jon Snow?
Answer: Look out!

Question: You all right?
Answer: Just seeing if you can take a hit, lad.

Question: Sorry. Were you sleeping?
Answer: Wa-

Question: Wa-? Wa-? Water? You want some water. I wish I had some for you.
Answer: So let's play a game. Which body part do you need the least?

Question: So let's play a game. Which body part do you need the least?
Answer: Please.

Question: But you've already told me everything. Remember? Your daddy was mean to you. The Starks didn't appreciate you. One good bit, though. The Stark boys, they're still alive. Wouldn't that be a hunt to remember? You failed, but I'm a better hunter than you.
Answer: Now how about your little finger? You don't use that for much, do you? No? Good. Let's start with that.

Question: Now how about your little finger? You don't use that for much, do you? No? Good. Let's start with that.
Answer: You've been wondering why you're here. Haven't you? Where you are. Who I am. Why I'm doing this to you. So guess. If you guess right, I'll tell you. By the old gods and the new, I swear it. You win the game if you can figure out who I am and why I'm torturing you and I win the game if you beg me to cut off your finger.

Question: You've been wondering why you're here. Haven't you? Where you are. Who I am. Why I'm doing this to you. So guess. If you guess right, I'll tell you. By the old gods and the new, I swear it. You win the game if you can figure out who I am and why I'm torturing you and I win the game if you beg me to cut off your finger.
Answer: If I win, you'll let me go?

Question: If I win, you'll let me go?
Answer: If you think this has a happy ending, you haven't been paying attention.

Question: You say please again and you'll wish you hadn't. You first. Where are we?
Answer: The North.

Question: Now, where?
Answer: Last Hearth.

Question: Do I look like a fucking Umber to you?
Answer: Karhold!

Question: Karhold? How did you know that? Did you see any banners flying when we came in?
Answer: No. It was just a guess.

Question: Very good, Lord Theon. And who am I?
Answer: Torrhen Karstark.

Question: What?
Answer: No.

Question: How old is she?
Answer: Nineteen.

Question: Could I see her first?
Answer: You want to count her teeth? We depart for the Twins in the morning. We need an answer before we leave and a wedding not more than a fortnight thereafter or this alliance is at an end.

Question: You want to count her teeth? We depart for the Twins in the morning. We need an answer before we leave and a wedding not more than a fortnight thereafter or this alliance is at an end.
Answer: Your father does realize we're in the middle of a war?

Question: Your father does realize we're in the middle of a war?
Answer: Father is old. It will put his heart at peace if he could see her wed to a good husband.

Question: Why should I let that old ferret choose my bride for me? At the very least, I should be offered the same choice you were. I'm his liege lord.
Answer: He's a proud man and we've wounded him.

Question: You're willing to risk our freedom and our lives for a chance at a prettier wife?
Answer: I have a war to fight. We can't win it without them. I have no time to haggle. You said you wanted to make amends for the Stone Mill.

Question: You recall that heroic engagement?
Answer: I had something less permanent in mind.
