Answer: Of course. Of course. En-enjoy.

Question: Rather less than I plan to be. Isn't it a man's duty to be drunk at his own wedding?
Answer: This isn't about your wedding. Renly Baratheon had a wedding. Your wife needs a child, a Lannister child, as soon as possible.

Question: And?
Answer: If you're going to give her one, you need to perform.

Question: What did you once call me? A drunken little lust-filled beast.
Answer: More than once.

Question: Well, you've done it. You've married a Lannister. Soon you'll have a Lannister baby. It's a dream come true for you, isn't it? What a glorious day.
Answer: Yes, Your Grace.

Question: I suppose it doesn't really matter which Lannister puts the baby into you. Maybe I'll pay you a visit tonight after my uncle passes out. How'd you like that?
Answer: You wouldn't? That's all right. Ser Meryn and Ser Boros will hold you down.

Question: You wouldn't? That's all right. Ser Meryn and Ser Boros will hold you down.
Answer: Time for the bedding ceremony.

Question: Where's your respect for tradition, Uncle? Come, everyone. Pick her up and carry her to her wedding bed. Get rid of her gown. She won't be needing it any longer. Ladies, attend to my uncle. He's not heavy.
Answer: There will be if I command it.

Question: What did you say? What did you say?
Answer: I believe we can dispense with the bedding, Your Grace. I'm sure Tyrion did not mean to threaten the king.

Question: I vomited on a girl once in the middle of the act. Not proud of it. But I think honesty is important between a man and wife, don't you agree? Come, I'll tell you all about it. Put you in the mood.
Answer: Is that wise, my lord?

Question: Is that wise, my lord?
Answer: Tyrion, Sansa. My name is Tyrion.

Question: Is that wise, Tyrion?
Answer: Nothing was ever wiser.

Question: What?
Answer: Neck. You have one. How old are you exactly?

Question: Neck. You have one. How old are you exactly?
Answer: Fourteen.

Question: What if I never want you to?
Answer: And so my watch begins.

Question: How can anyone speak nineteen languages?
Answer: It only took Your Grace a year to learn Dothraki reasonably well.

Question: Yes, well, it was either learn Dothraki or grunt at my husband and hope- what do you mean reasonably well?
Answer: Dothraki is difficult for the mouth to master. So guttural and harsh.

Question: What do you want?
Answer: You.

Question: You were sent here to kill me?
Answer: So why haven't you?

Question: So why haven't you?
Answer: I don't want to.

Question: What do your captains have to say about that?
Answer: You should ask them.

Question: Why?
Answer: We had philosophical differences.

Question: Over what?
Answer: Your beauty. It meant more to me than it did to them.

Question: And this is supposed to impress me?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Why would I trust a man who murders his comrades?
Answer: They ordered me to murder you. I told them I preferred not to. They told me I had no choice. I told them I am Daario Naharis. I always have a choice. They drew their swords and I drew mine.

Question: Will you fight for me?
Answer: Swear to me.

Question: How hard can it be to build a fire?
Answer: It doesn't matter. Come under the furs. We can keep each other warm.

Question: A what?
Answer: Well, I mean, there's no real difference.

Question: You thought of a name yet? It would be easier to refer to him if he had a name.
Answer: Sometimes do you talk fancy on purpose to confuse me?

Question: Sometimes do you talk fancy on purpose to confuse me?
Answer: What? No. This is just the way I talk.

Question: What? No. This is just the way I talk.
Answer: I'll build that fire.

Question: Don't you think he should have a name?
Answer: I don't know many boys' names.

Question: Why is it a last name?
Answer: Well, it's a family name. For instance, I'm Samwell Tarly. Samwell is my birth name and Tarly is my family name. You see? So my father is also a Tarly.

Question: Well, it's a family name. For instance, I'm Samwell Tarly. Samwell is my birth name and Tarly is my family name. You see? So my father is also a Tarly.
Answer: His name is Samwell Tarly, too?

Question: His name is Samwell Tarly, too?
Answer: No, Randyll Tarly.

Question: Is your father cruel like mine?
Answer: Different manner of cruel.

Question: Are you sure about this?
Answer: No.

Question: Why are you telling me?
Answer: You begged me not to send Theon to negotiate with his father and I ignored your advice.

Question: So, Casterly Rock? I'm asking your advice.
Answer: We have enough men?

Question: We have enough men?
Answer: If Walder Frey cooperates.

Question: My granddaughter Marianne. My granddaughter Freya. My granddaughter...W-W-Wertha? Waldra? Waldina?
Answer: I'm Merry.

Question: Love. That's what the Starks of Winterfell call it, eh? Heh. Very honorable, I call it a pretty face. Mmmm, very pretty. Prettier than this lot, that's for sure. Very shapely as well. Oh, you try to hide her under that dress. If you wanted to hide her, you shouldn't have brought her here in the first place.
Answer: I can always see what's going on beneath a dress. Been at this a long time. I bet when you take that dress off, everything stays right where it is. Doesn't drop an inch.

Question: Where?
Answer: There.

Question: Your men but not you?
Answer: I have no interest in slaves. A man cannot make love to property.

Question: You command the Unsullied. What do you think?
Answer: Lo jention mirre nūmāzme ēza, iderenna qopsa verdagon issa.

Question: How do you know all that?
Answer: I read about it in a very old book.

Question: You know all that from staring at marks on paper?
Answer: Yes.

Question: The roads have gone right to hell, haven't they? Cracked three spokes this morning.
Answer: Need a hand?

Question: Need a hand?
Answer: Need about eight hands.

Question: You're so dangerous, aren't you? Saying scary things to little girls. Killing little boys and old people. A real hard man you are.
Answer: More than anyone you know.

Question: That so?
Answer: You'd be like a kitten to him. He'd kill you with his little finger.

Question: That him?
Answer: No.

Question: Where are we?
Answer: The Gift, I think. Brandon The Builder gave all this land south of the Wall to the Night's Watch for their sustenance and support. Maester Luwin taught me that.

Question: It's good land and there's no war up here. Why leave?
Answer: Wildlings.

Question: What's one old man doing with eight horses?
Answer: He breeds them for the Watch.

Question: How's he keep folks from stealing them?
Answer: The Watch protects him.

Question: That give you some ideas?
Answer: Might do.

Question: How are we going to get past the Wall? My uncle said it's 700 feet high.
Answer: How did you get past it?

Question: How did you get past it?
Answer: Got in a boat and rowed past the Bay of Seals.

Question: Just one?
Answer: There's more.

Question: Where's Shaggydog and Summer?
Answer: Hunting.

Question: What did you do?
Answer: Nothing. I don't know.

Question: What's That?
Answer: That's a horse dying.

Question: Where you riding?
Answer: Doesn't matter now, does it?

Question: Doesn't matter now, does it?
Answer: No, it doesn't matter now.

Question: Do you hear me?
Answer: You're not gonna die for one of them.

Question: That's what you call a few guards?
Answer: Lord Edmure, I hope I'm not a disappointment to you.

Question: Is that safe?
Answer: They're long gone.

Question: They can't do that north of the Wall?
Answer: No one can do that. Anywhere.

Question: Where?
Answer: He was with the wildlings. They tried to kill him but he got away.

Question: Me? I'm coming with you.
Answer: No. You and Osha and Shaggydog head for the Last Hearth. The Umbers are our bannermen. They'll protect you.

Question: Will you know how to find the last Hearth?
Answer: You Southerners build your big castles and you never move. You're easy to find.

Question: You're leaving now? It's the middle of the night.
Answer: I learned to walk in darkness.

Question: We've been waiting a long time. Haven't we? Well I don't know, you tell me. How long does it take to sack a city?
Answer: It was just as you said. They did not believe until it was too late. Their slave soldiers threw down their spears and surrendered.

Question: And Daario Naharis?
Answer: The city is yours, my queen.

Question: They're good, aren't they?
Answer: They ought to be because they cost enough.

Question: What? He's my nephew, I love him. And he's a damned fool.
Answer: Don't you drink, Lord Bolton?

Question: Don't you drink, Lord Bolton?
Answer: Never do, my lady. Dulls the senses.

Question: That's the point. Didn't you marry one of these Frey girls?
Answer: Aye. Lord Walder let me choose any of his granddaughters and promised me the girl's weight in silver as a dowry. So I have a fat, young bride.

Question: The Septon has prayed his prayers, some words were said and Lord Edmure has wrapped my daughter in a cloak. But they are not yet man and wife. A sword needs a sheath . And a wedding needs a bedding . What does my sire say?
Answer: To bed! To bed! To bed!

Question: It seems normal to you?
Answer: It's tradition. Without the bedding ceremony, there's no real proof the lord and lady consummated their marriage.

Question: Boy or girl?
Answer: I don't know. But if it's a boy, I know what we should name him.

Question: Oh, do you? It seems to me the father should have some say in his son's naming.
Answer: Eddard. Don't you want to teach little Ned Stark how to ride horses?

Question: Eddard. Don't you want to teach little Ned Stark how to ride horses?
Answer: I do.

Question: Where are you going?
Answer: Got salt pork for the feast.

Question: Are you soft in the head? Turn this cart around!
Answer: I feel I've been remiss in my duties.

Question: You ready to head home to Winterfell, eh?
Answer: Feast over yet, is it?

Question: Feast over yet, is it?
Answer: Aye, it's over!

Question: And why I would let him do that?
Answer: On my honor as a Tully, on my honor as a Stark, let him go or I will cut your wife's throat!

Question: What are you doing?
Answer: I have a list.

Question: A list of people you mean to kill?
Answer: For laughing at me? Do I look like Joffrey to you? No, death seems a bit extreme. Fear of death, on the other hand-

Question: For laughing at me? Do I look like Joffrey to you? No, death seems a bit extreme. Fear of death, on the other hand-
Answer: You should learn to ignore them.

Question: So how should we punish them?
Answer: Who? Whom?

Question: Who? Whom?
Answer: Ser Eldrick Sarsfield and Lord Desmond Crakehall.

Question: Why sheep shift?
Answer: That's the vulgar word for dung.

Question: Killed a few puppies today?
Answer: Show him. Come on, show him.

Question: Roslin caught a fine fat trout. Her brothers gave her a pair of wolf pelts for her wedding. Signed Walder Frey.' Is that bad poetry or is it supposed to mean something?
Answer: Robb Stark is dead. And his bitch mother. Write back to Lord Frey. Thank him for his service and command him to send Robb Stark's head. I'm going to serve it to Sansa at my wedding feast.

Question: Let him make his threats. Hmm? He's a bitter little man.
Answer: Lord Tyrion should apologize immediately. Unacceptable, disrespectful, and in very bad taste.

Question: You really think a crown gives you power?
Answer: No. I think armies give you power.

Question: Oh, I know. Walder Frey gets all the credit. Or the blame, I suppose, depending on your allegiance. Walder Frey is many things, but a brave man? No. He never would have risked such an action if he didn't have certain assurances.
Answer: Which he got from me. Do you disapprove?

Question: Which he got from me. Do you disapprove?
Answer: I'm all for cheating. This is war.

Question: So that's why you did it? To save lives?
Answer: To end the war. To protect the family. Do you want to write a song for the dead Starks? Go ahead, write one. I'm in this world a little while longer to defend the Lannisters, to defend my blood.

Question: To end the war. To protect the family. Do you want to write a song for the dead Starks? Go ahead, write one. I'm in this world a little while longer to defend the Lannisters, to defend my blood.
Answer: The Northerners will never forget.

Question: Do you think she'll open her legs for me after I tell her how we murdered her mother and brother?
Answer: One way or another, you will get that girl pregnant.

Question: Shall I explain to you in one easy lesson how the world works?
Answer: Use small words. I'm not as bright as you.

Question: Does that amuse you?
Answer: No, it's a very good lesson. Only it's easy for you to preach utter devotion to family when you're making all the decisions.

Question: Easy for me, is it?
Answer: When have you ever done something that wasn't in your interest but solely for the benefit of the family?

Question: When have you ever done something that wasn't in your interest but solely for the benefit of the family?
Answer: The day that you were born. I wanted to carry you into the sea and let the waves wash you away. Instead, I let you live. And I brought you as my son. Because you're a Lannister.

Question: You'd rather be out there?
Answer: There are a lot of stories about this place. Horrible stories.

Question: You ever heard about the Rat Cook?
Answer: No. Who's he?

Question: No. Who's he?
Answer: Just a cook in the Night's Watch. He was angry at the king for something, I don't remember. When the king was visiting the Nightfort, the cook killed the king's son, cooked him into a big pie with onions, carrots, mushrooms and bacon. That night he served the pie to the king. He liked the taste of his son so much, he asked for a second slice. The gods turned the cook into a giant white rat who could only eat his own young. He's been roaming the Nightfort ever since, devouring his own babies. But no matter what he does, he's always hungry.

Question: An old man on the run with no allies. I have Tywin Lannister backing me. Who does he have?
Answer: As you say.

Question: They all laughed at me, all those high lords. They all thought they were better than me. Ned Stark, Hoster Tully. People snigger when I marry a young girl, but who said a word when Jon Arryn married the little Tully bitch?
Answer: You'll be needing a new young girl.

Question: Calling himself the Young Wolf. How's that for pomposity?
Answer: Well, here's to the Young Wolf!

Question: Will you move to Winterfell now that the war's over?
Answer: At some point perhaps. But Winterfell's in ruins.

Question: Yeah. What happened up there? I heard the Greyjoy boy seized the place. I heard he killed all the ravens. And after that, nothing.
Answer: I sent my bastard Ramsay to root him out. Robb Stark offered amnesty for the Ironborn if they gave us Theon.

Question: Oh. And?
Answer: Ramsay delivered the terms. The Ironborn turned on Theon as we knew they would. They handed him over trussed and hooded. But Ramsay- well Ramsay has his own way of doing things.

Question: What? No. Pork sausage. You think I'm some sort of savage?
Answer: People talk about phantom limbs. An amputee might have an itch where his foot used to be. So I've always wondered do eunuchs have a phantom cock?

Question: People talk about phantom limbs. An amputee might have an itch where his foot used to be. So I've always wondered do eunuchs have a phantom cock?
Answer: Next time you think about naked girls, would you feel an itch?

Question: Next time you think about naked girls, would you feel an itch?
Answer: Sorry. I shouldn't make jokes. My mother taught me not to throw stones at cripples.

Question: Sorry, what?
Answer: A little louder.

Question: You don't look like a Theon Greyjoy anymore. That's a name for a lord. But you're not a lord, are you? You're just meat.
Answer: Stinking meat.

Question: You reek. Reek! That's a good name for you. What's your name?
Answer: Theon Greyjoy.

Question: What's your name?
Answer: Th- Theon Greyjoy.

Question: What is your name?!
Answer: Reek. My name is Reek.

Question: Who are you?
Answer: Sam! Sam!

Question: Who are you?!
Answer: Gilly. Don't hurt us.

Question: Where are you going?
Answer: To Castle Black. I'm a brother of the Night's Watch.

Question: Who's your brother?
Answer: Doesn't matter.

Question: What? Why in the world would you want to go-
Answer: I don't want to. I have to.

Question: How did you get through the Wall?
Answer: Does the well lead to an underground river? Is that how you came here?

Question: Does the well lead to an underground river? Is that how you came here?
Answer: Come with us. There are steps carved into the south side of the Wall. Hodor can carry you to the top. We'll walk straight to Castle Black.

Question: How do you know all that?
Answer: The Night's Watch can't stop them. The kings of Westeros and all their armies can't stop them.

Question: But you're going to stop them?
Answer: Please, Sam. I have to go north. I have to.

Question: Son? He's not a man anymore.
Answer: He's your son. He's my brother. He's a Greyjoy.

Question: What is it?
Answer: Dragonglass.

Question: Why? What are they for?
Answer: Killing White Walkers.

Question: How do you know that?
Answer: The Walker came for my baby. And Sam-

Question: How are you keeping?
Answer: Great. Never better.

Question: I should have known. Every time a highborn asks my name, it's trouble. We're not really people to you, are we? Just a million different ways to get what you want.
Answer: I'm not a highborn.

Question: How far below? How close to the Red Keep were you?
Answer: The shit that poured from their privy pipes flowed down the side of Aegon's Hill along Tanner's Row and right in front of my front door on Gin Alley.

Question: The Street of Steel, with your armor and your knights? Pfft. You lived in the fancy part of town. And here we are now. Two boys from Flea Bottom in the castle of a king.
Answer: Yeah, we've come a long way. We're all the same, really. She went to great pains to point that out to me.

Question: If you mistrust fancy people so much, why were you in such a hurry to trust her?
Answer: You're me. Never been with a woman. Never talked to a woman, really. And then she comes at you- big words, no clothes. What would you have done?

Question: You're me. Never been with a woman. Never talked to a woman, really. And then she comes at you- big words, no clothes. What would you have done?
Answer: She does know her way around a man's head, I'll give her that.

Question: So how'd you become a lord?
Answer: Oh, that's a long story.

Question: You see? Highborns.
Answer: I didn't want to be a lord. I nearly didn't accept.

Question: Why did you?
Answer: I did it for my son. I didn't want him to step over a river of shit every time he stepped through his front door. I wanted him to have a better life.

Question: Does he?
Answer: He's dead.

Question: How'd he die?
Answer: Following me.

Question: When did you come to this strange country?
Answer: When I was thirteen.

Question: I love that girl. I would kill for her. Do you think that makes it easier for me?
Answer: No, I expect not.

Question: What do you want from me, Lord Varys?
Answer: Diamonds. I'd tell you to beware carrying so much wealth, but you know how to protect yourself. Get on one of those ships. Sail to Pentos or Lys or Myr. You can buy a house with these diamonds, a very large house. Hire servants. Start a new life, a good life, far from here. The mysterious foreign beauty. You'll have suitors lining up.

Question: Why do you want me to leave?
Answer: Tyrion Lannister is one of the few people alive who could make this country a better place. He has the mind for it, he has the will, he has the right last name. And you- you are a complication. I know you love him. And I know it's true love not bought by gold and silver. I'm not asking you to leave him for money. I'm asking you to leave because your presence in the capital endangers him. This will never be your home, my lady. Find a true home somewhere far from here while there's still time.

Question: So, enjoying married life? An unhappy wife is a wine merchant's best friend.
Answer: She doesn't deserve this.

Question: Deserve? Be careful with that. Start trying to work out who deserves what and before long you'll spend the rest of your days weeping for each and every person in the world.
Answer: There's nothing worse than a late-blooming philosopher.

Question: Will you be facing your marriage to Ser Loras with the same philosophical spirit?
Answer: I won't be marrying Ser Loras.

Question: You're not me. You want to make things better for Sansa? Give her a child.
Answer: So you can tell Father it was you who finally talked me into it?

Question: So you can tell Father it was you who finally talked me into it?
Answer: So she can have some happiness in her life.

Question: You have children. How happy would you say you are?
Answer: Not very. But if it weren't for my children, I'd have thrown myself from the highest window in the Red Keep. They're the reason I'm alive.

Question: Even Joffrey?
Answer: Even Joffrey. He was all I had once. Before Myrcella was born. I used to spend hours looking at him. His wisps of hair. His tiny little hands and feet. He was such a jolly little fellow. You always hear the terrible ones were terrible babies. 'We should have known. Even then we should have known.' It's nonsense. Whenever he was with me, he was happy. And no one can take that away from me, not even Joffrey- how it feels to have someone. Someone of your own.

Question: How long does it go on?
Answer: Until we've dealt with all our enemies.

Question: You sewed it on?
Answer: I did.

Question: What do you want?
Answer: Mind if I keep warm?

Question: Mind if I keep warm?
Answer: Fuck off.

Question: Does fuck off mean something different where you're from?
Answer: I've got money.

Question: What kind of coin is that?
Answer: It's worth a lot.

Question: Where did you get the knife?
Answer: From you.

Question: Is that the first man you've killed?
Answer: The first man.

Question: I'm not a lord, my dear. Not for many, many years. Every man who joins the Night's Watch renounces all former titles. Among other things. What is your name?
Answer: Gilly.

Question: And the child?
Answer: She hasn't chosen a name yet.

Question: Tarly do you remember the oath you swore when you joined this order?
Answer: He's not my child, Maester Aemon. She's one of Craster's wives. I remember every word of the oath. Night gathers and my watch begins. I am the shield that guards the realms of men. The realms of men. That means her as well as us. We didn't build five hundred miles of ice walls seve hundred feet high to keep men out. The night is gathering, Maester Aemon. I've seen it. It's coming for all of us.

Question: First night of the full moon.' Why is there a G in night?
Answer: I don't know. There just is.

Question: What is it?
Answer: Why are they ringing the bells? Are we being attacked?

Question: Why are they ringing the bells? Are we being attacked?
Answer: Stay here. Bar the door.

Question: And you take credit because you dropped a leech into the fire?
Answer: I take no credit. I have faith and my faith has been rewarded.

Question: Do you know who had this table carved and painted, Ser Davos?
Answer: Aegon Targaryen.

Question: And do you know how Aegon Targaryen conquered Westeros?
Answer: On the back of his dragon, Balerion the Dread.

Question: What is the life of one bastard boy against a kingdom?
Answer: Everything.

Question: What are you doing?
Answer: You're leaving.

Question: Is this some kind of trick?
Answer: Yes, but not on you.

Question: Where should I go?
Answer: You must keep the coast on your left side until you reach King's Landing.

Question: They were looking for me for twenty years. Do they know your face?
Answer: No.

Question: You ever been in a boat before?
Answer: You know how to swim?

Question: You know how to swim?
Answer: Don't fall out. Go on.

Question: Why are you doing this?
Answer: Because it's right. And because I'm a slow learner.

Question: Pyp? Sam?
Answer: Hush, now. You're home. Carry him inside. Gently.

Question: You don't deny it?
Answer: No. I let him go.

Question: Your mercy saved the boy's life. You feel good about that?
Answer: Aye, I do.

Question: You saved one innocent. How many tens of thousands have you doomed?
Answer: There has got to be another way.

Question: What other way?! Tell us about this other way.
Answer: I don't know, Your Grace. I can't see the future in the fire.

Question: Why am I gonna need you?
Answer: My king.

Question: When did you learn to read?
Answer: Matthos taught me before he died so I could be of better service to you.

Question: You see, Ser Davos? You've been saved by that fire god you like to mock. You're in his army now.
Answer: They will come, Your Grace. When they're ready.

Question: What does it mean?
Answer: It is old Ghiscari, khaleesi. It means 'mother'.

Question: Where did you get this much Valyrian steel?
Answer: From someone who no longer had need of it.

Question: Two?
Answer: The original weapon was absurdly large. Plenty of steel for two swords.

Question: Where's that written? I can and I will. The Kingsguard oath is for life.
Answer: The war is over. The king is safe. The king is never safe.

Question: How many people in this city alone would love to see his head on a pike?
Answer: Other knights protected the king while you were a prisoner. They will continue to do so when you go home.

Question: Home?
Answer: You'll return to Casterly Rock and rule in my stead.

Question: You know what they call me? Kingslayer. Oathbreaker. Man without honor. Now you want me to break another sacred vow.
Answer: You won't be breaking anything. There is a precedent to relieve a Kingsguard of his duties. The king will exercise that prerogative.

Question: No?
Answer: I don't believe I asked you a question.

Question: What do you want?
Answer: Supper would be nice.

Question: How many Dornishmen does it take to fuck a goat?
Answer: Please don't.

Question: If he's so damned important, how come they sent you to meet him?
Answer: There's bad blood between the Martells of Dorne and the Lannisters of Casterly Rock. Has been for years.

Question: And just in case the Martells of Dorne are looking to spill some Lannister blood, it may as well be yours, eh?
Answer: No need for cynicism. I happen to be an accomplished diplomat.

Question: Can you read the sigils?
Answer: Yellow balls?

Question: Yellow balls?
Answer: Wild lemons on a purple field, House Dalt of Lemonwood. A vulture grasping a baby in it's talons, House Blackmont. A crowned skull, the Manwoodys of Kingsgrave.

Question: And House Martell, a red sun pierced by a spear?
Answer: I don't see it, my lord.

Question: Will he?
Answer: And where is Prince Oberyn?

Question: And where is Prince Oberyn?
Answer: Arrived before dawn. Not a man for welcome parties, our prince.

Question: Some accomplished diplomacy that was. Now where?
Answer: We must find Prince Oberyn before he kills somebody or several somebodies.

Question: How do you plan on finding a single Dornishman in a city this big?
Answer: You're famous for fucking half of Westeros. You just arrived at the capital after two weeks of bad roads, where would you go?

Question: You're famous for fucking half of Westeros. You just arrived at the capital after two weeks of bad roads, where would you go?
Answer: I'd probably go to sleep, but I'm getting old.

Question: Look at this one. How lovely is she?
Answer: Beautiful. But pale.

Question: You like?
Answer: Timid. Timid bores me.

Question: You're a bit of mischief, aren't you?
Answer: I think she likes you. ELLARIA" She has good taste.

Question: You're not timid, are you?
Answer: Not timid.

Question: Do you like women?
Answer: When they look like her, my lord.

Question: A lie anywhere. Why not use the right words? I'm a bastard. She is a whore. And you're what? A procurer.
Answer: Any of the others?

Question: Any of the others?
Answer: The two girls can leave.

Question: I am a prince, boy. Have you ever been with a prince?
Answer: Can't say I have. I'm wildly expensive.

Question: Which way do you like it?
Answer: My way .

Question: You lost, friend?
Answer: Forgive me for staring. I don't see many Lannisters where I'm from.

Question: Why are you wasting a woman like this on a Dornishman? Bring him a shaved goat and a bottle of olive oil.
Answer: Do you know why all the world hates a Lannister?

Question: Do you know why all the world hates a Lannister?
Answer: You think your gold and your lions and your gold lions make you better than everyone. May I tell you a secret? You're not a golden lion. You're just a pink little man who is far too slow on the draw.

Question: You think your gold and your lions and your gold lions make you better than everyone. May I tell you a secret? You're not a golden lion. You're just a pink little man who is far too slow on the draw.
Answer: Longsword is a bad option in close quarters. When I pull my blade, your friend starts bleeding. Quite a lot, I'm afraid. So many veins in the wrist.

Question: What are you? His hired killer?
Answer: It started that way, aye. Now I'm a knight.

Question: How did that come to pass?
Answer: Killed the right people, I suppose.

Question: We'll need a few more girls. Girls, yes?
Answer: Oh, I partook. Now I'm married.

Question: Prince Oberyn, if I may, a word in private?
Answer: Seems I visited the Lannister brothel by mistake.

Question: Why did you come to King's Landing, Prince Oberyn?
Answer: I was invited to the royal wedding.

Question: And butchered those children. My nephew and niece. Carved them up and wrapped them in Lannister cloaks. And my sister, you know what they did to her?
Answer: I'm asking you a question.

Question: Where's Daario Naharis? Where's Grey Worm?
Answer: Gambling, Your Grace.

Question: Gambling?
Answer: Mhysa. Mhysa. Mhysa...

Question: How long have they been at it?
Answer: Since midnight, Your Grace.

Question: What's the prize to winning this stupid contest?
Answer: The honor of riding by your side on the road to Meereen.

Question: You like this girl? Must be frustrating.
Answer: You are not a smart man, Daario Naharis.

Question: Lemon cakes?
Answer: You love lemon cakes.

Question: How can you help me?
Answer: I don't know, but I can try.

Question: Do you know what they did to my brother? How they sewed his direwolf's head onto his body? And my mother. They say they cut her throat to the bone and threw her body in the river.
Answer: What happened to your family was a terrible crime. I didn't know your brother. He seemed like a good man, but I didn't know him. Your mother, on the other hand, I admired her. She wanted to have me executed, but I admired her. She was a strong woman. And she was fierce when it came to protecting her children. Sansa. Your mother would want you to carry on. You know it's true.

Question: Will you pardon me, my lord? I'd like to visit the godswood.
Answer: Of course. Of course. Prayer can be helpful, I hear.

Question: What are you doing?
Answer: What does it look like I'm doing? Come here.

Question: What does it look like I'm doing? Come here.
Answer: How many times have I told you? You can't visit me here.

Question: How many times have I told you? You can't visit me here.
Answer: I know. I know. We have come to a dangerous place. Have you forgotten me? Do you know how long it's been?

Question: I know. I know. We have come to a dangerous place. Have you forgotten me? Do you know how long it's been?
Answer: Of course I haven't forgotten.

Question: I want you. Don't you want me?
Answer: Things are a bit tense right now.

Question: What things?
Answer: My nephew the king wants to murder me. My wife hates me because my father murdered her family. Oberyn Martell wants to murder everyone whose last name is Lannister.

Question: Don't you want to relax?
Answer: What's wrong?

Question: What's wrong?
Answer: I told you. It's not a good time.

Question: Do you love her?
Answer: Love her? I barely know her. She's a child. She despises me.

Question: Love her? I barely know her. She's a child. She despises me.
Answer: That's not an answer.

Question: Ship you away?
Answer: Give me diamonds and make me disappear.

Question: What in the world are you talking about?
Answer: If you want me to leave, just say it. Say it!

Question: You want me to stay?
Answer: A work of art, really. The craftsmanship is excellent.

Question: Days?
Answer: Better part of an afternoon. There, how does that feel?

Question: Better part of an afternoon. There, how does that feel?
Answer: Uh... a hook would be more practical.

Question: The symptoms have abated?
Answer: Gone completely. I am in your debt, Maester Qyburn.

Question: I've grown rather fond of him. He's quite talented, you know?
Answer: What symptoms?

Question: What symptoms?
Answer: Symptoms that are not your concern.

Question: You let him touch you?
Answer: You jealous?

Question: You jealous?
Answer: I'm surprised. You never let Pycelle near you.

Question: You think I'd let that old lecher put his hands on me? He smells like a dead cat.
Answer: I'm not sure I've ever smelled a dead cat.

Question: Why?
Answer: Let's see, you started a brawl in the streets with Ned Stark and disappeared from the capital. My husband died in a tragic hunting accident.

Question: You don't really plan on staying in the Kingsguard, do you?
Answer: Staying in the Kingsguard means I live right here in the Red Keep with you.

Question: I want... Not now? When? I've been back for weeks.
Answer: Something's changed.

Question: Everything's changed. You come back after all this time with no apologies and one hand and expect everything to be the same?
Answer: What do you want me to apologize for?

Question: What do you want me to apologize for?
Answer: For leaving me.

Question: You think I wanted to be taken prisoner?
Answer: Don't know what you wanted. You weren't here. You left me alone.

Question: I... What are you saying?
Answer: I'm saying you took too long.

Question: You plan on killing all the crows yourself?
Answer: Do you plan on sitting here scratching your balls till winter?

Question: Do you plan on sitting here scratching your balls till winter?
Answer: We wait for Mance's orders.

Question: And what is it you want? March on Castle Black with just this lot? Your pretty crow said 1,000 men are nesting there.
Answer: Yeah, well, he's a liar.

Question: He is? Shouldn't it be "he was"? You said you put three arrows in him.
Answer: I did.

Question: Mance sent you?
Answer: How did you find us?

Question: How did you find us?
Answer: You came from the south, not the north.

Question: Why does the meat down here taste so much better than it does on our side of the Wall?
Answer: Help yourself.

Question: Fat and lazy. Easier for us, hmm?
Answer: You didn't see us coming? Lost your warg? And that baby crow you had with you, lost him too?

Question: You didn't see us coming? Lost your warg? And that baby crow you had with you, lost him too?
Answer: I'll answer to Mance. I won't answer to you.

Question: She yours?
Answer: I'm not anybody's.

Question: So you admit you murdered Qhorin Halfhand?
Answer: I didn't murder him.

Question: No? You put your sword through a brother of the Night's Watch. What do you call that?
Answer: He wanted me to kill him.

Question: A bastard son of a traitor. What would you expect?
Answer: The Halfhand believed our only chance to stop Mance was to get a man inside his army.

Question: The free folk? Listen to him. He even talks like a wildling now.
Answer: Aye, I talk like a wildling. I ate with the wildlings. I climbed the Wall with the wildlings. I... I laid with a wildling girl.

Question: You admit to breaking your vows, then?
Answer: I do.

Question: Giants?
Answer: Have you ever been beyond the Wall, ser?

Question: Have you ever been beyond the Wall, ser?
Answer: I commanded the City Watch of King's Landing, boy.

Question: How dare you?!
Answer: There's a band of wildlings south of the Wall already led by Tormund Giantsbane. I killed their warg and three others. They shot me full of arrows. Their orders are to attack Castle Black from the south when Mance hits it from the north. The signal for the attack will be a bonfire. Mance said it would be the greatest fire the North has ever seen. That's the truth. All the truth.

Question: Do you intend to execute me or am I free to go?
Answer: None of us are free. We are men of the Night's Watch. But we won't be taking your head today, Jon Snow. Go on.

Question: And you always know when a man's telling a lie? How did you acquire this magical power?
Answer: I grew up in King's Landing.

Question: We know who you are. We've heard all about you. But hearing is one thing. Aren't you just marvelous? Absolutely singular.
Answer: I hear you knocked my grandson into the dirt like the silly little boy he is.

Question: A shadow?
Answer: A shadow with the face of Stannis Baratheon. I swear to you by all the gods it was Stannis. He plunged his sword through Renly's heart and disappeared. One day, my lady, I will avenge our king.

Question: All the Kingsguard will be on duty, of course. Ser Boros will be stationed here. Ser Preston will be stationed here beside the primary entertainment. Your Grace?
Answer: Yes, yes, one guard at the... the thing. Go on.

Question: So this is the famous "Book of Brothers"? All the great deeds of all the great Kingsguard. Ser Arthur Dayne. The Sword of the Morning. Led the attack on the Kingswood Brotherhood. Defeated the Smiling Knight in single combat. Ser Duncan the Tall. Four pages for Ser Duncan. He must have been quite a man.
Answer: So they say.

Question: Is there? For a 40-year-old knight with one hand? How can you protect me with that?
Answer: I use my left hand now, Your Grace. Makes for more of a contest.

Question: Have you ever been to Meereen?
Answer: Several times, Your Grace, with Master Kraznys.

Question: And?
Answer: They say 1,000 slaves died building the Great Pyramid of Meereen.

Question: And now an army of former slaves is marching to her gates. You think the Great Masters are worried?
Answer: If they're smart, Your Grace.

Question: All right, what is this matter of strategy?
Answer: A dusk rose.

Question: Would you like to walk at the back of the train instead of riding?
Answer: And this one's called lady's lace.

Question: Would you like to walk without shoes?
Answer: You have to know a land to rule it. It's plants, it's rivers, it's roads, it's people. Dusk rose tea eases fever. Everyone in Meereen knows that. Especially the slaves who have to make the tea. If you want them to follow you, you have to become a part of their world. Strategy.

Question: You are a gambler, aren't you?
Answer: Your Grace.

Question: How many miles are there between here and Meereen?
Answer: 163, Your Grace. I'll tell our men to ride ahead and bury them. You don't need to see this.

Question: And? You made a promise.
Answer: To return the Stark girls to their mother who is now dead.

Question: Well, Arya Stark hasn't been seen since her father was killed. Where do you think she is? My money's on dead. There's a certain safety in death, wouldn't you say? And Sansa Stark is now Sansa Lannister. Bit of a complication.
Answer: A complication does not release you from a vow.

Question: What do you want me to do? Kidnap my sister-in-law? And take her where? Where would she be safer than here?
Answer: Look me in the eye and tell me that you think she'll be safe in King's Landing.

Question: Are you sure we're not related? Ever since I've returned, every Lannister I've seen has been a miserable pain in my ass. Maybe you're a Lannister, too. You've got the hair for it if not the looks.
Answer: It's all right. It's all right. It's all right.

Question: Yes. I have good reason to be. Once I was a knight. Now I'm only a fool. Don't you know me?
Answer: Ser Dontos. The king's nameday celebration. I'm sorry. I should have remembered.

Question: When am I going to get a horse of my own?
Answer: The little lady wants a pony.

Question: Horses aren't easy to come by. Even if they were, you think I'm gonna put you on your own horse? Watch the only thing of value I've got in the world ride away?
Answer: Why don't you have any money? Didn't you steal anything from Joffrey before you left?

Question: Why don't you have any money? Didn't you steal anything from Joffrey before you left?
Answer: No.

Question: You're not very smart, are you?
Answer: I'm not a thief.

Question: You're fine with murdering little boys, but thieving is beneath you?
Answer: A man's got to have a code.

Question: You think I'm gonna escape? Where would I go? I'd be dead by nightfall without you. My family's gone. I've got no one.
Answer: You've got an aunt in the Vale. Your rich Aunt Lysa. After I sell you to her, maybe she'll have enough left over to buy you that pony you want so much.

Question: What the fuck's a Lommy?
Answer: He was my friend. Polliver stole my sword and put it right through his neck. He's still got it.

Question: Got what?
Answer: My sword Needle.

Question: Needle? Of course you named your sword.
Answer: Lots of people name their swords.

Question: Pour our new friend some ale. What brings you so far north?
Answer: I could ask the same of you. What are you doing up here?

Question: I could ask the same of you. What are you doing up here?
Answer: Just keeping the king's peace.

Question: So I've heard. Stannis defeated at the Blackwater. Robb Stark killed at the Twins. And where am I for all of it? Stuck with your brother. Meaning no offense.
Answer: None taken.

Question: He's good, the Mountain is. Best at what he does. But torture, torture, torture, torture. You spend enough time putting the hammer to people, you start to feel like a carpenter making chairs. Drains the fun right out of it. And what's life without a little fun?
Answer: But I don't need to tell you that, eh?

Question: But I don't need to tell you that, eh?
Answer: She's all right. I've had better.

Question: You know what? You should come with us. His kind, they've always got something hidden away somewhere. Gold, silver, more daughters. Always something if you know how to make them talk. And there's plenty of him between here and King's Landing. You could do well for yourself. We certainly have been.
Answer: I'm not going to King's Landing.

Question: You got money to pay for it?
Answer: You paid for it?

Question: You paid for it?
Answer: No. But we're the king's men. So, you got money?

Question: No. But we're the king's men. So, you got money?
Answer: Not a penny.

Question: You lived your life for the king. You're gonna die for some chickens?
Answer: Someone is.

Question: Something wrong with your leg, boy?
Answer: What? What do you mean?

Question: What? What do you mean?
Answer: Can you walk? I've got to carry you?

Question: Can you walk? I've got to carry you?
Answer: Carry me?

Question: Carry me?
Answer: Fine little blade.

Question: Where is she?
Answer: Tansy, Tansy, Tansy!

Question: You brought her down. That's what matters. A fine shot. Wasn't it, Reek?
Answer: A fine shot, master. My lady.

Question: Why? I did whatever you asked.
Answer: But you made Myranda feel jealous.

Question: Me jealous of her?
Answer: My lord, please.

Question: Your new hand, it's nicer than the old one. Wouldn't you agree, Pod?
Answer: Is it solid gold?

Question: Is it solid gold?
Answer: Gilded steel.

Question: You're not eating. Why is no one eating? My wife wastes away and my brother starves himself.
Answer: I'm not hungry.

Question: What about your left?
Answer: I can hold a sword, but all my instincts are wrong. How can I protect the king when I can hardly wipe my own ass?

Question: I can hold a sword, but all my instincts are wrong. How can I protect the king when I can hardly wipe my own ass?
Answer: You're the Lord Commander now. Command. Let others do the fighting. When was the last time Father used a sword?

Question: You're the Lord Commander now. Command. Let others do the fighting. When was the last time Father used a sword?
Answer: I'm not Father. I'm the Kingslayer. When people find out I can't slay a pigeon...

Question: With whom? You? Men talk. Soon as someone discovers I can't fight, he'll tell everyone.
Answer: You need a proper, discreet swordsman. As it happens, I have just the one.

Question: Is this place safe?
Answer: There's this knight, Leygood, got thunderbolts on his shield.

Question: Plan on growing it back?
Answer: Come on, then.

Question: Where is your prize?
Answer: With the hounds. I'll have a look at him.

Question: What did you do to him?
Answer: I trained him. He was a slow learner, but he learned.

Question: You sent terms to Balon Greyjoy without my consent?
Answer: You made me acting Lord of the Dreadfort. I acted.

Question: Reek, how could you let me stand before my father unshaven? It's disrespectful.
Answer: I'm sorry, my lord.

Question: If I'm not a Bolton, Father, what does it matter?
Answer: Go on, Reek. A nice close shave.

Question: Reek, tell Father where are Bran and Rickon Stark?
Answer: I don't know, my lord.

Question: Reek, did you murder the Stark boys?
Answer: No, my lord. Just two farm boys.

Question: Oh, that's right, Reek. Robb Stark is dead. Sorry. I know he was like a brother to you. But my father put a knife through his heart. How do you feel about that?
Answer: You ready for a hunt?

Question: You ready for a hunt?
Answer: Always. Find those boys and I'll give you a thousand acres and a holdfast.

Question: Your pet rat have any thoughts on which way they went after Winterfell?
Answer: Jon Snow is at Castle Black.

Question: Who the fuck is Jon Snow?
Answer: Their bastard brother. He could be sheltering them. He may know where they are.

Question: You want to prove yourself a Bolton? Gather whatever men you can and ride for Moat Cailin. Bring this creature of yours. Maybe he'll be of some use. Take the Moat for the family, for our family, and I'll reconsider your position.
Answer: Lord Varys. Breakfasting with the king?

Question: Lord Varys. Breakfasting with the king?
Answer: I'm afraid foreigners aren't welcome at such exclusive affairs.

Question: No, I will not. How long do you imagine your father and sister would let me live if they suspected me of lying? I have no pet sellsword to protect me. No legendary brother to avenge me. Only little birds who whisper in my ear.
Answer: Forgive me if I don't weep for you.

Question: Your father has promised to hang the next whore he finds you with. Have you ever known your father to make an idle threat?
Answer: From House Tyrell and the people of the Reach, Your Grace, it is my honor to present you with this wedding cup.

Question: A handsome goblet, my lord. Or shall I call you Father?
Answer: I shall be honored, Your Grace.

Question: A book?
Answer: The Lives of Four Kings." Grand Maester Kaeth's history of the reigns of Daeron the Young Dragon, Baelor the Blessed, Aegon the Unworthy, and Daeron the Good. A book every king should read.

Question: Such a great sword should have a name. What shall I call her?
Answer: Stormbringer.

Question: You want me on the desk? What's wrong, my lion?
Answer: Don't call me that.

Question: What should I call you?
Answer: I'm afraid our friendship can't continue.

Question: Our friendship?
Answer: There's a ship waiting in the harbor bound for Pentos.

Question: What?
Answer: You'll have your own cabin, of course, and, across the Narrow Sea, a house, servants.

Question: What is this?
Answer: I'm a married man. My wife has suffered a great deal, as you well know. I don't want her to suffer anymore on my account. I need to uphold my vows.

Question: What are you afraid of?
Answer: I'm not afraid.

Question: You are. You are afraid of your father and your sister. You're going to run from them all your life?
Answer: I need you to leave.

Question: You're a whore! Sansa is fit to bear my children and you are not. I can't be in love with a whore. I can't have children with a whore. How many men have you been with? Five hundred? Five thousand?
Answer: How many whores have you been with?

Question: How many whores have you been with?
Answer: I have enjoyed my time with all of them and I have enjoyed my time with you most of all. But now that time is over.

Question: Did you see? Their souls. It was their souls. Our lord took them. Did you see?
Answer: Lord Florent was your brother by law.

Question: How many ships did he bring to your 'cause? How many men?
Answer: A good deal more than you.

Question: Did you see, Ser Davos? They're with our lord now. Their sins all burned away. Did you see?
Answer: I'm sure they're more than grateful, my queen.

Question: When Storm's End was under siege and I was starving, Stannis boiled soup for me from books. The binding glue is made from horses. One morning, he shot two seagulls on the beach. I've never tasted anything as good as grilled seagull. Do you remember?
Answer: Of course I remember.

Question: Have you ever known true hunger, my lady?
Answer: It's all I knew when I was a child.

Question: Until you found the Lord of Light?
Answer: Until he found me.

Question: You barely know her. You think she's sweet because she smiles when you visit. She's sullen and stubborn and sinful. Why else would the Lord of Light have seen fit to mark her face? She needs the rod.
Answer: She's my daughter. You will not strike her.

Question: Were you sleeping, Princess?
Answer: Did you watch the ceremony on the beach?

Question: Did you watch the ceremony on the beach?
Answer: I heard it.

Question: And it frightened you?
Answer: Ser Axell was my uncle. He was always kind to me.

Question: You have so many questions, don't you? So did I when I was a child. I was much like you. Only I wasn't a princess.
Answer: And you didn't have this.

Question: No. But I suffered in other ways, sweet girl, believe me. What do you know of the gods?
Answer: I read "The Seven-Pointed Star."

Question: There are no seven heavens and no seven hells?
Answer: There's only one hell, Princess. The one we live in now.

Question: Why did you wake me?
Answer: You've been gone for hours.

Question: Bit much, wouldn't you say?
Answer: It feels proportionate.

Question: Proportionate to what?
Answer: The expected extravagance.

Question: Shall we stick golden roses in half the meat pies to commemorate your generosity?
Answer: No, your heartfelt thank you is its own reward. I would imagine I'd be hearing it again before long. Wars are rather expensive. "The Iron Bank will have it's due." How they love to remind everyone. Almost as much as you Lannisters with your debts.

Question: You saw her board the ship?
Answer: Aye, she's on it.

Question: You saw the ship sail away?
Answer: No one knows she's there but you, me, and Varys.

Question: How do you know?
Answer: Because if someone follows me without an invitation, I'm the last person they ever follow.

Question: There's someone following you?
Answer: She's gone. I know you don't want to believe it, but she is. Now, go drink till it feels like you did the right thing.

Question: You look exquisite, child. The wind has been at you, though. I haven't had the opportunity to tell you how sorry I was to hear about your brother. War is war, but killing a man at a wedding, horrid. What sort of monster would do such a thing? As if men need more reasons to fear marriage.
Answer: My lady. My lady.

Question: Lord Tyrion, you see? Not as bad as all that. Perhaps if your pauper husband were to sell his mule and his last pair of shoes, he might be able to afford to bring you to Highgarden for a visit. Now that peace has come and all is right with the world, it would do you good to see some of it. You must excuse me. It's time I ate some of this food I paid for.
Answer: A coat of gold / Or a coat of red / A lion still has claws And mine, my lord...

Question: My love, why don't we make the announcement?
Answer: Everyone. The queen would like to say a few words.

Question: So, looking forward to your wedding?
Answer: Yes, very much.

Question: Did you just bow?
Answer: Apologies, Your Grace. I never did master the curtsy.

Question: Did he? Haven't heard that story before.
Answer: Not such a fascinating story, I'm afraid.

Question: Qyburn? Deplorable man. Brought shame on the Citadel with his repugnant experiments.
Answer: More repugnant than your gnarled fingers on that girl's thighs?

Question: More repugnant than your gnarled fingers on that girl's thighs?
Answer: Your Grace, I am a man of learning.

Question: My little brother had you sent to the Black Cells when you annoyed him. What do you think I could do to you if you annoyed me?
Answer: I never meant to annoy anyone.

Question: Bastards are born of passion, aren't they? We don't despise them in Dorne.
Answer: No? How tolerant of you.

Question: No? How tolerant of you.
Answer: I expect it is a relief, Lady Cersei, giving up your regal responsibilities. Wearing the crown for so many years must have left your neck a bit crooked.

Question: Who's got the gold now, Stark?
Answer: I am the rightful king.

Question: Well fought. Well fought. Here you are. Champion's purse. Though you're not the champion yet, are you? A true champion defeats all the challengers. Surely there are others out there who still dare to challenge my reign. Uncle. How about you? I'm sure they have a spare costume.
Answer: One taste of combat was enough for me, Your Grace. I would like to keep what remains of my face. I think you should fight him. This was but a poor imitation of your own bravery on the field of battle. I speak as a firsthand witness. Climb down from the high table with your new Valyrian sword and show everyone how a true king wins his throne. Be careful, though. This one is clearly mad with lust. It would be a tragedy for the king to lose his virtue hours before his wedding night.

Question: Well, how does he expect me to toast without wine? Uncle, you can be my cup-bearer seeing as you're too cowardly to fight.
Answer: Your Grace does me a great honor.

Question: What good is an empty cup? Fill it.
Answer: Kneel. Kneel before your king.

Question: Can we leave now?
Answer: Let's find out.

Question: Uncle. Where are you going? You're my cup-bearer, remember?
Answer: I thought I might change out of these wet clothes, Your Grace.

Question: Your Grace?
Answer: It's nothing.

Question: Joffrey. Please, Joffrey. Joffrey, what is it? Help him!
Answer: My son.

Question: Where is his wife? Where's Sansa?
Answer: Find her. Bar the gates of the city. Seize every ship in the harbor.

Question: Where is she?!
Answer: No one leaves the capital! No one!

Question: Where are we going?
Answer: Somewhere safe.

Question: Lord Baelish?
Answer: Petyr... Are you hurt, my lady?

Question: Petyr... Are you hurt, my lady?
Answer: Good. Good. I'm sure you've had quite a fright. Rest easy. The worst is past. Ser Dontos shouts up from his boat.

Question: I should get back before someone thinks to look for me. LITTLEFINGER First you'll want your pay. 10,000 was it?
Shh. You don't want the queen to hear, do you? 1,000 gold cloaks are searching for you. And if they found you, how do you think they would punish the girl who murdered the king?
Answer: I didn't murder anyone.

Question: Why did you kill him?
Answer: Because he was a drunk and a fool and I don't trust drunk fools.

Question: Saved you? My lady, he followed my orders. Every one of them. And he did it all for gold. Money buys a man's silence for a time. A bolt in the heart buys it forever.
Answer: He was helping me because I saved his life.

Question: I had it made a few weeks ago. What did I once tell you about the capital?
Answer: We're all liars here.

Question: So am I the queen?
Answer: More than you were with Renly. Less than you would have been if Joffrey had done you the courtesy of consummating the marriage before dying. In any case, this would not be an opportune moment to press the issue.

Question: The world is overflowing with horrible things. But they're all a tray of cakes next to death. They brought me your grandfather's body when he died, you know? Made me look at it.
Answer: What was it like?

Question: What was it like?
Answer: They took me to the Great Hall and there he was. The man I'd married and suffered to father my children. A great doughy lump I'd sat next to at endless dinners and tedious gatherings. There he was... lying on a table.

Question: Your brother is dead. Do you know what that means?
Answer: I'm not trying to trick you.

Question: Yes, you will become king. What kind of king do you think you'll be?
Answer: A good king?

Question: A good king?
Answer: Mm, I think so as well. You've got the right temperament for it. But what makes a good king? Hmm? What is a good king's single most important quality?

Question: Mm, I think so as well. You've got the right temperament for it. But what makes a good king? Hmm? What is a good king's single most important quality?
Answer: This is hardly the place or the time.

Question: Holiness?
Answer: Hmm. Baelor the Blessed was holy. And pious. He built this sept. He also named a six-year-old boy high septon because he thought the boy could work miracles. He ended up fasting himself into an early grave because food was of this world and this world was sinful.

Question: Yeah. A good king must be just. Orys I was just. Everyone applauded his reforms. Nobles and commoners alike. But he wasn't just for long. He was murdered in his sleep after less than a year by his own brother. Was that truly just of him? To abandon his subjects to an evil that he was too gullible to recognize?
Answer: No.

Question: What about strength?
Answer: Yes. Strength. King Robert was strong. He won the rebellion and crushed the Targaryen dynasty. And he attended three small council meetings in 17 years. He spent his time whoring and hunting and drinking until the last two killed him. So, we have a man who starves himself to death, a man who lets his own brother murder him, and a man who thinks that winning and ruling are the same thing. What do they all lack?

Question: Yes. Strength. King Robert was strong. He won the rebellion and crushed the Targaryen dynasty. And he attended three small council meetings in 17 years. He spent his time whoring and hunting and drinking until the last two killed him. So, we have a man who starves himself to death, a man who lets his own brother murder him, and a man who thinks that winning and ruling are the same thing. What do they all lack?
Answer: Wisdom.

Question: Yes. But what is wisdom? Hmm? A house with great wealth and fertile lands asks you for your protection against another house with a strong Navy that could one day oppose you. How do you know which choice is wise and which isn't? You've any experience of treasuries and granaries or shipyards and soldiers?
Answer: No. Of course not. A wise king knows what he knows and what he doesn't. You're young. A wise young king listens to his counselors and heeds their advice until he comes of age. And the wisest kings continue to listen to them long afterwards... Your brother was not a wise king. Your brother was not a good king. If he had been, perhaps he'd still be alive. Now, as the king, you will have to marry. Do you understand why?

Question: No. Of course not. A wise king knows what he knows and what he doesn't. You're young. A wise young king listens to his counselors and heeds their advice until he comes of age. And the wisest kings continue to listen to them long afterwards... Your brother was not a wise king. Your brother was not a good king. If he had been, perhaps he'd still be alive. Now, as the king, you will have to marry. Do you understand why?
Answer: A king needs a queen.

Question: Yes, but why? To further the family line. Do you know how that happens?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Yes, but has anyone explained the details to you?
Answer: I don't think so. It's all relatively straightforward.

Question: How are you?
Answer: I'm all right.

Question: You're a hateful woman. Why have the gods made me love a hateful woman?
Answer: Jaime, not here, please. Please.

Question: Gonna rain soon. Where are we?
Answer: Near Fairmarket, I think.

Question: You think? You don't have a map?
Answer: No, I don't have a map.

Question: How far is it to the Eyrie?
Answer: Far.

Question: And you're sure we're going the right way?
Answer: Believe me, girl, I want you there as soon as I can. Get my gold, be on my way.

Question: On your way where?
Answer: Why do you care? Might book passage across the Narrow Sea. Fight as a sellsword. Second Sons, could be. Seems like a good fit for me.

Question: Why do you care? Might book passage across the Narrow Sea. Fight as a sellsword. Second Sons, could be. Seems like a good fit for me.
Answer: I'd like to see Braavos one day.

Question: Why Braavos?

Question: What do you want?
Answer: What do I want? This is my land.

Question: What do I want? This is my land.
Answer: If I'm standing on it, it's my land.

Question: Which house did he fight for?
Answer: The Tullys of Riverrun.

Question: You got to do all seven of the fuckers?

Question: Did you fight at the Twins?
Answer: Call that a fight? Slaughtering livestock more like.

Question: Call that a fight? Slaughtering livestock more like.
Answer: The Red Wedding they're calling it. Walder Frey committed sacrilege that day. He shared bread and salt with the Starks. He offered them guest right.

Question: You got any ale?
Answer: Afraid not.

Question: How can a man not keep ale in his home?
Answer: You look like you could really swing that sword. A real warrior with proper training. Those raiders wouldn't stand a chance against you. How would it be if you stayed on till the new moon? I could use a man to help with the farmwork. Sally does what she can, but she can't lift a bale of hay. And if any thieves came looking for easy pickings, one look at you, I'd bet they'd run the other way. Meaning no offense.

Question: You look like you could really swing that sword. A real warrior with proper training. Those raiders wouldn't stand a chance against you. How would it be if you stayed on till the new moon? I could use a man to help with the farmwork. Sally does what she can, but she can't lift a bale of hay. Question: What'll you pay? I don't have much. But I have hidden a bit of silver from the bandits. Fair wages for fair work?
Answer: Fair wages for fair work.

Question: What did you do?!

Question: There's plenty worse than me. I just understand the way things are. How many Starks they got to behead before you figure it out?
Answer: Raper. Raper. Horse thief. Ninth born son. Raper. Thief. Thief and raper.

Question: Going to visit your wildling whore?

Question: No? Maybe I'll give her a copper tonight and find out.

Question: About what?

Question: A what?
Answer: Well, a wildling.

Question: I don't know. It makes me sound a bit dangerous, doesn't it?
Answer: So... are you all right? No one bothering you?

Question: So... are you all right? No one bothering you?
Answer: I get a lot of looks. I hear them making their jokes. But no one's touched me if that's what you mean.

Question: Why do you worry about it?
Answer: 100 men, one woman.

Question: What about you?
Answer: What about me? Gilly? I worry about you.

Question: What about me? Gilly? I worry about you.

Question: For what?

Question: So what are you saying?

Question: Are you bored of me?

Question: Bored of you? I... I want to protect you.

Question: You're a literary man now. What do you make of that?

Question: Joffrey?
Answer: The usurper Joffrey Baratheon. I said those words when I tossed a leech into the fire. A leech filled with bastard blood. A bastard you set free. I am now faced with a great opportunity and I am powerless to take advantage of it.

Question: What progress have you made?
Answer: I've rallied House Peasebury to your 'cause.

Question: The Golden Company?

Question: We're willing to use blood magic to put you on the throne, but we're not willing to pay men to fight? Now the Red Woman's magic is real. Her visions and prophecies may be, too, but I've never heard of visions and prophecies winning a war. Soldiers win wars. Soldiers on the ground. It's dirty on the ground.
Answer: We don't have any gold.

Question: What's the difference?
Answer: Well, if you're a famous smuggler, you're not doing it right.

Question: You've sailed to Braavos?
Answer: Of course. Almost got beheaded by a First Sword of Braavos. I tried to explain to him the difference between pirates and smugglers, but he didn't seem any more interested in the distinction than your father. I suppose if you work for the Iron Bank of Braavos and each one of your gold barges is worth half a kingdom, you tend not to be overly concerned with the kind of distinction...

Question: What's his name?

Question: Lovely. That the daddy?

Answer: He's dead.

Question: Oh. Where you from?

Question: North of here? You a fucking wildling?

Question: I promise to come back and visit whenever I can. You'll be safer here. Who's gonna protect you at Castle Black? Me?

Question: Rather suspicious. Why haven't you thrown me in a dungeon?

Question: Here I stand unarmed, unguarded. Should I be concerned?

I would like to think if I were arranging a royal assassination, I'd plan it in such a way that I wouldn't be standing there gawking like a fool when the king died. Trial in a fortnight. Have they announced the judges yet?

Whenever something bad happens to me, I assume it's my sister that had a hand in it. But say what you will of Cersei, she loves her children. She is the only one I'm certain had nothing to do with this murder. Which makes it unique as King's Landing murders go.

Question: Everything. My friendship with the Lannisters was productive. But Joffrey, a vicious boy with a crown on his head, is not a reliable ally. And who could trust a friend like that?

Question: Who could trust you?

Question: Have you been to see Tommen yet?

Question: No. Have they even agreed to the match? No one tells me anything.

Marrying a Targaryen was all the rage back then. But the momentI saw my intended, with his twitchy little ferret's face and ludicrous silver hair, I knew he wouldn't do. So the evening before Luthor was to propose to my sister, I got lost on my way back from my embroidery lesson and happened upon his chamber.

Question: Catelyn Stark's dead. So if I told you to leave the capital right now and find Sansa, if I told you to find that murderous little bitch and bring me her head, would you do it?
Answer: I know you went to see Tyrion. That creature who murdered our son.

Question: And?
Answer: He didn't do it, Cersei.

Question: Ser Pounce?
Answer: How did you get past the Kingsguard?

Question: How did you get past the Kingsguard?
Answer: Kingsguard.

Question: Did you know that people in arranged marriages often never meet until their wedding day? Before we decide to spend our lives together, we ought to get to know one another. Don't you think?
Answer: Yes. But if my mother found out...

Question: It can be our secret. Hmm? If we're going to be man and wife, we'll have a few secrets from her, I hope. So, Your Grace...

Question: Yes? Tell me a secret.
Answer: Hello. Aren't you a proper fellow?

Answer: That's Ser Pounce.

Question: That's a relief. Because you know what happens when we marry?

Question: When we marry, I become yours. Forever. It's getting late. I should go. May I come and visit you again? All right, then.

Question: Craster's? You think Bra nmight have found...

Question: I'm going beyond the Wallto Craster's Keep. I'm going to capture the mutineers holed up there or kill them. I'm asking for volunteers to come with me. There's 60 miles of wilderness between here and Craster's and Mance Rayder has an army bearing down on us, but we have to do this. Our survival may depend on us getting to these mutineers before Mance does. They know the Wall. They know our defenses. If Mance learns what they know, we're lost. But if that's not enough, then consider this. If the Night's Watch are truly brothers, then Lord Commander Mormont was our father. He lived and died for the Watch and he was betrayed by his own men. Stabbed in the back by cowards. He deserved far better. All we can give him now is justice. Who will join me?

Question: Any command for us, Lord Commander? What's that? Fuck 'em till they're dead?

Question: Did you hear that, boys? Fuck 'em till they're dead.

Question: This is nice. Fine leather. You're no wildling. Important. Highborn. Who are you?

Question: I like your curly hair. My mom had curls like that. Beautiful brown curls. Why'd you drag a crippled boy all the way up here?

Question: You knew exactly what he was. I did, too. You never love anything in the world the way you love your first child. Doesn't matter what they do. And what he did, it shocked me. Do you think I'm easily shocked?

Question: The things he did shocked me. He's only a boy. A good boy. A decent boy. He always has been. Who was the last decent king, I wonder? He could be the first man who sits on that throne in fifty years to actually deserve it.

Question: It would be some consolation, wouldn't it? For all the horror that put him there.

Question: A mother is not enough. You're still interested in being queen, I take it?
Answer: Oh. After all that's happened... It sounds strange, I know, but I am... I haven't even given any thought to it, what comes next. It would be a great honor, of course. But I will have to speak to my father about it.

Question: I won't even know what to call you. Sister? Or Mother? Hmm.

Question: You know what kind of stories poor men enjoy the most? Ones about rich girls they'll never meet.

Question: Is this the only way into the Eyrie?
Answer: The mountains are impassable. If you want to get to the Eyrie, you need to go through the Bloody Gate. It doesn't matter how large your army is, if you attack this gate, you do it on this road, three men abreast and get slaughtered like goats. The first Lords of the Vale didn't have much, but they had these mountains and they knew how to use them. And the fortress they built here has never been overcome. Not once in a thousand years. Know your strengths, use them wisely, and one man can be worth ten thousand.

Question: Who would pass the Bloody Gate?
Answer: Lord Petyr Baelish and his niece, Alayne.

Question: Oh, do take down that hood, child. Don't you think know who you are? You think I'd let my intended leave the Eyrie on urgent business without knowing what that business was? I let him go so he could bring you here to me.

Question: I'm done waiting, Petyr. We had our wedding night many years ago. Or don't you remember?

Question: What wife would do for you the things I've done for you? What wife would trust you the way I've trusted you? When you gave me those drops and told me to pour them into Jon's wine, my husbando s wine... when you told me to write a letter to Cat telling her it was the Lannisters...

Question: When will the wedding take place in your mind?

Question: Your mother always had a sweet tooth, you know?

Question: Really?
Answer: Oh, yes. At suppertime, she would go straight for honey cakes, candied almonds, custard. Anything sweet. Eventually, your grandfather had to assign a septa to watch her at meals. Cat was the firstborn daughter after all. It was important that she remain desirable so Father could arrange a good match for her and she was starting to get fat.

Question: My mother, fat? She never let me have my pudding until I'd finished all my proper food.
Answer: This is before she married your father and moved to the North. By the time you were born, your father's austerity had become hers. Marriage changes people. I didn't mean for you to stop. Go on, enjoy them. How do you like them?

Question: You're a prince of Dorne. A legendary fighter. A brilliant man feared throughout Westeros. But you could not save your sister. I'm a Lannister. Queen for nineteen years. Question: Lord Snow. Are you bringing me back for trial?

Question: Some old man teach you how to stand, how to parry?

Question: What should we do with this lot?
Answer: It's not safe for you here on your own. Mance Rayder has an army heading this way and there's worse out there than Mance. Come with us to Castle Black. We can find you work. Keep you safe.

Question: You want to stay here in Craster's Keep?
Answer: Burn it to the ground and all the dead with it.

Question: What can we do for you, Lord Stannis?
Answer: This is Stannis of the House Baratheon, King of the Andals and the First Men, Lord of the Seven Kingdoms and Protector of the Realm.

Question: And you feel your blood gives you a claim on our gold?

Question: Across the Narrow Sea, your books are filled with words like "usurper" and "madman" and "blood right." Here, our books are filled with numbers. We prefer the stories they tell. More plain. Less open to interpretation. How many fighting men remain loyal to you?
And how many ships do you have? The ones still afloat, Ser Davos, not at the bottom of Blackwater Bay.
And how much wheat and barley and beef and pork do you produce on Dragonstone to feed your 4,000 men on your 32 ships?
Answer: None.

Question: As long as Stannis lives, the war is not over. Who's the real power in King's Landing?
Answer: Ser Davos...

Question: How old is Tywin Lannister?

67. And when he dies, who's in command? A half-grown boy, the product of incest? Cersei Lannister, a queen whose people despise her? Jaime Lannister, a man best known for killing the king he was sworn to protect? When Tywin's gone, who do you back?
Answer: That is a problem for another time.

Question: After the battle, the first mate asks, "Captain, why do you call for your red shirt before battle?" The captain replies, "So that if I am stabbed, you will not see me bleed." The next morning the lookout screams, "10 pirate ships! We are surrounded!" The crew goes silent.
Answer: They all look to their brave captain, waiting for his usual command. Calm as ever, the captain bellows...

Question: You think they ever met a pirate who didn't tell them that joke?
Answer: Davos. I heard you were rotting in a dungeon in Dragonstone.

Question: We?
Answer: You, me-- we.

Question: how fast can you run?
Answer: Make for the ship, now.

Question: Reward?
Answer: Yes, Reek. Those creatures who came in the night, they wanted to take you away. And you didn't let them. You remained loyal.

Question: Do you love me, Reek?
Answer: Yes, of course, my lord.

Question: Pretend to be who?
Answer: Theon Greyjoy.

Question: My father spoke out against crucifying those children. He decried it as a criminal act, but was overruled. Is it justice to answer one crime with another?
Answer: I am sorry you no longer have a father, but my treatment of the masters was no crime. You'd be wise to remember that.

Question: And what traditions do you speak of?
Answer: The tradition of funeral rite. Proper burial in the Temple of the Graces. My father and 162 noble Meereenese are still nailed to those posts, carrion for vultures, rotting in the sun.

Question: And what of the slave children these noble Meereenese crucified? They were rotting in the sun as well. Would you have begged me for their right to a proper burial?
Answer: Your Grace, I cannot defend the actions of the masters. I can only speak to you as a son who loved his father. Let me take his body down. Let me have him brought to the temple and buried with dignity so that he might find peace in the next world.

Question: How many more?
Answer: There are 212 supplicants waiting, Your Grace.
These meetings aren't always going to be this early, are they? I was up late last night. So, does this mean I am a master of something now? Coins, ships?

Question: These meetings aren't always going to be this early, are they? I was up late last night. So, does this mean I am a master of something now? Coins, ships?
Answer: Lord Tywin and I already determined that I shall be the Master of Ships long before you--

Question: The trial begins this afternoon. We only have the morning for affairs of state. Shall we begin?
Answer: Sandor Clegane has been spotted in the Riverlands, my lord.

Question: What would it take to make the common soldier stupid enough to try his luck with the Hound?
Answer: 10 silver stags seems a generous bounty.

Question: Make it 100. What else?
Answer: More whispers from the east, my lord.

Question: The Targaryen girl?
Answer: Daenerys has taken up residence in Meereen. She has conquered the city and rules as its queen.

Question: Conquered with what?
Answer: She commands an army of Unsullied, my queen. Some 8,000 strong. She has a company of sellswords-- the Second Sons. She has two knights advising her-- Jorah Mormont and Barristan Selmy. And she has three dragons.

Question: How, my lord? By force?
Answer: Eventually, if it comes to that. Can your little birds find their way into Meereen?

Question: Eventually, if it comes to that. Can your little birds find their way into Meereen?
Answer: Most certainly, my Lord Hand.

Question: You seem quite knowledgeable about the Unsullied. Did you spend much time in Essos?
Answer: Five years.

Question: May I ask why?
Answer: Tis a big and beautiful world. Most of us live and die in the same corner where we were born and never get to see any of it. I don't want to be most of us.

Question: You are from Essos. Where? Lys?
Answer: I have an ear for accents. I've lost my accent entirely.

Question: I have an ear for that as well. How did you get here?
Answer: It's a long story.

Question: You did like boys before?
Answer: Really? Girls? Hmm. I hope you won't be offended when I say I never would have guessed.

Question: Really? Girls? Hmm. I hope you won't be offended when I say I never would have guessed.
Answer: Not at all. But I was never interested in girls, either.

Question: What then?
Answer: Nothing.

Question: Such as?
Answer: Let me guess, I've been pardoned.

Question: Really?
Answer: Father's orders.

Question: Tyrion of the House Lannister, you stand accused by the Queen Regent of regicide. Did you kill King Joffrey?
Answer: No.

Question: Did your wife, the Lady Sansa?
Answer: Not that I know of.

Question: How would you say he died, then?
Answer: Choked on his pigeon pie.

Question: So you would blame the bakers?
Answer: Or the pigeons. Just leave me out of it.

Question: Oh, why don't you tell them what Joffrey was doing?
Answer: Silence.

Question: By whom?
Answer: By the accused, Tyrion Lannister, after he had me wrongfully imprisoned.

Question: Grand Maester, you examined King Joffrey's corpse. Was it without question poison that killed him?
Answer: Without question.

Question: Was this one of the poisons stolen from your store?
Answer: It was. The Strangler. A poison few in the Seven Kingdoms possess. And used to strike down the most noble child the gods ever put on this good earth.

Question: Your own brother said this to you?
Answer: Shortly before the Battle of Blackwater Bay. I confronted him about his plans to put Joffrey on the front lines. As it turned out, when the attack came, Joff insisted on remaining at the battlements. He believed his presence would inspire the troops.

Question: Tyrion said, "And you will know the debt is paid." What debt?
Answer: I discovered he'd been keeping whores in the Tower of the Hand. I asked him to confine his salacious acts to the brothel where such behavior belongs. He wasn't pleased.

Question: Do you remember the precise nature of this threat?
