Answer: I'm afraid I do, my lord. He said, "Perhaps you should speak more softly to me, then. Monsters are dangerous and just now kings are dying like flies."

Question: And he said this to you at a meeting of the small council?
Answer: Yes. After we received word of Robb Stark's death. He didn't seem gladdened by the news. Perhaps his marriage to Sansa Stark had made him more sympathetic to the northern cause.

Question: Father, may I ask the witness one question?
Answer: One.

Question: You once said that without me, this city would have faced certain defeat. You said the histories would never mention me, but you would not forget. Have you forgotten, Lord Varys?
Answer: Sadly, my lord, I never forget a thing.

Question: You'd condemn your own son to death?
Answer: I've condemned no one. The trial is not over.

Question: As did I. Do you know the last order the Mad King gave me? To bring him your head. I saved your life so you could murder my brother?
Answer: It won't be murder. It'll be justice.

Question: Justice?
Answer: I'm performing my sworn duty as Hand of the King. If Tyrion is found guilty, he will be punished accordingly.

Question: Once you said family is what lives on. All that lives on. You told me about a dynasty that would last 1,000 years. What happens to your dynasty when Tyrion dies? I'm a Kingsguard, forbidden by oath to carry on the family line.
Answer: I'm well aware of your oath.

Question: What happens to your name? Who carries the lion banner into future battles? Your nephews? Lancel Lannister? Others whose names I don't even remember?
Answer: What happens to my dynasty if I spare the life of my grandson's killer?

Question: What happens to my dynasty if I spare the life of my grandson's killer?
Answer: It survives through me. I'll leave the Kingsguard. I'll take my place as your son and heir if you let Tyrion live.

Question: Not going well, is it?
Answer: You're going to be found guilty.

Question: Oh, you think so?
Answer: When you are, you need to enter a formal plea for mercy and ask to be sent to the Wall. Father's agreed to it. He'll spare your life and allow you to join the Night's Watch.

Question: How do you know?
Answer: Do you trust me?

Question: Do you trust me?
Answer: Keep your mouth shut. No more outbursts. This will all be over soon.

Question: Do you swear by all the gods that your testimony will be true and honest?
Answer: I swear it.

Question: Do you know this man?
Answer: Yes. Tyrion Lannister.

Question: How do you know him?
Answer: I was handmaiden to his wife Lady Sansa.

Question: This man stands accused of murdering King Joffrey. What do you know of this?
Answer: I know that he's guilty.

Question: How could you possibly know all this? Why would he reveal such plans to his wife's maid?
Answer: I wasn't just her maid. I was his whore.

Question: I beg your pardon? You said you were his...
Answer: His whore.

Question: How did you come to be in his service?
Answer: He stole me. I was with another man, a knight in your lordship's army. But when Tyrion arrived at the camp, he sent one of his cutthroats into our tent. He broke the knight's arm and brought me to Lord Tyrion. "You belong to me now," he said. "I want you to fuck me like it's my last night in this world."

Question: And did you?
Answer: Did I what?

Question: Did I what?
Answer: Fuck him like it was his last night in this world.

Question: I am a whore. Remember? That was before he married Sansa. After that, all he wanted was her. But she wouldn't let him into her bed. So he promised to kill King Joffrey for her.
Answer: Father, I wish to confess. I wish... to confess.

Question: You wish to confess?
Answer: I saved you. I saved this city and all your worthless lives. I should have let Stannis kill you all.

Question: Tyrion. Do you wish to confess?
Answer: Yes, Father. I'm guilty. Guilty. Is that what you want to hear?

Question: Yes, Father. I'm guilty. Guilty. Is that what you want to hear?
Answer: You admit you poisoned the king?

Question: You admit you poisoned the king?
Answer: No, of that I'm innocent. I'm guilty of a far more monstrous crime. I am guilty of being a dwarf.

Question: Have you nothing to say in your defense?
Answer: Nothing but this-- I did not do it. I did not kill Joffrey, but I wish that I had.

Question: I'm sorry, what am I grateful for? The opportunity to live and die at the Wall as punishment for a crime I did not commit?
Answer: You threw your life away. You threw it away. It's not a joke. You understand that, don't you?

Question: You threw your life away. You threw it away. It's not a joke. You understand that, don't you?
Answer: Of course it's a joke, just not a very funny one. I couldn't- I couldn't listen to her standing there telling her lies. I couldn't do it.

Question: Yes, I fell in love with a whore. And I was stupid enough to think that she had fallen in love with me. That deal you made, it was everything Father wanted. You do see that? He gets you back as his heir. The future Lord of the Rock. And he ships me off to Castle Black, out of sight at last. All so perfect. It felt good to take that from him. He knows I'm innocent and he's willing to sacrifice me anyway. He's willing to sacrifice any of us. Not you. You're the golden son. You could kill a king, lose a hand, fuck your own sister, you'll always be the golden son.
Answer: Careful. I'm the last friend you've got.

Question: Where's your sense of adventure? Even if you lose, imagine the look on Father's face when you fall.
Answer: Our family name snuffed out with a single swing of the sword.

Question: Will you find him for me? Who does Cersei plan on naming as a champion? I hope it's Ser Meryn Trant. I'd enjoy watching Bronn disembowel that pompous child beater.
Answer: No. Not Ser Meryn.

Question: Who am I fighting?
Answer: Does it matter?

Question: Does it matter?
Answer: Could be food.

Question: Where else to sit? Tried to walk back to my hut, hurt too much. Then I remembered they burned my hut down.
Answer: Who were "they"?

Question: Who were "they"?
Answer: I stopped asking a while ago.

Question: A bad way to go. Haven't you had enough?
Answer: Of what? I know. Time to go. Take matters into my own hands. The thought has occurred to me.

Question: Of what? I know. Time to go. Take matters into my own hands. The thought has occurred to me.
Answer: So why go on?

Question: So why go on?
Answer: Habit.

Question: Who are you?
Answer: My name is Arya. Arya Stark.

Question: You her father?
Answer: Her captor. Bringing her to her aunt for ransom.

Question: A fair exchange, that is. Always held to the notion of fair exchange in all my dealings. You give me, I give you. Fair. A balance. No balance anymore. Could I have a drink? Dying is thirsty work.
Answer: Wish it were wine.

Question: The fuck you doing?
Answer: There's a price on your head.

Question: And you thought you were going to collect it? Didn't think very hard, did you?
Answer: You were Yoren's prisoners when he was taking me to the Wall. He told me he'd fuck me bloody with a stick.

Question: This day's really not working out the way you planned. He on your little list?
Answer: He can't be. I don't know his name.

Question: What's your name?
Answer: Rorge.

Question: All right, Jon?
Answer: Welcome back, brother.

Question: I'm surprised you didn't ride over and say hello. The King-beyond-the-Wall is your old friend, isn't he?
Answer: We need to prepare.

Question: And how would we range north?
Answer: We wouldn't.

Question: Coward. You would cut off our legs, pluck out our eyes, leave us cowering behind the Wall hoping for the storm to pass?
Answer: We can't defend the gate against a hundred thousand men.

Question: Have you ever seen a giant, Ser Alliser? I have.
Answer: The bars on those gates are four inches thick. Cold-rolled steel.

Question: Are the stewards responsible for maintaining the tunnel?
Answer: No.

Question: Who would that be?
Answer: The builders.

Question: Ah, the builders. First Builder Yarwyck, Lord Snow here recommends sealing the tunnel, leaving us unable to carry out our duties as sworn brothers of the Night's Watch. Do you agree with him?
Answer: No.

Question: Do you like 'em? Eh? Gloves are doeskin. Softer than a virgin's thighs.
Answer: I sent for you days ago.

Question: Doing what?
Answer: My lonesome bachelor days are over. I'm to wed Lollys Stokeworth.

Question: Lollys Stokeworth? She doesn't strike me as your sort of girl.
Answer: I wouldn't say I had a single sort of girl.

Question: When my sister arranged this love match, did she mention that Lollys has an older sister?
Answer: Falyse. Aye, I did know about the older sister.

Question: And you understand the rules of inheritance?
Answer: Falyse is forty and barren.

Question: What? Ladies fall from their horses and snap their pretty necks all the time.
Answer: You and my sister deserve each other. Why did you bother to come here?

Question: You and my sister deserve each other. Why did you bother to come here?
Answer: You once said if anyone ever asked me to sell you out, you'd double their price.

Question: Is it two wives you want or two castles?
Answer: One of each will do. But if you want me to kill the Mountain for you, it'd better be a damn big castle.

Question: I have gold. What can I buy with gratitude?
Answer: You might be surprised. A Lannister always pays his debts.

Question: Does he frighten you so much?
Answer: I'd be a bloody fool if he didn't frighten me. He's freakish big and freakish strong. And quicker than you'd expect for a man of that size. Maybe I could take him, dance around until he's so tired of hacking at me, he dropped his sword, get him off his feet somehow. But one misstep... and I'm dead. Why should I risk it?

Question: I'd be a bloody fool if he didn't frighten me. He's freakish big and freakish strong. And quicker than you'd expect for a man of that size. Maybe I could take him, dance around until he's so tired of hacking at me, he dropped his sword, get him off his feet somehow. But one misstep... and I'm dead. Why should I risk it?
Answer: Because you're my friend.

Question: Aye, I'm your friend. And when have you ever risked your life for me?
Answer: I like you, pampered little shit that you are. I just like myself more.

Question: Why are you sorry? Because you're an evil bastard with no conscience and no heart? That's what I liked about you in the first place.
Answer: We had some good days together.

Question: What will you do?
Answer: I suppose I'll have to kill the Mountain myself. Won't that make for a great song?

Question: I suppose I'll have to kill the Mountain myself. Won't that make for a great song?
Answer: I hope to hear them sing it one day.

Question: How did you get in here? Your door is well guarded,
Answer: But your window is not.

Question: So if I command you to stay in Meereen and patrol the streets?
Answer: I'll stay in Meereen and patrol the streets. Send me to kill your enemies. Any enemy anywhere. Let me do what I do best.

Question: Could you bring me that vial over there? The blue one.
Answer: No, no, no. Not that one. You don't even want to touch that one. Next to it. That's the one.

Question: If they're lies, my lady, aren't they best avoided?
Answer: Not always.

Question: Did you use it with Stannis?
Answer: No. Don't be upset. Men never crave what they already have.

Question: Why?
Answer: You don't need powders and potions, my queen. You don't need lies. You are strong enough to look into the Lordo s light and see his truth for yourself.

Question: Jorah the Andal. Are you here to see our queen? She's in a good mood.
Answer: Khaleesi.

Question: You don't approve?
Answer: It's not a question of approval, it's a question of trust.

Question: Why would I? The man's a sellsword.
Answer: Didn't you fight for the Golden Company before pledging your sword to my brother?

Question: Didn't you fight for the Golden Company before pledging your sword to my brother?
Answer: I did.

Question: Daario Naharis killed his captains and dumped their heads at your feet when he grew tired of their commands. How could you ever have faith in a man like that?
Answer: I could never have faith in a man like Daario. That's why I've sent him and the Second Sons to retake Yunkai.

Question: You have?
Answer: I have.

Question: And repay the slavers with what? Kindness? A fine? A stern warning?
Answer: It's tempting to see your enemies as evil, all of them, but there's good and evil on both sides in every war ever fought.

Question: Hizdahr zo Loraq?
Answer: He will accompany the Second Sons and serve as my ambassador to Yunkai. He will tell the masters what has happened in Meereen. He will explain the choice they have before them. They can live in my new world or they can die in their old one.

Question: Why?
Answer: Thought I stole one of his toys. I didn't steal it. I was just playing with it. The pain was bad. The smell was worse. But the worst thing was that it was my brother who did it. My father, who protected him... told everyone my bedding caught fire. You think you're on your own?

Question: Thought I stole one of his toys. I didn't steal it. I was just playing with it. The pain was bad. The smell was worse. But the worst thing was that it was my brother who did it. My father, who protected him... told everyone my bedding caught fire. You think you're on your own?
Answer: Let me wash it out and help you sew it up at least.

Question: Can I get you anything else?
Answer: No, this will do nicely, thank you. Kidney pie is wonderful.

Question: A good kidney pie is all about the ingredients. Flour, lard, water, eggs, milk. Easy enough. But the meat, peacetime or not, getting your hands on a good bottom round steak and calves' kidneys is not easy. I mean, some people settle for plain old beef kidneys. Got no right to cook anything, them. Oh, and the gravy. Don't get me started on the gravy. Very difficult to get right. See, a lot of people give up on the gravy. You cannot give up on the gravy. No gravy, no pie. Simple as that. That's nice armor. Are you a knight?
Answer: No.

Question: Oh, it's just people with armor are usually knights. Generally speaking. From King's Landing, though, aren't you? From there myself originally. Flea Bottom born and bred. What brings you to these parts?
Answer: We're looking for someone.

Question: Someone in particular? Maybe they came in here. A lot of people come in here. Just the other day we had seventeen-
Answer: A girl, tall, red hair, very pretty. Her name is Sansa Stark, but she may be using a different name.

Question: Starks? What, like them lot from "Winterhell"?
Answer: No, ain't seen anyone like that. I heard they was all traitors. Don't need no traitors in here.

Question: Sure I can't get you a bit more kidney pie?
Answer: What?

Question: What?
Answer: It's nothing, my lady.

Question: My lady. My lord. Could I have a word?
Answer: What about? Not kidney pie.

Question: What about? Not kidney pie.
Answer: You seem like a proper lady. Someone who could be trusted. I never met no Sansa Stark. But I know her sister... Arya.

Question: When was that?
Answer: Heading up north with the Night's Watch. She was all dressed up as a boy. Like your ladyship, only without the armor. Going by the name Arry.

Question: So what happened to her?
Answer: Well-

Question: That's the one. If you find her, could you give her this? She liked the last one I gave her, but, well, this one turned out better.
Answer: Um, you were saying?

Question: Um, you were saying?
Answer: Her mother's dead, grandfather's dead, Walder Frey is the new lord of Riverrun. The Brotherhood isn't going to Riverrun.

Question: Why the Eyrie?
Answer: Her aunt, Lysa Arryn. Catelyn Stark's sister. She's Arya's last living relative with money. She hates the Lannisters. Lord Tyrion made sure I knew which house married which and who hated who.

Question: You sure about this?
Answer: No.

Question: And what about what I want? Justice for my sister and her children.
Answer: If you want justice, you've come to the wrong place.

Question: What are you doing?
Answer: I'm building my home, Winterfell. At least I think I am. I haven't been back there in a very long time.

Question: Why did you leave?
Answer: It's a long story.

Question: When will you go back?
Answer: Probably never. My family doesn't live there anymore and someone burned it down.

Question: Oh. Does Winterfell have a Moon Door?
Answer: No, I'm afraid not. It's not high up in the mountains. It's down on the ground.

Question: That sounds dangerous. How do you make people fly?
Answer: We don't.

Question: What do you do with all the bad people and the scary people and the people you don't like?
Answer: I never did anything with them at all. Girls didn't take part in that where I came from.

Question: Why did you really kill Joffrey? Tell me why.
Answer: I loved your mother more than you could ever know. Given the opportunity, what do we do to those who've hurt the ones we love? In a better world, one where love could overcome strength and duty, you might have been my child. But we don't live in that world.

Question: I loved your mother more than you could ever know. Given the opportunity, what do we do to those who've hurt the ones we love? In a better world, one where love could overcome strength and duty, you might have been my child. But we don't live in that world.
Answer: You're more beautiful than she ever was.

Question: You wanted to see me, Aunt Lysa?
Answer: Come here, Sansa.

Question: Do you know how far the fall is?
Answer: No.

Question: You want her? This empty-headed child?
Answer: Let her go.

Question: She's just like her mother. She'll never love you. I lied for you. I killed for you. Why did you bring her here? Why?
Answer: I'll send her away. I swear on my life. I swear to all the gods. Let her go, Lysa.

Question: There's a man with an ear. Too bad you've got a hangnail for a cock. First time I saw you with your britches down, I thought you were a eunuch! You seen it girls. Like a baby snail peekin' out of his shell. *laughs and walks toward Gilly* *to Gilly* Your baby was crying this morning. It waked me up. You hear me?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Well, what are you going to say?
Answer: I'm sorry it woke you up.

Question: Hehehe, little Wildling bitch. You shouldo ve stayed with your own kind. *an owl hoots in the distance* Are you listening to me?
Answer: Shut your mouth.

Question: What? It's just an owl you dumb bitch.
Answer: No it's not.

Question: And we just cower in here while they slaughter our brothers?
Answer: Our brothers had orders to stay at Castle Black.

Question: Oh, so it's alright then?! Black Jack and Kegs and Mully chopped to pieces 'cause they broke the rules?!
Answer: I didn't say it was alright! I'm sayin' they shouldn't have been there.

Question: How do a hundred and two men stop a thousand?
Answer: Whoever dies last, be a good lad and burn the rest of us. Once I'm done with this world, I don't want to come back.

Question: You think he was spying on you?
Answer: No, not spying.

Question: What?
Answer: I believe he was interested.

Question: When the slavers castrate the boys, do they take all of it?
Answer: All of it?

Question: All of it?
Answer: The...the pillar an the stones.

Question: Haven't you ever wondered?
Answer: Yes, your grace.

Question: Do you remember the name you were given at birth?
Answer: I remember nothing. Only unsullied.

Question: When they cut you, do you remember that?
Answer: I'm sorry. I'm sorry they did that to you.

Question: Why? Why sorry?
Answer: It's a terrible thing to do to a boy.

Question: Bracken. Mmm, strong. As long as they're in the see. But when you take them out of the water, no bones. They collapse under their proud weight and slum into a heap of nothing. You'd think they'd know that. Unfortunately they're not very bright. What do you tell them?
Answer: I'm Theon Greyjoy, son of Balon, heir to the Iron Islands.

Question: And what are you really?
Answer: I'm Reek.

Question: Are you sure? You do look very much like a lord. Formidable, proud.
Answer: Until when?

Question: Until when?
Answer: Always. Forever.

Question: to Theon* No closer. Who are you?
Answer: I'm Kenning, commander of this garrison. And you say you're Theon Greyjoy?

Question: I'm Kenning, commander of this garrison. And you say you're Theon Greyjoy?
Answer: Yes.

Question: And why should I believe that?
Answer: I was born on Pike to Balon Greyjoy. His third and last-living son. I am your prince. I swear it by the drowned god. What is dead may never die.

Question: And if you were my prince, why are you marching with a Bolton army?
Answer: Lord Bolton took me captive after Winterfell. He sent me to treat with you in good faith as your fellow Ironborn.

Question: And what does Lord Bolton want?
Answer: You are fading from sickness. You are badly outnumbered and you're hundreds of miles from the sea. Lord Bolton implores you to protect your men and abandon this fortress you can no longer hold. Do this and he will be just and fair with you as he is being with me. The Boltons will give you safe passage to the stony shore.

Question: He wants us to surrender?
Answer: My own father, your king, surrendered years ago to Robert Baratheon. I watched him bend the knee. There was no shame there. He fought with honor, as did you.

Question: No shame fought with honor. Only a whipped dog would speak this way. Or a woman. Are you a woman boy?
Answer: scared* You don't know.

Question: You go tell your master that, Theon Greyjoy. Or whoever the fuck you are. What in the hell are you muttering?
Answer: Reek.

Question: If we yield, we live? Is that what it says on this paper here?
Answer: Yes. Have your men raise the white flag and open the gates. You're going home.

Question: You didn't really think I'd let them go did you? It's falling out of fashion. Fileting. Sad, but true. Traditions are important. Where are we without our history, eh?
Answer: Yes m'lord. Will we go home now?

Question: Yes m'lord. Will we go home now?
Answer: I believe we will. To our new home.

Question: And when Jon Arryn named you Master of Coin, no one cared. Always been a grubby job. Why not let a grubby man do it? But when I heard you were lurking here, fawning over the Lady Arryn...
Answer: Lady Arryn invited me. She and I have been close since childhood.

Question: She was an odd fish. Everyone knew that. But suicide? She adored that boy of hers. I don't see her abandoning him. Not by choice.
Answer: Strange that within days of your arrival, you've married Lady Arryn and she's fallen through the Moon Door.

Question: Come closer, child. You have nothing to fear from us or him. Lord Baelish here is your uncle? Your name is Alayne? Perhaps you would feel more comfortable if Lord Baelish left the room.
Answer: My lady...

Question: Sansa Stark? You tell lies right to my face, you little worm?
Answer: Lord Baelish has told many lies. All to protect me. Since my father was executed, I have been a hostage in King's Landing. A plaything for Joffrey to torture or Queen Cersei to torment. They beat me, they humiliated me, they married me to the Imp. I had no friends in King's Landing...except one. He saved me. Smuggled me away when he had the chance. He knew I'd be safe here in the Eyrie with my own blood, my Aunt Lysa. The Lannisters have friends everywhere. Even the Vale. He made me swear not to tell anyone my true name.

Question: Not much justice to be meted out in suicide, is there?
Answer: For Lysa, no. But for her son? Only 20 years ago, the knights of the Vale rode behind Jon Arryn, Ned Stark, Robert Baratheon. They fought together to overcome the Mad King. And since then, Arryn and Royce, Corbray, Waynwood, all the great houses of the Vale watched from the corner. A timid boy at a tavern brawl.

Question: For Lysa, no. But for her son? Only 20 years ago, the knights of the Vale rode behind Jon Arryn, Ned Stark, Robert Baratheon. They fought together to overcome the Mad King. And since then, Arryn and Royce, Corbray, Waynwood, all the great houses of the Vale watched from the corner. A timid boy at a tavern brawl.
Answer: Are you questioning our courage?

Question: Are you questioning our courage?
Answer: I want to know which side you're on. Do you support the Lannisters, the house that executed your friend Ned Stark?

Question: I want to know which side you're on. Do you support the Lannisters, the house that executed your friend Ned Stark?
Answer: Of course we don't support the damn Lannisters.

Question: No? Catelyn Stark begged her sister for support and Lysa refused. By staying out of the fray, you've allowed Tywin Lannister to destroy his rivals on every compass point. Who stands against him now?
Answer: Who would you have us back, Lord Baelish? Robb Stark is dead.

Question: Who would you have us back, Lord Baelish? Robb Stark is dead.
Answer: I'd have you back Robin Arryn, Lord of the Vale.

Question: Yes? Who sent you?
Answer: Ser Barristan.

Question: Have I forgotten a council meeting?
Answer: No.

Question: What's this?
Answer: A royal pardon signed by Robert Baratheon. You spied on her.

Question: Who gave you this?
Answer: Does it matter?

Question: Does it matter?
Answer: Have you told her?

Question: Have you told her?
Answer: I wanted to tell you first, man-to-man rather than go behind your back.

Question: Why did the usurper pardon you?
Answer: If we could speak alone.

Question: Who do you think sent this to Meereen? Who profits? This is the work of Tywin Lannister. He wants to divide us. If we're fighting each other, we're not fighting him.
Answer: The pardon was signed the year we met. Why were you pardoned? Unless you're saying this document was forged.

Question: The pardon was signed the year we met. Why were you pardoned? Unless you're saying this document was forged.
Answer: It is not forged.

Question: Why, then?
Answer: I sent letters to Varys, the spymaster of King's Landing.

Question: What was the content of these letters?
Answer: Information.

Question: What information?
Answer: When you and Viserys arrived in Pentos. His plan to marry you to Khal Drogo. When you were married. When your brother died.

Question: You told him I was carrying Drogo's child?
Yes or no?
Answer: Khaleesi.

Question: Don't call me that. Did you tell him I was carrying Drogo's child?
Answer: Yes.

Question: and you want me to forgive you?
Answer: I have loved you.

Question: Love? Love? How can you say that to me? Any other man, and I would have you executed. But you, I do not want you in my city dead or alive. Go back to your masters in King's Landing. Collect your pardon if you can.
Answer: Daenerys, please.

Question: Walk with me. Has there been any word from Locke?
Answer: No.

Question: Not nothing. The North. Ride 700 miles that way, you're still in the North. 400 miles that way. 300 miles that way. The North is larger than the other six kingdoms combined. And I am the Warden of the North. The North is mine. Now tell me, what is your name?
Answer: Ramsay Snow.

Question: Yes?
Answer: First time I saw you, you were just a child. A girl from the North come to the capital for the first time. Not a child any longer. Why did you help me?

Question: First time I saw you, you were just a child. A girl from the North come to the capital for the first time. Not a child any longer. Why did you help me?
Answer: They would have thrown you through the Moon Door if they found you guilty.

Question: If they'd have executed you, what would they have done with me?
Answer: I don't know.

Question: Better to gamble on the man you know than the strangers you don't? And you think you know me?
Answer: I know what you want.

Question: Do you?
Answer: I thought it'd make me happy, but it doesn't. Not really. Nothing makes you happy.

Question: Like what?
Answer: Killing Polliver, killing Rorge.

Question: So you're sad because you didn't get to kill Joffrey yourself. Is that it?
Answer: At least I could have been there to watch. I wanted to see the look in his eyes when he knew it was over.

Question: You protected him for most of his life. You think you could have saved him?
Answer: I wasn't the damn wine taster. Little shit deserved to die, but poison...poison's a woman's weapon. Men kill with steel.

Question: You really think my aunt will pay for me?
Answer: Aye, she'll pay.

Question: Who would pass the Bloody Gate?
Answer: The bloody Hound, Sandor Clegane. And his...traveling companion Arya Stark, niece of your lady Lysa Arryn.

Question: Shall we go?
Answer: Wine always helps. I thank you for it. Trial by combat. Deciding a man's guilt or innocence in the eyes of the gods by having two other men hack each other to pieces. Tells you something about the gods. How much longer?

Question: Wine always helps. I thank you for it. Trial by combat. Deciding a man's guilt or innocence in the eyes of the gods by having two other men hack each other to pieces. Tells you something about the gods. How much longer?
Answer: Soon.

Question: Do you think Oberyn has a chance? The Red Viper of Dorne. You don't get a name like that unless you're deadly, right?
Answer: I've never seen him fight.

Question: That's putting it mildly. What's the punishment for regicide? Drawing and quartering? Hanging? Breaking at the wheel?
Answer: Beheading.

Question: Seems rather ordinary. And he was my nephew as well, so what is that? Fratricide is brothers. Filicide is sons. Nepoticide. That's the one. Matricide, patricide, infanticide, suicide. There's no kind of killing that doesn't have its own word.
Answer: Cousins.

Question: Cousins, you're right. There is no word for cousin killing. Well done. Do you remember cousin Orson? Orson Lannister?
Answer: Of course. Wet-nurse dropped him on his head. Left him simple.

Question: Simple? Used to sit all day in the garden. Crushing beetles with a rock.
Answer: Khuu! Khuu! Khuu!

Question: Why?
Answer: I was curious. Why was he smashing all those beetles? What did he get out of it? First thing I did was ask him. "Orson, why are you smashing all those beetles?" He gave me an answer. "Smash the beetles. Smash 'em. Khuu! Khuu! Khuu!" I wasn't deterred. I was the smartest person I knew. Certainly I had the wherewithal to unravel the mysteries that lay at the heart of a moron. So I went to Maester Volarik's library.

Question: I was curious. Why was he smashing all those beetles? What did he get out of it? First thing I did was ask him. "Orson, why are you smashing all those beetles?" He gave me an answer. "Smash the beetles. Smash 'em. Khuu! Khuu! Khuu!" I wasn't deterred. I was the smartest person I knew. Certainly I had the wherewithal to unravel the mysteries that lay at the heart of a moron. So I went to Maester Volarik's library.
Answer: Volarik. Tried to touch me once.

Question: Turns out, far too much has been written about great men and not nearly enough about morons. Doesn't seem right. In any case, I found nothing that illuminated the nature of Orson's affliction or the reason behind his relentless beetle slaughter. So I went back to the source. I may not have been able to speak with Orson, but I could observe him, watch him the way men watch animals to come to a deeper understanding of their behavior. *picks up a beetle* And as I watched, I became more and more sure of it. There was something happening there. His face was like the page of a book written in a language I didn't understand. But he wasn't mindless. He had his reasons. And I became possessed with knowing what they were. I began to spend inordinate amounts of time watching him. I would eat my lunch in the garden, chewing my mutton to the music of "khuu, khuu, khuu". And when I wasn't watching him, I was thinking about him. Father droned on about the family legacy and I thought about Orson's beetles. I read the histories of Targaryen conquests. Did I hear dragon wings? No. I heard "khuu, khuu, khuu" and I still couldn't figure out why he was doing it. And I had to know, because it was horrible that all these beetles should be dying for no reason.
Answer: Every day around the world, men, women, and children are murdered by the score. Who gives a dusty fuck about a bunch of beetles?

Question: Every day around the world, men, women, and children are murdered by the score. Who gives a dusty fuck about a bunch of beetles?
Answer: I know, I know. But still, it filled me with dread. Piles and piles of them, years and years of them. How many countless living crawling things smashed and dried out and returned to the dirt? In my dreams I found myself standing on a beach made of beetle husks stretching as far as the eye could see. I woke up crying, weeping for their shattered little bodies. I tried to stop Orson once.

Question: I know, I know. But still, it filled me with dread. Piles and piles of them, years and years of them. How many countless living crawling things smashed and dried out and returned to the dirt? In my dreams I found myself standing on a beach made of beetle husks stretching as far as the eye could see. I woke up crying, weeping for their shattered little bodies. I tried to stop Orson once.
Answer: He was twice your size.

Question: He just pushed me aside with a "khuu" and kept on smashing. Every day until that mule kicked him in the chest and killed him. *puts the beetle back on the ground* So what do you think? Why did he do it? What was it all about?
Answer: I don't know.

Question: You learn this during your years in the fighting pits? I always drink before a fight.
Answer: It could get you killed. It could get me killed.

Question: You're going to fight that?
Answer: I'm going to kill that.

Question: Have they told you who I am?
Answer: Some dead man.

Question: I am the brother of Elia Martell. Do you know why I have come all the way to this stinking shit-pile of a city? For you.
Answer: I'm going to hear you confess before you die. You raped my sister. You murdered her. You killed her children. Say it now and we can make this quick.

Question: Wait. Are you dying? No, no, no. You can't die yet. You haven't confessed. Say it. Say her name. Elia Martell. You raped her. You killed her children. Elia Martell. Who gave you the order? Who gave you the order?! Say her name! You raped her! You murdered her! You killed her children. Say it. Say her name. Say it!
Answer: Elia Martell. I killed her children. Then I raped her. Then I smashed her head in like this!

Question: What was she like?
Answer: She...she had red hair.

Question: Oh? How big were her feet?
Answer: Well what do you want me to say?

Question: Well what do you want me to say?
Answer: I want you to tell me what it was like to have someone. To be with someone. To love someone and have them love you back. We're all gonna die a lot sooner than I'd planned. You're the closest I'll ever get to know it.

Question: But if she had, you wouldo ve? You'd have broken your vows?
Answer: The interesting thing is, our vows never specifically forbid intimate relations with women.

Question: What?
Answer: I shall take no wife" yes, that's in there, there's no denying that. "I shall father no children" it's very specific. But what our vows have to say about other...activities...is open to interpretation.

Question: Anyway, there's nothing for him to interpret. We didn't. So what's it like?
Answer: It's...there's this person, this whole other person. And you're wrapped up in them and they're wrapped up in you and...you...for a little...for a little while you're more than just you, you're...well I don't know, I'm not a bleedin' poet!

Question: And what did I get for it? An arrow six inches from my heart.
Answer: There'll be arrows for all of us soon I imagine.

Question: Did I ever tell you about her? My Sheila?
Answer: Yes.

Question: And more words. Know what I think you do when you see him? Serve him up a nice juicy slice of ginger minge.
Answer: What, you been thinkin' about that ginger minge? Wondering what it tastes like?

Question: What, you been thinkin' about that ginger minge? Wondering what it tastes like?
Answer: Maybe I have.

Question: And what is it that couldn't wait until morning, Tarly?
Answer: Maester Aemon. How did you know-

Question: That it was you? Who else but Samwell Tarly would be wasting candles to read in the middle of the night?
Answer: Let me help you.

Question: Oh, no need. I know my way around this library better than any other place in Castle Black. Thousands of books and no eyes to read them. Old age is a wonderful source of ironies if nothing else. But you didn't answer my question, what are you reading?
Answer: Maester Faull

Question: You were?
Answer: You can imagine all manner of horrors befalling that poor girl and her child, is it so difficult to imagine that an old person was once, more or less, like you?

Question: You can imagine all manner of horrors befalling that poor girl and her child, is it so difficult to imagine that an old person was once, more or less, like you?
Answer: I'm sorry Maester, I didn't mean it like that.

Question: You know who I was before I came here? What I couldo ve been if I'd only said the word? Of course you do. I met many girls when I was Aemon Targaryen. A future king always does. Some of them were quite forward in their attempts to win my affections. One of them succeeded. I was very young.
Answer: Who was she?

Question: Who was she?
Answer: Ah ha. I could tell you everything about her. Who she was. How we met. The color of her eyes and the shape of her nose. I can see her right in front of me. She's more real than you are. We could spend all night trading tales of lost love. Nothing makes the past a sweeter place to visit than the prospect of imminent death. Go to bed Tarly.

Question: Sam, is that you?!
Answer: Yes!

Question: Are you alright? Shh, you're alright. Yeah, of course you are my brave little fella.
Answer: It was horrible.

Question: A hundred thousand you say?
Answer: Yes sir.

Question: Do you know what leadership means, Lord Snow? It means that the person in charge gets second-guessed by every clever little twat with a mouth. But if he starts second-guessing himself, that's the end. For him. For the clever little twats. For everyone. This is not the end. Not for us. Not if you lot do your duty for however long it takes to beat them back. And then you get to go on hating me and I get to go on wishing your Wildling whore had finished the job.
Answer: You'll be safe down here. I'll check on you as soon as I can.

Question: You're leaving me again?
Answer: I'm not leaving you!

Question: What are you going to do out there?
Answer: Help my brothers.

Question: How?! You going to fight the Free Folk when they come? They'll kill you. In Molestown they killed everyone.
Answer: I can't just hide here with you while they're fighting out there.

Question: Why not? You won't matter up there, you will down here.
Answer: Look. I am a man of the Night's Watch, Gilly. I made a promise to defend The Wall and I have to keep it, because that's what men do.

Question: I've never thrown a spear before. I've never held a sword with a proper edge. There's no place for me to be. You're not afraid?
Answer: Of course I'm afraid, there's a band of Wildlings coming to kill us.

Question: Well if you're afraid of a band of Wildlings, how in seven hells did you manage to kill a White Walker?
Answer: I didn't know I was going to kill it, but I had to do something I didn't have any choice, he was going to kill Gilly and take the baby. If someone had asked me my name right then, I wouldn't have known. I wasn't Samwell Tarly anymore. I wasn't a Steward in the Night's Watch or son of Randyll Tarly or any of that. I was nothing at all. And when you're nothing at all, there's no more reason to be afraid.

Question: But you're afraid now?
Answer: Yes, well, I'm not nothing anymore.

Question: How high are the walls?
Answer: Well, we'll be up and over before they know what's happened.

Question: I said knock and hold you cunts! Does knock mean draw?!
Answer: No Ser!

Question: Does fucking hold mean fucking drop?!
Answer: You all plan to die here tonight?

Question: You all plan to die here tonight?
Answer: That's very good to hear. Draw!

Question: Now?
Answer: Now!

Question: What?!
Answer: What are you fucking waiting for, loose!

Question: Did you get one?
Answer: No. Ah shit, Pyp. Shit. Sam.

Question: Yeah?
Answer: I think we're gonna die.

Question: Brothers! A hundred generations have defended this castle. We've never fallen before. She will not fall tongiht. Those are Things at our walls. They eat the flesh of the men they kill. Do you want to fill the belly of a Thing tonight?
Answer: No!

Question: Those are giants riding mammoths down there. Do you think your cold, rolled steel's gonna stop them?
Answer: No such thing as giants. They're stories for the children.

Question: Needed below? Yes. Yes.
Answer: Archers! Knock your arrows! Draw! Loose!

Question: How do you know that?
Answer: Because I've made that claim.

Question: Oh, is it over?
Answer: Huh?

Question: Huh?
Answer: Well then. *hands Pyp a loaded crossbow*

Question: to Olly* Get me to the top! You hear me?!
Answer: Your name's Olly, right? Listen to me Olly, get me to the top and when we give a signal, bring us back down. Do you hear me?

Question: Your name's Olly, right? Listen to me Olly, get me to the top and when we give a signal, bring us back down. Do you hear me?
Answer: And find a weapon, Olly. Fight them!

Question: What are you doing up here?
Answer: The Wildlings are over the walls. Ser Alliser has fallen. The castle walls can't stand much longer.

Question: Might as well enjoy our last night, right boys? Light the fuckers up. Knock! Draw! Loose!
Answer: How are we gonna stop that?

Question: How are we gonna stop that?
Answer: We shot twenty-eight arrows in him already.

Question: The gods aren't down here. It's the six of us, you hear me?
Answer: No, please.

Question: Do you remember that cave?
Answer: We shouldo ve stayed in that cave.

Question: Woah! It's me. It's me. I promised you, didn't I?
Answer: We held them off.

Question: Great victory? Mance was testing our defenses. He almost made it through. And he has more giants, he has more mammoths. He has a thousand times as many men. They'll hit us again tonight. Maybe we can hold them off for a day or two, but we can never beat them.
Answer: Where are you going?

Question: Where are you going?
Answer: I'm going to find Mance.

Question: Who's left to give orders? The Wildling army is only an army because of Mance. He united a hundred warring tribes. Without Mance they lose their leader. They lose their purpose, they go back to fighting each other, scatter back to their home.
Answer: Without Mance? You're going to kill him?

Question: Without Mance? You're going to kill him?
Answer: I'm going to try.

Question: You're right. It's a bad plan. What's your plan?
Answer: They held the gate. Get some brothers down here to help you. You need to burn the bodies. Raise the outer gate, then lower it again as soon as I'm out.

Question: What are you doing?
Answer: I promised Jeor I'd never lose it again. *he hands the sword to Sam* In case I don't come back.

Question: All of your vows? She wasn't enough to turn ya, eh? Were you enough to turn her?
Answer: She put three arrows in me when I escaped.

Question: Did you see her again at Castle Black?
Answer: Yes.

Question: And?
Answer: She's dead.

Question: Your doing?
Answer: No.

Question: Kullback, could I trouble you for something to eat? I don't imagine our guest has eaten anything in quite some time. So. You're here to strike a bargain?
Answer: Turn your army around and go home.

Question: You know I know you're low on arrows. You're low on oil. You're low on men. How many are left? 50?
Answer: I told Tormund and Orell. We have more than a thousand men.

Question: I showed you everything I had. The whole army, a hundred thousand strong, and what did you do? You fired on us with everything you had. It wasn't much. Soon as I saw that I sent four hundred men to climb the wall. An unmanned stretch five miles west of here. A lot of them will die climbing, but most of them will be over by the end of the day. This is me being honest with you, Jon Snow, which is more than you've ever done for me. My people have bled enough. We're not here to conquer, we're here to hide behind your wall just like you. We need your tunnel. Now we both know that winter is coming and if my people aren't south of the wall when it comes in earnest, we'll all end up worse than dead. Wanna strike a bargain with me? Here's a bargain. You go back, you open the gates to us and I swear to you that no one else will die. Refuse and we'll kill every last man in Castle Black.
Answer: Ah! Oh, that's why you're here. I reckon you could do it before any of them could stop ya. They'd kill you of course, they'd kill ya slow, but ya knew that when you came in here. Are you capable of that, Jon Snow? Killing a man in his own tent when he's just offered ya peace? Is that what the Night's Watch is? Is that what you are?

Question: Ah! Oh, that's why you're here. I reckon you could do it before any of them could stop ya. They'd kill you of course, they'd kill ya slow, but ya knew that when you came in here. Are you capable of that, Jon Snow? Killing a man in his own tent when he's just offered ya peace? Is that what the Night's Watch is? Is that what you are?
Answer: You attacking us?

Question: You attacking us?
Answer: No, it's like you said, we don't have the men.

Question: You're the king beyond the wall?
Answer: You know who I am?

Question: You know who I am?
Answer: Never had the pleasure.

Question: What are men of the Night's Watch doing in a Wildling camp?
Answer: I was sent to discuss terms with the king beyond the wall.

Question: What do you think he'd have done with him?
Answer: I was this man's prisoner once. He couldo ve tortured me, he couldo ve killed me, but he spared my life. I think my father wouldo ve taken him prisoner, listened to what he had to say.

Question: May I ask what you think you're doing?
Answer: Saving him.

Question: You can save him?
Answer: Difficult to say, your grace, but if my past work is any guide. We stand a chance.

Question: Will it weaken him?
Answer: Oh no.

Question: Do you think you'll be the first person dragged into a sept to be married against her will?
Answer: When you marched into the throne room to tell me we'd won the Battle at Blackwater, do you remember?! I was sitting on the iron throne with Tommen. I was about to give him essence of nightshade, that's how far I was willing to go when I thought someone awful had come to take my son away. Someone awful is coming to take him away.

Question: When you marched into the throne room to tell me we'd won the Battle at Blackwater, do you remember?! I was sitting on the iron throne with Tommen. I was about to give him essence of nightshade, that's how far I was willing to go when I thought someone awful had come to take my son away. Someone awful is coming to take him away.
Answer: No.

Question: And how will you do that?
Answer: I'll tell everyone the truth.

Question: And what truth would that be?
Answer: You don't know, do you? You never believed it. How is that possible? What am I saying, of course it's possible. How can someone so consumed by the idea of his family have any conception what his actual family was doing? We were right there in front of you and you didn't see us. One look in the past twenty years, one real look and you wouldo ve known.

Question: You don't know, do you? You never believed it. How is that possible? What am I saying, of course it's possible. How can someone so consumed by the idea of his family have any conception what his actual family was doing? We were right there in front of you and you didn't see us. One look in the past twenty years, one real look and you wouldo ve known.
Answer: Known what?

Question: Known what?
Answer: Everything they say is true. About Jaime and me.

Question: You won. One fewer brother. Must be proud of yourself. There's really nothing you wouldn't do, is there?
Answer: For my family, no. I would do things for my family you couldn't imagine.

Question: Are you really mad enough to blame him for that? He didn't decide to kill her. He was an infant.
Answer: A disease doesn't decide to kill you, all the same you cut it out before it does. What do you decide? What do you choose?

Question: A disease doesn't decide to kill you, all the same you cut it out before it does. What do you decide? What do you choose?
Answer: The things I did to get back to you, to endure all that, only to find you-

Question: Told him what?
Answer: I told him about us.

Question: You told him?
Answer: I told him I wouldn't marry Loras Tyrell. I told him I'm staying right here with Tommen, with you.

Question: You think he'll just accept that?
Answer: Go and ask him.

Question: What did you say?
Answer: I don't want to talk about Tywin Lannister. I don't choose Tywin Lannister, I don't love Tywin Lannister. I love my brother. I love my lover. People will whisper, they'll make their jokes. Let them. They're all so small I can't even see them. I only see what matters.

Question: I hope I can prove worthy of her admiration. What can I do for you?
Answer: When you took the city, the children begged me not to leave the house. But Master Mighdal and I agreed that I must. So I lost my home. Now I live on the streets.

Question: Even if they are safe, who would I be there? What purpose would I serve? With my master, I was a teacher. I had the respect and love of these children.
Answer: What is it that you want from me?

Question: What is it that you want from me?
Answer: Your grace, I ask you to let me sell myself back to Master Mighdal.

Question: You want to return to a man who owned you, like a goat or a chair?
Answer: Please, your grace, the young may rejoice in the new world you've built for them. But for those of us too old to change there is only fear and squalor. I am not alone. There are many outside waiting to beg the same-

Question: What was her name?
Answer: Zala, your grace.

Question: How old was she?
Answer: Three.

Question: Three. *in Valyrian* And still no word on Drogon?
Answer: in Valyrian* Sailors saw him flying over the Black Cliffs three days ago, my queen. Nothing since then.

Question: Your old blind man patched me up. Why?
Answer: He's sworn to treat all wounded men, friend or foe.

Question: You want me alive so you can torture me?
Answer: No one's going to torture you.

Question: So how do we die? Hanging? Beheading? Drop us from the top of the wall?
Answer: I don't know what happens to the prisoners.

Question: Who decides?
Answer: I suppose Stannis does.

Question: He your king now?
Answer: I don't have a king.

Question: We're gonna burn the bodies of your dead. Do you want to say any words over them?
Answer: Words? What kind of words?

Question: Words? What kind of words?
Answer: Funeral words. I don't know how the Free Folk do it.

Question: Do what?
Answer: Say farewell.

Question: Snow. Did you love her? She loved you.
Answer: She told you?

Question: She told you?
Answer: No. All she ever talked about was killing you. That's how I know. She belongs in the North. The real North. You understand me?

Question: No. All she ever talked about was killing you. That's how I know. She belongs in the North. The real North. You understand me?
Answer: We can stop, we can rest.

Question: Who are you?
Answer: The First Men called us The Children, but we were born long before them. Come, he waits for you.

Question: How do you know?
Answer: I've been watching you. All of you, all of your lives, with a thousand eyes and one. Now you've come to me at last, Brandon Stark, though the hour is late.

Question: You're going to help me walk again?
Answer: You'll never walk again. But you will fly.

Question: Podrick. Podrick! Where are the horses?
Answer: I hobbled them last night.

Question: What sort of hobble?
Answer: A figure-eight, like you taught me.

Question: Thieves, maybe?
Answer: It's at least thirty miles to the Eyrie from here. You're carrying the saddle bags.

Question: I like your sword. Are we getting close to the bloody gate?
Answer: About ten more miles.

Question: Did you hear that Podrick? Only about ten more miles to the Bloody Gate.
Answer: Are you a knight?

Question: Are you a knight?
Answer: No.

Question: Does it have a name?
Answer: Oathkeeper.”

Question: Who taught you how to fight?
Answer: My father.

Question: You want something?
Answer: That's Sandor Clegane- the Hound.

Question: Why didn't you?
Answer: She commanded me to bring Jaime Lannister back to King's Landing.

Question: No? Fancy sword you've got there. Where'd you get it? I've been looking at Lannister gold all my life. Go on, Brienne of fucking Tarth, tell me that's not Lannister gold.
Answer: Jaime Lannister gave me this sword.

Question: Safety?! Where the fuck's that? Her aunt in the Eyrie's dead. Her mother's dead, her father's dead, her brother's dead. Winterfell's a pile of rubble. There's no safety, you dumb bitch. If you don't know that by now, you're the wrong one to watch over her.
Answer: And that's what you're doing? Watching over her?

Question: And that's what you're doing? Watching over her?
Answer: Aye, that's what I'm doing.

Question: Arya! Arya! ARYA! Where is she?
Answer: She was just here...

Question: Why weren't you watching her?
Answer: I was watching you I thought you migth need some help…

Question: Which way Pod? Which way did she go?
Answer: Ah, I think that way.

Question: You're still here? [Coughs] Big bitch saved you.
Answer: I don't need saving.

Question: You're gonna die?
Answer: Unless there's a Maester hiding behind that rock, aye, I'm done. I'd skin you alive for wine. [Arya offers water.] Fuck water! Killed by a woman. I bet you liked that. Go on, go after her. She'll help you. Going out alone, you won't last a day out there.

Question: You remember where the heart is? Fuck it. I'm ready. Go on, girl. Another name off your list. You kept promising me. I cut down your butcher's boy, the ginger. He was begging for mercy. Please sir, please don't kill me, please, please. Bled all over my horse. Saddle stunk of butcher's boy for weeks. And your sister, your pretty sister. I shouldo ve taken her. That night the Blackwater burned, I shouldo ve fucked her bloody. At least I'd have one happy memory! Do I have to beg you? Do it. Do it.
Answer: Kill me. Kill me! Kill me! Kill me!

Question: Is that any way to speak about our mother?
Answer: What're you doing?

Question: What're you doing?
Answer: What do you think I'm doing? The galley's waiting in the bay bound for the Free Cities.

Question: What do you think I'm doing? The galley's waiting in the bay bound for the Free Cities.
Answer: Who's helping you?

Question: Who's helping you?
Answer: Varys.

Question: Varys?
Answer: You have more friends than you thought.

Question: Tyrion! Put down the crossbow. Who released you? Ah, your brother ,I expect. He always had a soft spot for you. Come, we'll go and talk in my chambers. Is this how you want to speak to me? Shaming your father has always given you pleasure…
Answer: All my life, you've wanted me dead.

Question: Yes. But you refused to die. I respect that, even admire it. You fight for what's yours. I'd never let them execute you; is that what you fear? I'd never let Illyn Payne take your head. You're a Lannister. You're my son.
Answer: I loved her.

Question: Who?
Answer: Shae.

Question: It doesn't matter?
Answer: She was a whore!

Question: And what? You'll kill your own father in the privy? No. You're my son. Enough of this nonsense…
Answer: I am your son, and you sentenced me to die. You knew I didn't poison Joffrey, but you sentenced me all the same. Why?

Question: I am your son, and you sentenced me to die. You knew I didn't poison Joffrey, but you sentenced me all the same. Why?
Answer: Enough. We'll go back to my chambers and speak with some dignity.

Question: What, are you afraid of a dead whore?
Answer: You shot me. You're no son of mine.

Question: What have you done? Quickly. Trust me, my friend, I've brought you this far.
Answer: I want to see the captain.

Question: Where's home?
Answer: The Free City of Braavos.

Question: Why not?
Answer: If your father hears…

Question: Are you sure?
Answer: Yes.

Question: I've been promised to the prince. When will we marry?
Answer: You'll never wed the prince. You'll wed the king.

Question: But I will be queen?
Answer: Oh yes, you'll be queen. For a time. In comes another. Younger, more beautiful, to cast you down and take all you hold dear.

Question: Will the king and I have children?
Answer: No. The king will have 20 children, and you will have 3.

Question: They?
Answer: All of them out there are enemies. They're waiting a night to make sure he's really dead and as soon as they see the stones on his eyes they'll set to work on tearing us apart.

Question: and now our father is dead. And that little monster is out there somewhere drawing breath. Did you set him free?
Answer: Tyrion may be a monster but at least he killed our father on purpose. You killed him by mistake. With stupidity. You're a man of action, aren't you? When it occurs to you to do something you do it, nevermind the consequences. Take a look. Look at the consequences. Here they are. He loved you more than anyone in this world.

Question: Tyrion may be a monster but at least he killed our father on purpose. You killed him by mistake. With stupidity. You're a man of action, aren't you? When it occurs to you to do something you do it, nevermind the consequences. Take a look. Look at the consequences. Here they are. He loved you more than anyone in this world.
Answer: Apologies.

Question: Do you know what it's like to stuff your shit through one of those air holes?
Answer: No. I only know what it's like to pick up your shit and throw it overboard.

Question: Pentos?
Answer: The home of my colleague. Ilyrio Mopatis. A merchant. He and I met many years ago, through mutual friends. A group of people who saw Robert Baratheon for the disaster he was. We tried to do what was best for the realm by supporting the Targaryen restoration. And thus began the chain of mistakes that has led us both here. Things have gotten worse, not better. Westeros needs to be saved from itself.

Question: My lord?
Answer: I don't think I am anymore. A lord. Are you a lord if you kill your father? I don't suppose they revoke your nobility for killing a whore. That has to be happen all the time.

Question: I don't think I am anymore. A lord. Are you a lord if you kill your father? I don't suppose they revoke your nobility for killing a whore. That has to be happen all the time.
Answer: You already drank yourself across the Narrow Sea.

Question: In a box. Why stop now?
Answer: Because we are talking about the future of our country.

Question: You want the same? Same as always?
Answer: You… you don't have to.

Question: Sons of the Harpy?
Answer: Yes, your grace. They left it on the body.

Question: Then they will have to learn to see things differently, Mossador. He did not risk his life fighting for freedom so cowards in masks could take it away. And I did not take up residence in this pyramid so I could watch the city below decline into chaos. What was the name of the man you lost?
Answer: White Rat, your grace.

Question: Why do you come?
Answer: White Rat, the Unsullied who… I have heard they found his body in a brothel. I have heard that more than one Unsullied has been known to visit Meereen's brothels. May I ask you why? Why would an Unsullied go to a brothel?

Question: White Rat, the Unsullied who… I have heard they found his body in a brothel. I have heard that more than one Unsullied has been known to visit Meereen's brothels. May I ask you why? Why would an Unsullied go to a brothel?
Answer: I do not know. I must go.

Question: Shouldn't you be training, too?
Answer: Well, I'm hardly a new recruit. How many brothers can say they've killed a white walker and a Thenn? I might be the first in history!

Question: Well, I'm hardly a new recruit. How many brothers can say they've killed a white walker and a Thenn? I might be the first in history!
Answer: These men need a firm hand. Always have. They're poachers and thieves.

Question: You're not cold, my lady?
Answer: Never. The Lordo s fire lives within me, Jon Snow.

Question: Are you a virgin?
Answer: No.

Question: You know who rules at Winterfell now?
Answer: Roose Bolton.

Question: The traitor who plunged a dagger into Robb Stark's heart. Don't you want to avenge him?
Answer: I want a great many things, your grace. But I'm a sworn brother of the Night's Watch now.

Question: Many don't. You were seen taking the body of a wildling girl north of the Wall. Why?
Answer: It's where she belonged.

Question: Your grace, you want the wildlings to march in your army?
Answer: If they swear to follow me, I'll pardon them. We'll take Winterfell. Once the North is won, I'll declare them citizens of the realm. I'll give them land to live on.

Question: You admire him, don't you?
Answer: I respect him.

Question: How much time do I have?
Answer: Nightfall. The sun drops fast this time of year. Hurry, Jon Snow.

Question: Great warrior? He sings a sword like a girl with palsy.
Answer: My lord.

Question: Does he?
Answer: The gift of a great name. Sometimes that's all one needs.

Question: Will we head north at some point? He said Sansa had a brother at Castle Black. We're a few days ride from the Kingsroad, but that will take us--
Answer: Us? The only reason you're here is that Jaime Lannister told me you weren't safe in the capital. You're hundreds of miles from King's Landing. No one knows what you look like. No one cares. You're safe.

Question: Us? The only reason you're here is that Jaime Lannister told me you weren't safe in the capital. You're hundreds of miles from King's Landing. No one knows what you look like. No one cares. You're safe.
Answer: But I'm you're squire.

Question: Do you even know what a squire is?
Answer: An attendant to a knight?

Question: An attendant to a knight?
Answer: I'm not a knight. That means you're not a squire.

Question: Well, where would I go?
Answer: I don't care, I'm not your mother.

Question: Will you shut your mouth? I didn't ask for advice. I don't want anyone following me. I'm not a leader. All I ever wanted is to fight for a Lord I believed in. The good lords are dead and the rest are monsters.
Answer: You told Lord Royce we were going to the Fingers.

Question: Lord Royce may be as honorable as he thinks he is, but he's not alone in that castle. Do you trust all those knights and ladies, stable boys and serving girls?
Answer: No. Do you trust the carriage driver or the knights escorting us?

Question: No. Do you trust the carriage driver or the knights escorting us?
Answer: No. But I pay them well, and they've seen what happens to men who disappoint me.

Question: So where are we going? To a land where you trust everyone?
Answer: So a land so far from here, even Cersei Lannister can't get her hands on you.

Question: What can I do for you?
Answer: You can forgive me.

Question: What could you possibly have done to warrant my forgiveness?
Answer: I led you into the darkness.

Question: It does. That's the Sunspear bit right there. And that's where the mountains are. And over here is… Sunsnake? Stonespear?
Answer: Sandstone.

Question: What's your name?
Answer: Olyvar, my lady.

Question: Perhaps you might consider being a bit more discreet?
Answer: Why? They all know about me anyway. Everybody knows everything about everyone. What's the point in trying to keep a secret in a place like this?

Question: Why? They all know about me anyway. Everybody knows everything about everyone. What's the point in trying to keep a secret in a place like this?
Answer: In any event… you shouldn't keep your intended waiting.

Question: My intended? Please. Tywin's dead. That means no one can force Cersei to marry me.
Answer: Lucky you.

Question: You think I want that woman married to my brother?
Answer: If she doesn't marry me, she doesn't go to Highgarden. Which means she stays in King's Landing. Which means you're trapped here with Cersei Lannister as your mother-by-law.

Question: Perhaps?
Answer: Perhaps?

Question: Perhaps?
Answer: Eunuch, the spider, the master of whisperers.

Question: Refuse the Kingslayer? A dangerous proposition.
Answer: Not as dangerous as releasing me. You risked your life, your position, everything. Why? You're not family, you owe me nothing.

Question: Not as dangerous as releasing me. You risked your life, your position, everything. Why? You're not family, you owe me nothing.
Answer: I didn't do it for you. I did it for the Seven Kingdoms.

Question: Compassion? Yes. I killed my lover with my bare hands. I shot my own father with a crossbow.
Answer: I never said you were perfect.

Question: What is it you want exactly?
Answer: Peace. Prosperity. A land where the powerful do not prey on the powerless.

Question: Perhaps. And perhaps we've grown so used to horror we assume there's no other way. If you sat on the Iron Throne, would you spread misery throughout the land?
Answer: I will never sit on the Iron Throne.

Question: Who said anything about him? You have a choice my friend. You can stay here at Ilyrio's palace and drink yourself to death, or you can ride with me to Mereen, meet Daenerys Targaryen, and decide if the world is worth fighting for.
Answer: Can I drink myself to death on the road to Meereen?

Question: Can I drink myself to death on the road to Meereen?
Answer: When did the Unsullied start patrolling the streets of Meereen? Looks like your friends haven't been behaving themselves.

Question: When did the Unsullied start patrolling the streets of Meereen? Looks like your friends haven't been behaving themselves.
Answer: The mission to Yunkai was a resounding success. The Wise Masters of Yunkai have agreed to cede power to a council of elders, made up of both the freedmen and the former slaveholders. All matters of consequence will be brought to you for review.

Question: Concessions?
Answer: Politics is the art of compromise, your grace.

Question: The fighting pits? Where slaves fought slaves to the death?
Answer: In the new world that you've brought to us, free men would fight free men.

Question: How many times must I say no before you understand?
Answer: Whatever he wants from me he's not going to get it. If he really believes I'm going to reopen the fighting pits…

Question: What?
Answer: My mother was a whore, I told you that. She liked to drink pear brandy. The older she got, the less she made selling her body, the more she wanted to drink. So one day when I was 12, she sold me to a slaver she fucked the night before.

Question: Why?
Answer: I was a bad child. I wasn't big, but I was quick. And I loved to fight. So they sold me to a man in Tolos who trained fighters for the pits. I had my first match when I was 16.

Question: You were sold into slavery, forced to fight to the death for the amusement of the masters, and you're defending the fighting pits?
Answer: I'm only here because of those pits. I learned to fight like a Dothraki screamer, a Norvoshi priest, a Westerosi knight. Soon I was famous. 10,000 men and women screamed my name when I stepped into the pit. I made so much money for my master he set me free when I died. I joined the Second Sons, and then I met you.

Question: Viserion? Rhaegal?
Answer: Easy. Easy. Easy.

Question: You know what Stannis wants?
Answer: He wants me to bend the knee. And he wants the free folk to fight for him. I'll give him this much

Question: Shouldn't a king be bold?
Answer: Oh, aye. I respect him. If he gets what he wants, I expect he'll be a better ruler than the fools sitting on the Iron Throne the last hundred years. But I'll never serve him.

Question: You spent your life convincing 90 clans to come together for the first time in history. Thenns and Hornfoots, the ice-river clans, even the giants. A life's work uniting them. You didn't do it for power. You didn't do it for glory. You brought them together to save them because none of them will survive the winter, not if they're north of the wall. Isn't their survival more important than your pride?
Answer: Pride? Fuck my pride. This isn't about that.

Question: Pride? Fuck my pride. This isn't about that.
Answer: Then bend the knee and save your people.

Question: And how many tens of thousands are out there right now? How many women? How many children? And you won't go out and rescue them because why? You're afraid of looking afraid.
Answer: Oh, I am afraid. No shame in that. How will they do it? Beheading? Hanging?

Question: Oh, I am afraid. No shame in that. How will they do it? Beheading? Hanging?
Answer: They'll burn you alive.

Question: And what happens to your people? You preserve your dignity and die standing, and they'll sing songs about you. “You'd rather burn than kneel. The great hero.” Until winter comes, and the white walkers come for us all, and there's no one left to sing.
Answer: You're a good lad. Truly, you are. But if you can't understand why I won't enlist my people in a foreigner's war, there's no point explaining.

Question: Ale? Ale?
Answer: Before we left, a maester gave you a raven scroll.

Question: So it was good news.?
Answer: My marriage proposal has been accepted.

Question: Ale?
Answer: I'll have some.

Question: What is it?
Answer: Sansa Stark. Don't look!

Question: You sure?
Answer: She's dyed her hair, but it's her. She's sitting with Petyr Baelish.

Question: Littlefinger?
Answer: A bunch of knights with him.

Question: Bunch? What's a bunch? 100? 6? 20?
Answer: 10, I think. Too many. My lady, I don't think this is the right--

Question: Do you like the taste?
Answer: I don't see what all the fuss is about. Why do men love it so much?

Question: I don't see what all the fuss is about. Why do men love it so much?
Answer: It gives some men courage.

Question: Does it give you courage?
Answer: That's far enough.

Question: We've met. With Renly Baratheon. What did he say about you? He said, "You're a loyalty comes free of charge." Someone appears to have paid quite a bit for it since then.
Answer: Lady Sansa, before your mother's death, I was her sworn sword. I gave my word I would find you and protect you. I will shield your back and keep your council, and give my life for yours if need be. I swear it by the old gods and the new.

Question: Please, Lady Brienne. No need for such formality. You are Catelyn Stark's sworn sword?
Answer: I was.

Question: Then what did happen?
Answer: He was murdered by a shadow. A shadow with a face of Stannis Baratheon.

Question: A shadow? With a face? This woman swore to protect Renly; she failed. She swore to protect your mother; she failed. Why would I want somebody with your history of failure guiding Lady Sansa?
Answer: Why should you have any say in her affairs?

Question: Why should you have any say in her affairs?
Answer: Because I am her uncle. I married her Aunt Lysa shortly before my belovedo s untimely death. We're family now, and you're an outsider. Forgive me, Lady Brienne, but experiences made me wary of outsiders.

Question: We don't want our new friend wandering the countryside alone. The roads of these parts aren't safe. Why don't you stay?
Answer: He asked you to stay.

Question: Podrick?
Answer: Yes, my lady?

Question: Yes, my lady?
Answer: You can stand now.

Question: Yes, my lady. Sansa Stark?
Answer: Wary of strangers, as she should me. I saw her riding on the East Trail with Littlefinger. We'll follow them.

Question: Do you think she's safe from Littlefinger?
Answer: No, my lady.

Question: What?
Answer: Not so loud.

Question: And what has your caution brought? Our eldest child murdered at his own wedding. Our only daughter shipped off to Dorne. Our baby boy sent to marry that smirking whore from Highgarden.
Answer: I'll make things better.

Question: No army. Do you know where they're keeping her?
Answer: Oberyn mentioned the Water Gardens.

Question: I'll find her. Is there anything else, your grace?
Answer: You're going to Dorne? A one-handed man? Alone?

Question: You're going to Dorne? A one-handed man? Alone?
Answer: I never said I was going alone.

Question: No sunflowers. I don't like yellow. Roses are very nice, definitely roses. And music. I adore music. But no flutes, I hate flutes! We can have a harp if you like, but no flutes. Then there's the food. Food is the most important thing, don't you agree? We're going to need pigeon pies. That's what they eat in the capital, don't they?
Answer: Don't they?

Question: Don't they?
Answer: Don't who?

Question: Don't who?
Answer: People eat pigeon pie in the capital.

Question: It's a fine place, isn't it? A fine place. I never thought I'd end up settling down in a place like this.
Answer: You won't.

Question: Pardon?
Answer: We won't get to live at Stokeworth. When Mother dies, my sister gets the castle because she's older.

Question: You know what I think? I think you're a good person. And your sister is a mean person.
Answer: She is.

Question: Who's that?
Answer: Jaime fucking Lannister.

Question: Beautiful bride you've chosen. When were you planning on getting married?
Answer: Just get on with it.

Question: On with what?
Answer: What you're here for. There's no way this little visit could possibly mean anything good for me.

Question: How is this good for me?
Answer: Cause you're going to come with me and help me with something important. And when we return, I'm going to give you a much better girl, and a much better castle.

Question: Return from where?
Answer: As far south as south goes.

Question: You would have me go to war?
Answer: You would have me go to war?

Question: You would have me go to war?
Answer: The whole country would have you go to war.

Question: Oberyn is dead. And this Lannister girl skips about the Water Gardens eating our food, breathing our air. How many of your brothers and sisters do they have to kill?
Answer: I loved my brother. And you made him very happy. For that you will always have a place in my heart. But we do not mutilate little girls for vengeance. Not here. Not while I rule.

Question: And how long will that be?
Answer: The Unsullied are too conspicuous.

Question: Anyone can see you coming from a mile off. Of course you haven't found any Sons of the Harpy. You haven't, have you?
Answer: My Second Sons, on the other hand, they drink, they whore, fight in the streets--they blend in. They overhear things in taverns, follow people from the taverns to nice, quiet alleys, break a few fingers, overhear a few more things. Before you know it...

Question: In a hurry? You're afraid?
Answer: Unsullied fear nothing.

Question: Why?
Answer: For one thing, he may have valuable information.

Question: How do you know that?
Answer: Because I questioned him.

Question: Why should he want to bring back slavery? What did it do for him?
Answer: Perhaps the only thing that gave him pride was knowing that there was someone lower than he was.

Question: And how do you know this?
Answer: Everyone knows this.

Question: About what?
Answer: About your father. About the Mad King.

Question: The Mad King? You're here to remind me of my enemies' lies? Consider me reminded.
Answer: Your Grace, I served in his Kingsguard. I was at his side from the first. Your enemies did not lie.

Question: When I agreed to come with you, did I misrepresent my intentions? Besides, what is there for me to do inside this fucking box?
Answer: You don't like it?

Question: You don't like it?
Answer: I want to take a walk.

Question: Are we really going to spend the entire road to Volantis talking about the futility of everything?
Answer: You're right. No point. The road to Volantis? You said we were going to Meereen. What's in Volantis?

Question: You're right. No point. The road to Volantis? You said we were going to Meereen. What's in Volantis?
Answer: The road to Meereen.

Question: And what do you hope to find at the end of the road to Meereen?
Answer: I told you. A ruler.

Question: Why?
Answer: Cause I liked it. Power. Even as a servant.

Question: How many dwarves are there in the world? Is Cersei going to kill them all?
Answer: Not him.

Question: Are you trying to deceive your Queen? Shall I throw them in a cell, Your Grace?
Answer: That won't be necessary, Ser Meryn. I don't want to dissuade the other hunters. Mistakes will be made.

Question: You're the Hand of the King?
Answer: No, Uncle. Clearly it would not be appropriate for a woman to assume that role. I'm merely advising my son until he comes of age and chooses a Hand for himself.

Question: Your Grace, him? This man? This embarrassment to the Citadel? Your Grace, what qualifications can he possibly have for this post?
Answer: The qualification of loyalty, Grand Maester. That's far more than the eunuch ever had. Far more than many ever have.

Question: What mission?
Answer: That is not your concern as Master of War.

Question: You would abandon your king in his time of need?
Answer: If he wants to send for me, I will be waiting for him. At Casterly Rock.

Question: Hmm! Did you know that the youngest Lord Commander in history, Osric Stark, was elected at the age of 10?
Answer: I know "S".

Question: How old were you when you learned to read?
Answer: Three.

Question: Three?! Who taught you, your mother?
Answer: No. Old Maester Cressen did. I had a lot of time to practice. My mother kept me inside because...

Question: What do you call it in the South, what happened to your face?
Answer: Greyscale. What do you call it north of the Wall?

Question: Greyscale. What do you call it north of the Wall?
Answer: I don't know. But two of my sisters had it. They both died. How did they cure you?

Question: I don't know. But two of my sisters had it. They both died. How did they cure you?
Answer: I don't remember. I was a baby. Lots of people came and tried, I think. Whatever they did, it went away. What happened to your sisters?

Question: I don't remember. I was a baby. Lots of people came and tried, I think. Whatever they did, it went away. What happened to your sisters?
Answer: My father made them move out of the keep into the huts outside. None of us were allowed to go near them. But we heard them. Especially at night. They started to sound... not like themselves.

Question: Did you ever see them?
Answer: Only once at the end. They were covered with it. Their faces, their arms. They acted like animals. My father had to drag them out to the woods on a rope.

Question: What did he do to them in the woods?
Answer: Mother.

Question: Why?
Answer: She's a wildling.

Question: Who then? You?
Answer: No. Only one of their own.

Question: Do you know this wretched girl Lyanna Mormont?
Answer: The Lord Commander's niece.

Question: That amuses you?
Answer: I apologize, Your Grace. Northerners can be a bit like the free folk. Loyal to their own.

Question: Unpleasant man. He thinks you're a traitor. What's your life going to be like on the Wall with Thorne in command?
Answer: Unpleasant, I expect.

Question: He'll make you a Stark with the stroke of a pen?
Answer: It's the first thing I ever remember wanting. I'd daydream that my father would ask the king, and just like that I would never be the bastard of Winterfell again.
